Original: Nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita mi ritrovai per una selva oscura, ché la diritta via era smarrita
Translate: "About halfway through my existence, I found myself lost in a dark wood, because I had lost the correct way."

Original: Ahi quanto a dir qual era è cosa dura esta selva selvaggia e aspra e forte che nel pensier rinova la paura
Translate: "There was a terrible forest, inextricable and wild to the point that even the idea of being inside makes you afraid."

Original: Tant’è amara che poco è più morte
Translate: "It is so frightening that death is almost little,

Original: ma per trattar del ben ch’i’ vi trovai, dirò de l’altre cose ch’i’ v’ ho scorte
Translate: but to describe the good that I have found within it, I can talk about other things that I have seen you."

Original: Io non so ben ridir com’i’ v’intrai, tant’era pien di sonno a quel punto che la verace via abbandonai
Translate: "I didn't have the clarity to describe how he got in, I was so sleepy when I took the right path."

Original: Ma poi ch’i’ fui al piè d’un colle giunto, là dove terminava quella valle che m’avea di paura il cor compunto,  guardai in alto e vidi le sue spalle vestite già de’ raggi del pianeta che mena dritto altrui per ogne calle
Translate: "After reaching the feet of a hill, at the end of the valley that had aroused fear and sadness in me, I lifted up my eyes and had the vision of its summit illuminated by the light of the sun, indicating me the right way to follow."

Original: Allor fu la paura un poco queta, che nel lago del cor m’era durata la notte ch’i’ passai con tanta pieta
Translate: "That night I spent with a deep anxiety that I had felt in my heart, but then the fear subsided a little."

Original: E come quei che con lena affannata, uscito fuor del pelago a la riva, si volge a l’acqua perigliosa e guata,  così l’animo mio, ch’ancor fuggiva, si volse a retro a rimirar lo passo che non lasciò già mai persona viva
Translate: "Similar to the shipwreck thrown on the shore, which anxiously observes the stormy waters from which he was saved, so I also looked at the terrible way that did not let any escape of salvation be seen."

Original: Poi ch’èi posato un poco il corpo lasso, ripresi via per la piaggia diserta, sì che ’l piè fermo sempre era ’l più basso
Translate: "After the brief pause I had given to my tired body, I resumed climbing the desert slope of the hill, always putting the firmest foot on the ground lower."

Original: Ed ecco, quasi al cominciar de l'erta, una lonza leggera e presta molto, che di pel macolato era coverta
Translate: "Located on the slope that preceded the beginning of the ascent, a slender and snappy lion covered by a cloak of spotted hair profiled on the horizon."

Original: e non mi si partia dinanzi al volto, anzi ’mpediva tanto il mio cammino, ch’i’ fui per ritornar più volte vòlto
Translate: "He didn't stand aside when I came to his presence, in fact he blocked the passage so many times that I seriously thought of turning back."

Original: Temp’era dal principio del mattino, e ’l sol montava ’n sù con quelle stelle ch’eran con lui quando l’amor divino  mosse di prima quelle cose belle
Translate: "In the early hours of the morning, with the sun rising together with that constellation of Creation, divine love began to move beautiful things."

Original: sì ch’a bene sperar m’era cagione di quella fiera a la gaetta pelle  l’ora del tempo e la dolce stagione
Translate: The brightness of the sun and the flowers blossomed in spring gave reasons for the beautiful spotted tiger.

Original: ma non sì che paura non mi desse la vista che m'apparve d'un leone
Translate: "However, despite everything, I felt frightened in the face of the sudden vision of a lion"

Original: Questi parea che contra me venisse con la test’alta e con rabbiosa fame, sì che parea che l’aere ne tremesse
Translate: "This individual was heading towards me, with a strong and furious air, to the point that even the atmosphere seemed to tremble."

Original: Ed una lupa, che di tutte brame sembiava carca ne la sua magrezza, e molte genti fé già viver grame,  questa mi porse tanto di gravezza con la paura ch’uscia di sua vista, ch’io perdei la speranza de l’altezza
Translate: "A wolf profiled on the horizon, as thin as desire and burying with his presence the poverty of many."

Original: E qual è quei che volontieri acquista, e giugne ’l tempo che perder lo face, che ’n tutti suoi pensier piange e s’attrista
Translate: "I felt so anxious and had such a fear at the sight of his appearance that I lost the confidence to get to the top of the hill."

Original: tal mi fece la bestia sanza pace, che, venendomi ’ncontro, a poco a poco mi ripigneva là dove ’l sol tace
Translate: "so he made me the wild animal without peace, that coming to me pushed me little by little down, where there was no light."

Original: Mentre ch’i’ rovinava in basso loco, dinanzi a li occhi mi si fu offerto chi per lungo silenzio parea fioco
Translate: "Going down to the forest, a figure profiled in the darkness before my eyes, but I could not distinguish it clearly."

Original: Quando vidi costui nel gran diserto, "Miserere di me", gridai a lui, "qual che tu sii, od ombra od omo certo
Translate: "When he appeared in desolation, I cried out loud: "Have mercy on me, whatever you are - a creature or someone really existing!"

Original: Rispuosemi: "Non omo, omo già fui, e li parenti miei furon lombardi, mantoani per patrïa ambedui
Translate: "I answered: "No, I am no longer a man, I have been before. My parents were originally from Lombardy and both came from Mantua."

Original: Nacqui sub Iulio, ancor che fosse tardi, e vissi a Roma sotto ’l buono Augusto nel tempo de li dèi falsi e bugiardi
Translate: "I was born under the reign of Julius Caesar, but I lived in Rome during the peaceful and prosperous empire of the eminent Augustus, in an age where the ancient pagan cults were still strongly practiced."

Original: Poeta fui, e cantai di quel giusto figliuol d’Anchise che venne di Troia, poi che ’l superbo Ilïón fu combusto
Translate: "I sang of Aeneas, the son of Anchise, who saved himself from the fall of the proud Troy consumed by the flames."

Original: Ma tu perché ritorni a tanta noia? perché non sali il dilettoso monte ch’è principio e cagion di tutta gioia?"
Translate: "Why don't you choose the joyful hill, which is the source of all well-being instead of returning to the evil of the forest?"

Original: "Or se’ tu quel Virgilio e quella fonte che spandi di parlar sì largo fiume?", rispuos’io lui con vergognosa fronte
Translate: ""So you are Virgilio and that spring that flows such a great river of words?""I asked him embarrassed."

Original: "O de li altri poeti onore e lume, vagliami ’l lungo studio e ’l grande amore che m’ ha fatto cercar lo tuo volume
Translate: "I beg you to enlighten my steps, bright figure among other poets; the strength of dedication and affection that led me to instruct me in your work is all I need."

Original: Tu se’ lo mio maestro e ’l mio autore, tu se’ solo colui da cu’ io tolsi lo bello stilo che m’ ha fatto onore
Translate: I consider you as a master and an example, I treated my beautiful style alone, which made me famous.

Original: Vedi la bestia per cu’ io mi volsi
Translate: I spotted the creature that forced me to change direction.

Original: aiutami da lei, famoso saggio, ch’ella mi fa tremar le vene e i polsi"
Translate: "O great wise man, your strength shakes every drop of my blood, so please help me."

Original: "A te convien tenere altro vïaggio", rispuose, poi che lagrimar mi vide, "se vuo’ campar d’esto loco selvaggio
Translate: "If you want to get rid of this wild land, you have to take another adventure," he replied after seeing me cry."

Original: ché questa bestia, per la qual tu gride, non lascia altrui passar per la sua via, ma tanto lo ’mpedisce che l’uccide
Translate: "No one can go through the road of the beast that leads to screaming, pain of annihilation."

Original: e ha natura sì malvagia e ria, che mai non empie la bramosa voglia, e dopo ’l pasto ha più fame che pria
Translate: "His devilish character has never allowed him to satisfy his greed, and every time he eats he is even more hungry."

Original: Molti son li animali a cui s’ammoglia, e più saranno ancora, infin che ’l veltro verrà, che la farà morir con doglia
Translate: "Animals choose a companion, increasing more and more until the hunting dog arrives that causes them to die with suffering."

Original: Questi non ciberà terra né peltro, ma sapïenza, amore e virtute, e sua nazion sarà tra feltro e feltro
Translate: "This one does not care for material well-being, but seeks spiritual inspiration and will find his home among the felt fabric."

Original: Di quella umile Italia fia salute per cui morì la vergine Cammilla, Eurialo e Turno e Niso di ferute
Translate: "It will be the salvation of the noble Italy, for which Eurialo and Niso lost their lives in battle, Turno and Camilla the virgin endured pains."

Original: Questi la caccerà per ogne villa, fin che l’avrà rimessa ne lo ’nferno, là onde ’nvidia prima dipartilla
Translate: "He will hunt her down in every part of the world, until he has sent her back to hell, from where she was sent out because of envy for the first time."

Original: Ond’io per lo tuo me’ penso e discerno che tu mi segui, e io sarò tua guida, e trarrotti di qui per loco etterno
Translate: "I think it's in your greatest interest to go where I go, let me lead you and take you to a place of the worlds beyond."

Original: ove udirai le disperate strida, vedrai li antichi spiriti dolenti, ch’a la seconda morte ciascun grida
Translate: "You will see the tormented shadows of the lost, crying desperately and asking for the final end."

Original: e vederai color che son contenti nel foco, perché speran di venire quando che sia a le beate genti
Translate: "Those who rejoice in punishment, for they trust in the enlightenment of Paradise in the future."

Original: A le quai poi se tu vorrai salire, anima fia a ciò più di me degna: con lei ti lascerò nel mio partire
Translate: "If you decide to come up and see these places, there will be another person more suitable than me to accompany you: when I leave, you will be in good hands."

Original: ché quello imperador che là sù regna, perch’i’ fu’ ribellante a la sua legge, non vuol che ’n sua città per me si vegna
Translate: That ruler above does not grant me access to his city because my rebellion against his law is known.

Original: In tutte parti impera e quivi regge
Translate: Men recognize God's sovereignty over every place in the Universe and in Paradise He reigns triumphant.

Original: quivi è la sua città e l’alto seggio: oh felice colui cu’ ivi elegge
Translate: "Oh, blessed is he who chooses to dwell in this city, with his second throne!"

Original: E io a lui: "Poeta, io ti richeggio per quello Dio che tu non conoscesti, acciò ch’io fugga questo male e peggio,  che tu mi meni là dov’or dicesti, sì ch’io veggia la porta di san Pietro e color cui tu fai cotanto mesti"
Translate: "Then I said to the poet: "I pray in the name of that God whom you have never known to be free from this suffering and even greater others, I beg you to lead me where you said, so I can see the door of St. Peter and the people so injured as described."

Original: Allor si mosse, e io li tenni dietro
Translate: "He began his journey, and I accompanied him.

Original: Lo giorno se n’andava, e l’aere bruno toglieva li animai che sono in terra da le fatiche loro
Translate: The approaching of the night interrupted the efforts of animals living on earth.

Original: e io sol uno m’apparecchiava a sostener la guerra sì del cammino e sì de la pietate, che ritrarrà la mente che non erra
Translate: "I was the only one who prepared me for the fear and terror of the road that will advance, a track so clear as if it had been painted by my infallible mind."

Original: O muse, o alto ingegno, or m’aiutate
Translate: "Oh, godly muse and majestic poetic intellect, give me some of your wisdom."

Original: o mente che scrivesti ciò ch’io vidi, qui si parrà la tua nobilitate
Translate: You have noted what you have seen: here it will show you your nobility.

Original: Io cominciai: "Poeta che mi guidi, guarda la mia virtù s’ell’è possente, prima ch’a l’alto passo tu mi fidi
Translate: "As I set out on my way, I exclaimed: "Oh poet, consider whether I am strong enough to go on this difficult adventure!""

Original: Tu dici che di Silvïo il parente, corruttibile ancora, ad immortale secolo andò, e fu sensibilmente
Translate: "It is said that Silvio's father, still alive, passed into the afterlife along with his physical body."

Original: Però, se l’avversario d’ogne male cortese i fu, pensando l’alto effetto ch’uscir dovea di lui, e ’l chi e ’l quale  non pare indegno ad omo d’intelletto
Translate: "Man and his blessings undoubtedly deserve respect from those who are intelligent, since he was kind to the ruler of evils; which should have had a great impact."

Original: ch’e’ fu de l’alma Roma e di suo impero ne l’empireo ciel per padre eletto:  la quale e ’l quale, a voler dir lo vero, fu stabilita per lo loco santo u’ siede il successor del maggior Piero
Translate: "He, chosen as the founder of the noble Rome and its kingdom, established an empire so grand that it was considered a sacred abode for the successor of the first pope."

Original: Per quest’andata onde li dai tu vanto, intese cose che furon cagione di sua vittoria e del papale ammanto
Translate: "After the journey described by you, Enea acquired the knowledge needed to achieve victory and establish the papal mantle."

Original: Andovvi poi lo Vas d’elezïone, per recarne conforto a quella fede ch’è principio a la via di salvazione
Translate: Then went the instrument of choice to cement that faith which is the first step towards salvation.

Original: Ma io, perché venirvi? o chi ’l concede? Io non Enëa, io non Paulo sono
Translate: Why should I do so and who gives me permission? I am certainly not Aeneas or St Paul.

Original: me degno a ciò né io né altri ’l crede
Translate: No one believes that I am able to carry out this mission.

Original: Per che, se del venire io m’abbandono, temo che la venuta non sia folle
Translate: "If I decide to take this journey with you, I'm afraid it might be insane."

Original: Se’ savio intendi me’ ch’i’ non ragiono"
Translate: You have a deeper understanding than I can express.

Original: E qual è quei che disvuol ciò che volle e per novi pensier cangia proposta, sì che dal cominciar tutto si tolle,  tal mi fec’ïo ’n quella oscura costa, perché, pensando, consumai la ’mpresa che fu nel cominciar cotanto tosta
Translate: "So as the one who was initially excited to look for something and then, because of the reflection and possibly the encounter with new ideas, he changed course completely, so it was for me in the mysterious places: thinking about it I abandoned my project hesitantly formulated."

Original: "S’i’ ho ben la parola tua intesa", rispuose del magnanimo quell’ombra, "l’anima tua è da viltade offesa
Translate: "The silhouette of that person of high lineage replied, "If I have interpreted your speech correctly, your soul is a slave of cowardice."

Original: la qual molte fïate l’omo ingombra sì che d’onrata impresa lo rivolve, come falso veder bestia quand’ombra
Translate: "Just as a false image drives an animal crazy when it is reflected in a mirror, so man can be crushed by fear and dissuade from venture into deeds worthy of merit."

Original: Da questa tema acciò che tu ti solve, dirotti perch’io venni e quel ch’io ’ntesi nel primo punto che di te mi dolve
Translate: "To help you get out of this fear, I'll explain why I came here and how I felt when I felt your suffering."

Original: Io era tra color che son sospesi, e donna mi chiamò beata e bella, tal che di comandare io la richiesi
Translate: "While I was among the forgotten souls in the Abyss, I was called by such a beautifully beautiful woman that I invoked her command."

Original: Lucevan li occhi suoi più che la stella
Translate: The shimmering brightness of his eyes seemed to be that of a star.

Original: e cominciommi a dir soave e piana, con angelica voce, in sua favella:
Translate: "The tone of his voice was as sweet as the song of an angel, and when he spoke it seemed that the words came out softly."

Original: "O anima cortese mantoana, di cui la fama ancor nel mondo dura, e durerà quanto ’l mondo lontana,
Translate: "O noble soul of Mantua, whose memory will survive the world as long as it lasts."

Original: l’amico mio, e non de la ventura, ne la diserta piaggia è impedito sì nel cammin, che vòlt’è per paura
Translate: "He, who had loved me unconditionally on the lone ridge of a hill, was so paralyzed by fear that he had to turn back."

Original: e temo che non sia già sì smarrito, ch’io mi sia tardi al soccorso levata, per quel ch’i’ ho di lui nel cielo udito
Translate: "I believe that from what I have heard about him from above, he is already so exhausted that I have not arrived in time to save him."

Original: Or movi, e con la tua parola ornata e con ciò c’ ha mestieri al suo campare, l’aiuta sì ch’i’ ne sia consolata
Translate: "Start at once, fill the void with your affectionate words and do everything in your power to save and calm me."

Original: I’ son Beatrice che ti faccio andare
Translate: "I, Beatrice, will lead you."

Original: vegno del loco ove tornar disio
Translate: I want to go back to where I came from.

Original: amor mi mosse, che mi fa parlare
Translate: I felt the love that made me come here and talk to you.

Original: Quando sarò dinanzi al segnor mio, di te mi loderò sovente a lui"
Translate: "When I find myself in front of the Lord, I will often celebrate your name."

Original: Tacette allora, e poi comincia’ io:  "O donna di virtù sola per cui l’umana spezie eccede ogne contento di quel ciel c’ ha minor li cerchi sui,  tanto m’aggrada il tuo comandamento, che l’ubidir, se già fosse, m’è tardi
Translate: "Then he kept quiet and I said, ""O noble lady, you are an example of which humanity is deeply proud. Your prayer finds me so in tune that even if I had performed before the time would have come anyway.""

Original: più non t’è uo’ ch’aprirmi il tuo talento
Translate: All you have to do is tell me what you want.

Original: Ma dimmi la cagion che non ti guardi de lo scender qua giuso in questo centro de l’ampio loco ove tornar tu ardi"
Translate: "Would you like to return to the vast place you come from, but what is the reason why you're not afraid as you descend into this Hellless abyss?"

Original: "Da che tu vuo’ saver cotanto a dentro, dirotti brievemente", mi rispuose, "perch’i’ non temo di venir qua entro
Translate: ""She said to me: ""I'm not afraid to come in, I can explain briefly why if you want more information"."

Original: Temer si dee di sole quelle cose c' hanno potenza di fare altrui male
Translate: One must be afraid only of those things that have the strength to harm others.

Original: de l'altre no, ché non son paurose
Translate: "not the others, for they are not threatening."

Original: I’ son fatta da Dio, sua mercé, tale, che la vostra miseria non mi tange, né fiamma d’esto ’ncendio non m’assale
Translate: God has made me so blessed that poverty cannot touch me and no fire of Hell can harm me.

Original: Donna è gentil nel ciel che si compiange di questo 'mpedimento ov'io ti mando, sì che duro giudicio là sù frange
Translate: "There is a noble woman in heaven who is sorry for this barrier, and I ask you for your help so that we can overcome the hard divine sentence."

Original: Questa chiese Lucia in suo dimando e disse: - Or ha bisogno il tuo fedele di te, e io a te lo raccomando -
Translate: "Lucia, your faithful one needs you. Please let me recommend you take care of him."

Original: Lucia, nimica di ciascun crudele, si mosse, e venne al loco dov’i’ era, che mi sedea con l’antica Rachele
Translate: "Lucia, friend of the merciful, walked as far as Rachel and I were of great age."

Original: Disse: - Beatrice, loda di Dio vera, ché non soccorri quei che t’amò tanto, ch’uscì per te de la volgare schiera?  Non odi tu la pieta del suo pianto, non vedi tu la morte che ’l combatte su la fiumana ove ’l mar non ha vanto? -
Translate: ""Beatrice, you who have been incensed by God, why not help the one who has had so much love to overcome the vulgar crowd? Don't you feel the anguish of his tears? Don't you see death in struggle with the sea of stormy sin?

Original: Al mondo non fur mai persone ratte a far lor pro o a fuggir lor danno, com’io, dopo cotai parole fatte,  venni qua giù del mio beato scanno, fidandomi del tuo parlare onesto, ch’onora te e quei ch’udito l’ hanno"
Translate: Never has anyone been so quick in chasing their own interests or fleeing from their own misfortunes like me after listening to your noble words, nobles who honor you and those who have heard"."

Original: Poscia che m’ebbe ragionato questo, li occhi lucenti lagrimando volse, per che mi fece del venir più presto
Translate: "After telling me this with shiny eyes of tears, I felt moved to come faster.

Original: E venni a te così com’ella volse: d’inanzi a quella fiera ti levai che del bel monte il corto andar ti tolse
Translate: I came to you as you wished: I saved you from the proud beast that forbade you a smooth ascent to the hill.

Original: Dunque: che è perché, perché restai, perché tanta viltà nel core allette, perché ardire e franchezza non hai,
Translate: "Why are you stuck here after all you've been through? Why do you resist fear and adopt willpower seems to be an impossible task for you?"

Original: poscia che tai tre donne benedette curan di te ne la corte del cielo,
Translate: Three blessed saints pray for you in the kingdom of heaven.

Original: e ’l mio parlar tanto ben ti promette?"
Translate: My promises are to bring you every good.

Original: Quali fioretti dal notturno gelo chinati e chiusi, poi che ’l sol li ’mbianca, si drizzan tutti aperti in loro stelo,
Translate: "As flowers bending under the night frost, but rays of sunshine illuminate them and lift up their stems, plants smell the air at dawn."

Original: tal mi fec’io di mia virtude stanca, e tanto buono ardire al cor mi corse, ch’i’ cominciai come persona franca:
Translate: "I resorted to my tired moral strength, and my heart filled with boldness so that I began to speak with new vigour:"

Original: "Oh pietosa colei che mi soccorse
Translate: "Oh woman with an ice heart who had just helped me"

Original: e te cortese ch’ubidisti tosto a le vere parole che ti porse
Translate: and you kindly immediately obeyed the true words he said to you

Original: Tu m’ hai con disiderio il cor disposto sì al venir con le parole tue, ch’i’ son tornato nel primo proposto
Translate: Your words had led me to such a great desire that I had returned to my original intention to come.

Original: Or va, ch’un sol volere è d’ambedue: tu duca, tu segnore e tu maestro"
Translate: "We both have the same desire: you are my leader, my ruler, and I will take you as your guide. Let's go now!"

Original: Così li dissi e poi che mosso fue,
Translate: "I showed him the direction, and after he had taken the way of the journey"

Original: intrai per lo cammino alto e silvestro
Translate: I faced the difficult and impervious path

Original: ’Per me si va ne la città dolente, per me si va ne l'etterno dolore, per me si va tra la perduta gente
Translate: "You enter the city of pain through me, I lead to that place of infinite suffering, I walk among the scattered souls."

Original: Giustizia mosse il mio alto fattore
Translate: My Supreme Creator has acted rightly.

Original: fecemi la divina podestate, la somma sapïenza e ’l primo amore
Translate: "The supreme power, ultimate wisdom and primordial love have been granted to me."

Original: Dinanzi a me non fuor cose create se non etterne, e io etterno duro
Translate: "Before me, only the eternal existed, and I will remain forever."

Original: Lasciate ogne speranza, voi ch’intrate’
Translate: ""He who crosses the threshold of this place, abandons all hope"."

Original: Queste parole di colore oscuro vid’ïo scritte al sommo d’una porta
Translate: I saw these words written in gloomy ink over a door.

Original: per ch’io: "Maestro, il senso lor m’è duro"
Translate: I asked my teacher why I couldn't understand the meaning.

Original: Ed elli a me, come persona accorta: "Qui si convien lasciare ogne sospetto
Translate: "As a wise man, he said to me: "It is necessary to act without delay"."

Original: ogne viltà convien che qui sia morta
Translate: You don't have to be afraid.

Original: Noi siam venuti al loco ov’i’ t’ ho detto che tu vedrai le genti dolorose c’ hanno perduto il ben de l’intelletto"
Translate: We came to the point where I anticipated you to observe the condemned souls who no longer have the blessing of heavenly wisdom.

Original: E poi che la sua mano a la mia puose con lieto volto, ond’io mi confortai, mi mise dentro a le segrete cose
Translate: "After he wrapped me in a protective embrace, his smiling face comforted me and accompanied me to that place distinct from earthly existence."

Original: Quivi sospiri, pianti e alti guai risonavan per l’aere sanza stelle, per ch’io al cominciar ne lagrimai
Translate: "The sighs, tears and laments tore up the night without stars, making me cry from the beginning."

Original: Diverse lingue, orribili favelle, parole di dolore, accenti d’ira, voci alte e fioche, e suon di man con elle  facevano un tumulto, il qual s’aggira sempre in quell’aura sanza tempo tinta, come la rena quando turbo spira
Translate: "Unknown pronunciations, cries of pain, blasphemies filled with rage, harsh and suffocated voices that mix with the sound of the beaten hands in rhythm created a thunderous roar that plunges into the still air like the sand in the wind during a storm."

Original: E io ch’avea d’error la testa cinta, dissi: "Maestro, che è quel ch’i’ odo? e che gent’è che par nel duol sì vinta?"
Translate: "I had my perplexities and so I asked: "Master, what do I feel? And who are these downcast by displeasure?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Questo misero modo tegnon l’anime triste di coloro che visser sanza ’nfamia e sanza lodo
Translate: He replied: "This is the sad fate of those who have lived neither with glory nor with reproach!"

Original: Mischiate sono a quel cattivo coro de li angeli che non furon ribelli né fur fedeli a Dio, ma per sé fuoro
Translate: "I am among those angels who have taken no part in the rebellion against God, nor loyal to the Lord, but have adhered to a neutral attitude."

Original: Caccianli i ciel per non esser men belli, né lo profondo inferno li riceve, ch’alcuna gloria i rei avrebber d’elli"
Translate: "Neither Heaven restrains them, so as not to cloud their majesty, nor does Hell grant them a place among his hells because the condemned cannot obtain any glory from their company."

Original: E io: "Maestro, che è tanto greve a lor che lamentar li fa sì forte?"
Translate: "I asked the Master: "What is causing them so much pain that they cause such complaints?"."

Original: Rispuose: "Dicerolti molto breve
Translate: He said to me, "I'll give you a quick explanation."

Original: Questi non hanno speranza di morte, e la lor cieca vita è tanto bassa, che ’nvidïosi son d’ogne altra sorte
Translate: "Souls cannot hope to be freed from their present miserable condition, they ardently desire any other destiny."

Original: Fama di loro il mondo esser non lassa
Translate: There is no sign of their passage into the world.

Original: misericordia e giustizia li sdegna:
Translate: God's mercy and justice are outraged by this.

Original: non ragioniam di lor, ma guarda e passa"
Translate: "Let's ignore them, give them a quick look and move on."

Original: E io, che riguardai, vidi una ’nsegna che girando correva tanto ratta, che d’ogne posa mi parea indegna
Translate: "And I, observing, noticed a sign that rolled with such speed that it seemed never had to end."

Original: e dietro le venìa sì lunga tratta di gente, ch’i’ non averei creduto che morte tanta n’avesse disfatta
Translate: "Behind it there were so many souls, that I never thought death had taken so many lives."

Original: Poscia ch’io v’ebbi alcun riconosciuto, vidi e conobbi l’ombra di colui che fece per viltade il gran rifiuto
Translate: "Once recognized some of them, I saw the figure of those who had contemptuously rejected a great destiny."

Original: Incontanente intesi e certo fui che questa era la setta d’i cattivi, a Dio spiacenti e a’ nemici sui
Translate: I immediately realized that they were the cowards so hated by God as by his adversaries.

Original: Questi sciaurati, che mai non fur vivi, erano ignudi e stimolati molto da mosconi e da vespe ch’eran ivi
Translate: "These unfortunate ones, who never lived a real existence, were discovered and annoyed by flies and wasps in every direction."

Original: Elle rigavan lor di sangue il volto, che, mischiato di lagrime, a’ lor piedi da fastidiosi vermi era ricolto
Translate: "Their bloody face fell to the ground, accompanied by tears that were then picked up by repulsive worms."

Original: E poi ch’a riguardar oltre mi diedi, vidi genti a la riva d’un gran fiume
Translate: "When I surveyed his gaze, I saw souls in the vicinity of a large river."

Original: per ch’io dissi: "Maestro, or mi concedi  ch’i’ sappia quali sono, e qual costume le fa di trapassar parer sì pronte, com’i’ discerno per lo fioco lume"
Translate: "I remember then I asked the Master: "Who are those people, and what is the force that pushes them to cross the darkness as they appear so eager to do so?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Le cose ti fier conte quando noi fermerem li nostri passi su la trista riviera d’Acheronte"
Translate: He told me that the circumstances would be clearer once he reached the sad shore of the Acheron River.

Original: Allor con li occhi vergognosi e bassi, temendo no ’l mio dir li fosse grave, infino al fiume del parlar mi trassi
Translate: "Without raising my eyes, fearful of being able to annoy him if I had said anything, I remained silent until we reached the river."

Original: Ed ecco verso noi venir per nave un vecchio, bianco per antico pelo, gridando: "Guai a voi, anime prave
Translate: "!An elder with a white thick beard, who approached us on a boat, cried out to us: "Be careful, you corrupt people!."

Original: Non isperate mai veder lo cielo: i’ vegno per menarvi a l’altra riva ne le tenebre etterne, in caldo e ’n gelo
Translate: "Never hope to admire the stars: I am here to lead you to the other side, into eternal darkness, between fire and cold light."

Original: E tu che se’ costì, anima viva, pàrtiti da cotesti che son morti"
Translate: "Get yourself away from those who have already sprung, or essence in the flesh."

Original: Ma poi che vide ch’io non mi partiva,  disse: "Per altra via, per altri porti verrai a piaggia, non qui, per passare:
Translate: "Seeing that I was not moving away, he said, "You will reach the destination with another route, in ports other than this one here; you will certainly not pass by here.""

Original: più lieve legno convien che ti porti"
Translate: A lighter ship than mine will be taken from you.

Original: E ’l duca lui: "Caron, non ti crucciare: vuolsi così colà dove si puote ciò che si vuole, e più non dimandare"
Translate: "The teacher consoled Charon: ""You don't have to worry; at the top there is someone who does what he wants, so don't add anything else"."

Original: Quinci fuor quete le lanose gote al nocchier de la livida palude, che ’ntorno a li occhi avea di fiamme rote
Translate: "The fur-covered ferryman in the horrible swamp had eyes surrounded by fiery rings, and after that he remained silent."

Original: Ma quell’anime, ch’eran lasse e nude, cangiar colore e dibattero i denti, ratto che ’nteser le parole crude
Translate: "When they heard his harsh words, the naked and helpless souls dyed themselves with a mortal pallor and their teeth began to beat."

Original: Bestemmiavano Dio e lor parenti, l’umana spezie e ’l loco e ’l tempo e ’l seme di lor semenza e di lor nascimenti
Translate: "They damned God, their ancestors, humanity as a whole, the place where they were and everything that was connected to the moment of procreation and the coming to the world."

Original: Poi si ritrasser tutte quante insieme, forte piangendo, a la riva malvagia ch’attende ciascun uom che Dio non teme
Translate: "Crying desperately, they all gathered together on the shore of the infernal river that waited for those who were not afraid of God."

Original: Caron dimonio, con occhi di bragia loro accennando, tutte le raccoglie
Translate: "Caron, the devil with glowing eyes like embers, waved a gesture to them inviting everyone up."

Original: batte col remo qualunque s'adagia
Translate: any of them that extends is struck by its oar

Original: Come d’autunno si levan le foglie l’una appresso de l’altra, fin che ’l ramo vede a la terra tutte le sue spoglie,  similemente il mal seme d’Adamo gittansi di quel lito ad una ad una, per cenni come augel per suo richiamo
Translate: "of those who caught him Like a bird trapped by the claws of the hunter, the evil seed of Adam descends down the River Lete, rejecting the offerings that Charon makes them, leaf after leaf, until they are all to abandon the edge of the shore."

Original: Così sen vanno su per l’onda bruna, e avanti che sien di là discese, anche di qua nuova schiera s’auna
Translate: "While flowing on the dark river, a second mass had gathered before they reached the opposite bank."

Original: "Figliuol mio", disse 'l maestro cortese, "quelli che muoion ne l'ira di Dio tutti convegnon qui d'ogne paese
Translate: "The noble teacher said to his son: "Alas, people from whom he expected much must come here from every part of the globe"."

Original: e pronti sono a trapassar lo rio, ché la divina giustizia li sprona, sì che la tema si volve in disio
Translate: "They are thrilled to wade the river, for God's righteousness encourages them to turn fear into desire."

Original: Quinci non passa mai anima buona
Translate: There is no good soul here that can pass.

Original: e però, se Caron di te si lagna, ben puoi sapere omai che ’l suo dir suona"
Translate: "If Charon complains about you, you'll understand what his speech alludes to."

Original: Finito questo, la buia campagna tremò sì forte, che de lo spavento la mente di sudore ancor mi bagna
Translate: "Those dark places were so distressing that only memory made me sweat for fear. At the end of it, they trembled with such intensity that they could not forget."

Original: La terra lagrimosa diede vento, che balenò una luce vermiglia la qual mi vinse ciascun sentimento
Translate: A wind caused by the tears poured on the earth caused a reddish light to shine so intense that it overwhelmed all my senses.

Original: e caddi come l’uom cui sonno piglia
Translate: He lost his balance as if he were in a deep sleep

Original: Ruppemi l’alto sonno ne la testa un greve truono, sì ch’io mi riscossi come persona ch’è per forza desta
Translate: "A loud thunder broke the tranquillity of my mind, waking up abruptly like the one who was suddenly raised up."

Original: e l’occhio riposato intorno mossi, dritto levato, e fiso riguardai per conoscer lo loco dov’io fossi
Translate: "I stared straight and looked carefully, turning my rested head, to see where I was."

Original: Vero è che ’n su la proda mi trovai de la valle d’abisso dolorosa che ’ntrono accoglie d’infiniti guai
Translate: "I found myself unexpectedly at the most extreme border of the dark Valley of Hell, where one hears an echo of uninterrupted lamentations."

Original: Oscura e profonda era e nebulosa tanto che, per ficcar lo viso a fondo, io non vi discernea alcuna cosa
Translate: "The darkness was so deep, dense and impenetrable that even though I looked far away, I couldn't tell anything."

Original: "Or discendiam qua giù nel cieco mondo", cominciò il poeta tutto smorto
Translate: "Virgilio, pale in face, said it was time to enter the blind world."

Original: "Io sarò primo, e tu sarai secondo"
Translate: You'll follow me after I go.

Original: E io, che del color mi fui accorto, dissi: "Come verrò, se tu paventi che suoli al mio dubbiare esser conforto?"
Translate: "Recognizing his pallor, I exclaimed: "How can I proceed if you too, usually a source of reassurance for all my concerns, seem so frightened?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "L’angoscia de le genti che son qua giù, nel viso mi dipigne quella pietà che tu per tema senti
Translate: "He told me that the despair of the hearts trapped in this place is imprinted on his face, creating that feeling of fear that you interpret as fear."

Original: Andiam, ché la via lunga ne sospigne"
Translate: "Let's hurry, since the journey is long and we can't waste time."

Original: Così si mise e così mi fé intrare nel primo cerchio che l’abisso cigne
Translate: "In this way he went along with me in the first layer of earth surrounding the deep pit of hell."

Original: Quivi, secondo che per ascoltare, non avea pianto mai che di sospiri che l’aura etterna facevan tremare
Translate: "The solitary eternal air was traveled by sighs, whose vibrations seemed to resonate in listening."

Original: ciò avvenia di duol sanza martìri, ch’avean le turbe, ch’eran molte e grandi, d’infanti e di femmine e di viri
Translate: "The immense ranks of children, women and men who patiently endured their pain were too numerous to count."

Original: Lo buon maestro a me: "Tu non dimandi che spiriti son questi che tu vedi? Or vo’ che sappi, innanzi che più andi,  ch’ei non peccaro
Translate: "The good teacher said to me, "Before you go any further, I want you to know who these spirits are you are seeing. They have committed no sin."

Original: e s’elli hanno mercedi, non basta, perché non ebber battesmo, ch’è porta de la fede che tu credi
Translate: "Although they have good qualities, it is not enough because they have not received the baptism that would serve to recognize them as part of the faith professed by you."

Original: e s’e’ furon dinanzi al cristianesmo, non adorar debitamente a Dio: e di questi cotai son io medesmo
Translate: "If I was part of this category, it would mean that I lived before Christianity and would not have worshipped God as it had to."

Original: Per tai difetti, non per altro rio, semo perduti, e sol di tanto offesi che sanza speme vivemo in disio"
Translate: "We find ourselves imprisoned in this sin, deprived of other punishments, which means living in the despair of a desire without fulfillment."

Original: Gran duol mi prese al cor quando lo ’ntesi, però che gente di molto valore conobbi che ’n quel limbo eran sospesi
Translate: "I felt a deep sadness in my heart, knowing that among the souls trapped in that Limbo were those of extraordinary people."

Original: "Dimmi, maestro mio, dimmi, segnore", comincia’ io per volere esser certo di quella fede che vince ogne errore:
Translate: "I began to ask with absolute confidence my teacher and lord,"

Original: "uscicci mai alcuno, o per suo merto o per altrui, che poi fosse beato?"
Translate: "Was there anyone who, thanks to himself or to others, has left this environment and then gone to bliss?"

Original: E quei che ’ntese il mio parlar coverto,  rispuose: "Io era nuovo in questo stato, quando ci vidi venire un possente, con segno di vittoria coronato
Translate: "Virgilio understood my allusive words and answered me: "I was here a short time ago when I saw a great figure advancing, bearing the symbols of victory."

Original: Trasseci l’ombra del primo parente, d’Abèl suo figlio e quella di Noè, di Moïsè legista e ubidente
Translate: "From here began the shadow of the just fathers first of all, Abel the son of Adam and Noah, followed by the legislator Moses fully obedient."

Original: Abraàm patrïarca e Davìd re, Israèl con lo padre e co’ suoi nati e con Rachele, per cui tanto fé,
Translate: "Abraham, the patriarch, and David, the king of Israel, did much for his wife Rachel with their children."

Original: e altri molti, e feceli beati
Translate: .and made them all happy.

Original: E vo’ che sappi che, dinanzi ad essi, spiriti umani non eran salvati"
Translate: I would like you to understand that before them no soul was able to save itself.

Original: Non lasciavam l’andar perch’ei dicessi, ma passavam la selva tuttavia, la selva, dico, di spiriti spessi
Translate: "While Virgil spoke, we proceeded without pause through the multitude of souls around us."

Original: Non era lunga ancor la nostra via di qua dal sonno, quand’io vidi un foco ch’emisperio di tenebre vincia
Translate: "We hadn't traveled a long way since I woke up, when I saw an enlightenment that knocked down the veil of darkness."

Original: Di lungi n’eravamo ancora un poco, ma non sì ch’io non discernessi in parte ch’orrevol gente possedea quel loco
Translate: "We were still at a certain distance, but close enough to feel that that place was a voice of virtuous souls."

Original: "O tu ch’onori scïenzïa e arte, questi chi son c’ hanno cotanta onranza, che dal modo de li altri li diparte?"
Translate: "Who are those who hold an honorable position between science and art, since they receive privileged treatment over others?"

Original: E quelli a me: "L’onrata nominanza che di lor suona sù ne la tua vita, grazïa acquista in ciel che sì li avanza"
Translate: "Virgilio answered me and said that the splendid fame for which they are still remembered on Earth gives them a heavenly honor that distinguishes them from all other spirits."

Original: Intanto voce fu per me udita: "Onorate l’altissimo poeta
Translate: Ode to the greatest poet: let's give him all due respect!

Original: l’ombra sua torna, ch’era dipartita"
Translate: "His soul, coming back, reappeared."

Original: Poi che la voce fu restata e queta, vidi quattro grand’ombre a noi venire: sembianz’avevan né trista né lieta
Translate: "After the echo of sound calmed down, four gigantic people met us: they did not look joyful or sad."

Original: Lo buon maestro cominciò a dire: "Mira colui con quella spada in mano, che vien dinanzi ai tre sì come sire:  quelli è Omero poeta sovrano
Translate: The good master left: "See him who carries a weapon and precedes others as their leader, that is Homer, the greatest poet."

Original: l’altro è Orazio satiro che vene
Translate: "Orazio, author of the Satire, is the follower."

Original: Ovidio è ’l terzo, e l’ultimo Lucano
Translate: "Ovidio is the third, Lucano the last."

Original: Però che ciascun meco si convene nel nome che sonò la voce sola, fannomi onore, e di ciò fanno bene"
Translate: "With my name uttered by one voice, each one of them honors me, and this is right."

Original: Così vid’i’ adunar la bella scola di quel segnor de l’altissimo canto che sovra li altri com’aquila vola
Translate: "I saw the sublime meeting of the poets of that famous gentleman, author of splendid verses, who stands above others like an eagle."

Original: Da ch’ebber ragionato insieme alquanto, volsersi a me con salutevol cenno, e ’l mio maestro sorrise di tanto
Translate: "While they were talking, they greeted me with a sign of the head and my teacher enjoyed this."

Original: e più d’onore ancora assai mi fenno, ch’e’ sì mi fecer de la loro schiera, sì ch’io fui sesto tra cotanto senno
Translate: "Their kindness toward me increased again, making me the sixth member of the experienced group."

Original: Così andammo infino a la lumera, parlando cose che ’l tacere è bello, sì com’era ’l parlar colà dov’era
Translate: "We continued our adventure towards the light, remaining silent on some things that were not appropriate to say, just as we liked to discuss it in the surroundings."

Original: Venimmo al piè d’un nobile castello, sette volte cerchiato d’alte mura, difeso intorno d’un bel fiumicello
Translate: "We arrived at the foot of a magnificent castle, surrounded by seven defensive stratagems and protected by a pretty stream of water."

Original: Questo passammo come terra dura
Translate: On its surface we went as when passing through the ground.

Original: per sette porte intrai con questi savi: giugnemmo in prato di fresca verdura
Translate: "With the advice of these wise men we crossed the seven doors, finally arriving in a meadow covered with a carpet of fresh and green grass."

Original: Genti v’eran con occhi tardi e gravi, di grande autorità ne’ lor sembianti: parlavan rado, con voci soavi
Translate: "The people we met had a severe air but a peaceful gaze; they spoke in a few words, as delicate as their tone of voice."

Original: Traemmoci così da l’un de’ canti, in loco aperto, luminoso e alto, sì che veder si potien tutti quanti
Translate: "We moved to a central, open and well-lit location, from where we could all see."

Original: Colà diritto, sovra ’l verde smalto, mi fuor mostrati li spiriti magni, che del vedere in me stesso m’essalto
Translate: "There in front, where the green grass shone like a glittering lacquer, my attention was captured by the vision of the "great spirits"; I rejoice for having had the opportunity to observe them."

Original: I’ vidi Eletra con molti compagni, tra ’ quai conobbi Ettòr ed Enea, Cesare armato con li occhi grifagni
Translate: "I last Elettra accompanied by many friends, among whom I identified Ettore and Enea, and Caesar with threatening gaze armed entirely."

Original: Vidi Cammilla e la Pantasilea
Translate: Camilla and Pentesilea were observed by me.

Original: da l’altra parte vidi ’l re Latino che con Lavina sua figlia sedea
Translate: "From the opposite side I saw the Latin King sitting with his daughter Lavinia."

Original: Vidi quel Bruto che cacciò Tarquino, Lucrezia, Iulia, Marzïa e Corniglia
Translate: "I have observed Lucio Bruto who has hunted Tarquinio il Superbo, as well as Lucrezia, Giulia, Marzia and Cornelia."

Original: e solo, in parte, vidi ’l Saladino
Translate: "In a secluded corner, I saw the Saladin who was all alone."

Original: Poi ch’innalzai un poco più le ciglia, vidi ’l maestro di color che sanno seder tra filosofica famiglia
Translate: "After I looked up, I spotted the illustrious teacher among his fellow philosophers."

Original: Tutti lo miran, tutti onor li fanno: quivi vid’ïo Socrate e Platone, che ’nnanzi a li altri più presso li stanno
Translate: "The fools gathered around Socrates and Plato, while all those present were there to admire them and express their gratitude."

Original: Democrito che ’l mondo a caso pone, Dïogenès, Anassagora e Tale, Empedoclès, Eraclito e Zenone
Translate: ". Democritus, Diogenes, Anassagoras, Tales, Empedocles, Heraclitus and Zenone agree that the world is ruled by chance."

Original: e vidi il buono accoglitor del quale, Dïascoride dico
Translate: "Dioscorides, the wise man known for his description of plant qualities, has been seen."

Original: e vidi Orfeo, Tulïo e Lino e Seneca morale
Translate: "I saw Orpheus, Cicero, Lino, and the wise Seneca."

Original: Euclide geomètra e Tolomeo, Ipocràte, Avicenna e Galïeno, Averoìs che ’l gran comento feo
Translate: "Euclid, considered the founder of geometry, along with Ptolemy, Hippocrates, Avicenna and Galen, as well as Averroè who gave life to his great commentary."

Original: Io non posso ritrar di tutti a pieno, però che sì mi caccia il lungo tema, che molte volte al fatto il dir vien meno
Translate: I cannot give a detailed description of everyone because the amount of information I have to consider is so great that I have to leave out details.

Original: La sesta compagnia in due si scema: per altra via mi mena il savio duca, fuor de la queta, ne l’aura che trema
Translate: "The group of six poets separates: the wise master guides me on an alternative path, away from the quiet atmosphere and inside the tempestuous one."

Original: E vegno in parte ove non è che luca
Translate: I come to a place where everything is in the dark.

Original: Così discesi del cerchio primaio  giù nel secondo, che men loco cinghia e tanto più dolor, che punge a guaio
Translate: "Going down from the first circle to the second, there was a smaller area but filled with greater suffering that led to complaint"

Original: Stavvi Minòs orribilmente, e ringhia: essamina le colpe ne l’intrata
Translate: "Minos is standing on the threshold and cries out with threatening air, examining the sins of sinners who present themselves."

Original: giudica e manda secondo ch’avvinghia
Translate: distinguishes between them by putting into effect a judgment based on the form of the tail.

Original: Dico che quando l’anima mal nata li vien dinanzi, tutta si confessa
Translate: "When the doomed soul comes before him, he makes a complete confession."

Original: e quel conoscitor de le peccata  vede qual loco d’inferno è da essa
Translate: and that judge of sins determines to which section of Hell he must bring

Original: cignesi con la coda tante volte quantunque gradi vuol che giù sia messa
Translate: wraps with the tail a number of times equal to the Circles that the damned must descend.

Original: Sempre dinanzi a lui ne stanno molte: vanno a vicenda ciascuna al giudizio, dicono e odono e poi son giù volte
Translate: "Under his gaze, souls appear one after the other to hear his opinion, dialogue with him before falling down."

Original: "O tu che vieni al doloroso ospizio", disse Minòs a me quando mi vide, lasciando l’atto di cotanto offizio,  "guarda com’entri e di cui tu ti fide
Translate: "When he saw me, Minos admonishes me, saying: "O you who are about to enter into this place of suffering, pay attention to how you enter and to whom you trust."

Original: non t’inganni l’ampiezza de l’intrare
Translate: Do not stop at appearances: access can be difficult.

Original: E ’l duca mio a lui: "Perché pur gride?  Non impedir lo suo fatale andare: vuolsi così colà dove si puote ciò che si vuole, e più non dimandare"
Translate: "Virgilio replied: ""Why are you still screaming? Do not hinder his journey and what God has established. In Heaven, all that you want can be accomplished, so do not add anything else"."

Original: Or incomincian le dolenti note a farmisi sentire
Translate: I begin to perceive the melancholy of notes.

Original: or son venuto là dove molto pianto mi percuote
Translate: I have reached a place where suffering is deep.

Original: Io venni in loco d’ogne luce muto, che mugghia come fa mar per tempesta, se da contrari venti è combattuto
Translate: "Joining in a dark place, like the sea at the height of a storm with impetuous winds."

Original: La bufera infernal, che mai non resta, mena li spirti con la sua rapina
Translate: "of the wretched A hellish whirlwind, which never stops, mercilessly drags the souls of the ill-capitulated."

Original: voltando e percotendo li molesta
Translate: It torments them with beatings and blows.

Original: Quando giungon davanti a la ruina, quivi le strida, il compianto, il lamento
Translate: "When they come to ruin, they overshadow the sky with their cries, tears and lamentations."

Original: bestemmian quivi la virtù divina
Translate: Sacrilege blasphemies against God are uttered

Original: Intesi ch’a così fatto tormento enno dannati i peccator carnali, che la ragion sommettono al talento
Translate: "Those who submit reason to pleasure are at the mercy of a punishment, destined for the sinners of lust."

Original: E come li stornei ne portan l’ali nel freddo tempo, a schiera larga e piena, così quel fiato li spiriti mali
Translate: "As when the stornelli fly in formation with their wings on a harsh winter day, so the wind takes away the evil spirits."

Original: di qua, di là, di giù, di sù li mena
Translate: "Move them here and there, up and down."

Original: nulla speranza li conforta mai, non che di posa, ma di minor pena
Translate: "There is no hope of consolation, either to have a little respite or to reduce punishment."

Original: E come i gru van cantando lor lai, faccendo in aere di sé lunga riga, così vid’io venir, traendo guai,  ombre portate da la detta briga
Translate: "Like cranes that leave a trail of lamentations in the sky, I saw souls carried by the storm coming sighing towards me."

Original: per ch’i’ dissi: "Maestro, chi son quelle genti che l’aura nera sì gastiga?"
Translate: "I asked the Master: ""Who are those poor beings scourged by the inexorable storm?""

Original: "La prima di color di cui novelle tu vuo' saper", mi disse quelli allotta, "fu imperadrice di molte favelle
Translate: "Virgilio then answered me that among the people from whom I wanted to know, the first was an empress of different peoples."

Original: A vizio di lussuria fu sì rotta, che libito fé licito in sua legge, per tòrre il biasmo in che era condotta
Translate: "He abandoned himself to the habit of lust, asserting his law to make lawful what she liked, thus eliminating the moral reproach that she should receive."

Original: Ell’è Semiramìs, di cui si legge che succedette a Nino e fu sua sposa: tenne la terra che ’l Soldan corregge
Translate: "She is Semiramide, just as she is read that she married Nino and later succeeded her throne; ruling the land in which the Soldano now reigns."

Original: L’altra è colei che s’ancise amorosa, e ruppe fede al cener di Sicheo
Translate: "She who took her life because of love, and did not keep any remembrance of Sicheus, is the other."

Original: poi è Cleopatràs lussurïosa
Translate: the seductive Cleopatra

Original: Elena vedi, per cui tanto reo tempo si volse, e vedi ’l grande Achille, che con amore al fine combatteo
Translate: "Look at Elena, for whom a fierce war with a tragic outcome was fought, and see the great Achilles, who ran in battle for romantic reasons."

Original: Vedi Parìs, Tristano"
Translate: ""Look at Paris, Tristan!"""

Original: e più di mille ombre mostrommi e nominommi a dito, ch’amor di nostra vita dipartille
Translate: and showed me a thousand souls who lost their lives for love.

Original: Poscia ch’io ebbi ’l mio dottore udito nomar le donne antiche e ’ cavalieri, pietà mi giunse, e fui quasi smarrito
Translate: "After listening to my teacher mention the female and male figures of the past, I felt a great agitation and had the impression of losing myself."

Original: I’ cominciai: "Poeta, volontieri parlerei a quei due che ’nsieme vanno, e paion sì al vento esser leggeri"
Translate: "I began by saying: "Poet, I would like to speak with those two flying together with the current of the air, as if they were being dragged by a slight breeze."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Vedrai quando saranno più presso a noi
Translate: "He said to me, "We will wait until they are closer to us.""

Original: e tu allor li priega per quello amor che i mena, ed ei verranno"
Translate: Pray to them in the name of the feeling that unites them and will come.

Original: Sì tosto come il vento a noi li piega, mossi la voce: "O anime affannate, venite a noi parlar, s’altri nol niega
Translate: "When the wind pushed them toward us, I took the word: "O weary souls, come and visit us if it is granted by God."

Original: Quali colombe dal disio chiamate con l’ali alzate e ferme al dolce nido vegnon per l’aere, dal voler portate
Translate: "With their wings raised, as if they were called by desire, the doves fly to their sweet nest, firm and safe."

Original: cotali uscir de la schiera ov’è Dido, a noi venendo per l’aere maligno, sì forte fu l’affettüoso grido
Translate: "The two went away from Dido together, coming to us in the air of fire, thanks to my strong and passionate call."

Original: "O animal grazïoso e benigno che visitando vai per l’aere perso noi che tignemmo il mondo di sanguigno,  se fosse amico il re de l’universo, noi pregheremmo lui de la tua pace, poi c’ hai pietà del nostro mal perverso
Translate: "Oh kind entity, that you come into darkness to visit us who have stained the world with our shortcomings, we would invoke the friendship of the King of the Universe if he could grant us some peace; no matter how much they express our sadness and despair."

Original: Di quel che udire e che parlar vi piace, noi udiremo e parleremo a voi, mentre che ’l vento, come fa, ci tace
Translate: "While the wind subsides in this place, we are ready to listen and talk to you about what you want."

Original: Siede la terra dove nata fui su la marina dove ’l Po discende per aver pace co’ seguaci sui
Translate: "The land of my birth rises at the confluence of the Po, where the water pours into the sea to meet its peace with its tributaries."

Original: Amor, ch'al cor gentil ratto s'apprende, prese costui de la bella persona che mi fu tolta
Translate: "The noble heart was immediately struck by love, for he possessed the beautiful form that was torn from me."

Original: e 'l modo ancor m'offende
Translate: And he still hurts me.

Original: Amor, ch’a nullo amato amar perdona, mi prese del costui piacer sì forte, che, come vedi, ancor non m’abbandona
Translate: "Love, which leaves no possibility for those who feel it not to return it, grabbed me with so much intensity for the beauty of him who still persists in me in all his strength."

Original: Amor condusse noi ad una morte
Translate: All the love we had brought us to the same end.

Original: Caina attende chi a vita ci spense"
Translate: Caina is waiting for the man responsible for our death.

Original: Queste parole da lor ci fuor porte
Translate: They told us these words.

Original: Quand’io intesi quell’anime offense, china’ il viso, e tanto il tenni basso, fin che ’l poeta mi disse: "Che pense?"
Translate: "When I heard the cries of those suffering, I bowed my head and kept him in that position for so long that in the end Virgil asked me, "What do you think?"

Original: Quando rispuosi, cominciai: "Oh lasso, quanti dolci pensier, quanto disio menò costoro al doloroso passo
Translate: "He replied with sadness: "Ah, how many sweet dreams and desires have accompanied these two lives in this tragic march."

Original: Poi mi rivolsi a loro e parla’ io, e cominciai: "Francesca, i tuoi martìri a lagrimar mi fanno tristo e pio
Translate: "While I was looking at Francesca, her suffering caused me a great sadness that almost moved me to cry."

Original: Ma dimmi: al tempo d’i dolci sospiri, a che e come concedette amore che conosceste i dubbiosi disiri?"
Translate: "How did he cut the distance Love he had imposed between you at the time of your relationship, allowing you to understand how much you wanted?"

Original: E quella a me: "Nessun maggior dolore che ricordarsi del tempo felice ne la miseria
Translate: "She pointed out to me how much they love the memories of the happiest days, when they are persecuted by a strong regret."

Original: e ciò sa 'l tuo dottore
Translate: Your teacher is aware of this.

Original: Ma s’a conoscer la prima radice del nostro amor tu hai cotanto affetto, dirò come colui che piange e dice
Translate: "If you have so much curiosity to discover the origin of our love, act like those who are in tears but speak at the same time."

Original: Noi leggiavamo un giorno per diletto di Lancialotto come amor lo strinse
Translate: One day we were reading for fun the book about Lancelot and his love for Geneva.

Original: soli eravamo e sanza alcun sospetto
Translate: None of us had any idea what would happen.

Original: Per più fïate li occhi ci sospinse quella lettura, e scolorocci il viso
Translate: "What we read caused us to touch each other with our eyes, making us pale."

Original: ma solo un punto fu quel che ci vinse
Translate: He only overwhelmed us for a moment.

Original: Quando leggemmo il disïato riso esser basciato da cotanto amante, questi, che mai da me non fia diviso,  la bocca mi basciò tutto tremante
Translate: "When we heard that Geneva had been kissed by such a worthy lover, the person I loved shyly kissed my lips."

Original: Galeotto fu ’l libro e chi lo scrisse: quel giorno più non vi leggemmo avante"
Translate: Galeotto was the author of the book

Original: Mentre che l'uno spirto questo disse, l'altro piangëa
Translate: On that day we did not continue to read further pages.

Original: sì che di pietade io venni men così com'io morisse
Translate: "While one spirit uttered this phrase, the other burst into tears and I became extremely upset to the point that I felt like I was dying."

Original: E caddi come corpo morto cade
Translate: I fell like an inert mass.

Original: Al tornar de la mente, che si chiuse dinanzi a la pietà d’i due cognati,
Translate: "When I regained consciousness, I was shocked by the suffering of the two brothers-in-laws"

Original: che di trestizia tutto mi confuse, novi tormenti e novi tormentati mi veggio intorno,
Translate: "I feel wrapped in an atmosphere of sadness, seeing people around me suffering and damaged."

Original: come ch’io mi mova e ch’io mi volga, e come che io guati
Translate: "Whatever I do or look around,"

Original: Io sono al terzo cerchio, de la piova etterna, maladetta, fredda e greve
Translate: "I am in the Third Circle, where a cursed and unbearable rain is falling, unstoppable and cold intensity."

Original: regola e qualità mai non l’è nova
Translate: Its level of quality and performance remains unchanged.

Original: Grandine grossa, acqua tinta e neve per l’aere tenebroso si riversa
Translate: "Among the darkness a frantic fall of torrential rain, polluted water and snow pours out."

Original: pute la terra che questo riceve
Translate: "the earth, macerated by the water, emanated an unpleasant stench."

Original: Cerbero, fiera crudele e diversa, con tre gole caninamente latra sovra la gente che quivi è sommersa
Translate: "Cerberus, a frightening and fearsome beast, barks fiercely like a dog with three heads toward the damned who are immersed in the slime."

Original: Li occhi ha vermigli, la barba unta e atra, e ’l ventre largo, e unghiate le mani
Translate: "He has a red face, covered in dirt and anointed, his belly swollen and claws on his legs."

Original: graffia li spirti ed iscoia ed isquatra
Translate: "Laceration, chastise, and destroy the cursed."

Original: Urlar li fa la pioggia come cani
Translate: The rain causes in them a scream similar to that of the dogs.

Original: de l’un de’ lati fanno a l’altro schermo
Translate: They try to protect each other with their hips.

Original: volgonsi spesso i miseri profani
Translate: toward poor sinners often seek help

Original: Quando ci scorse Cerbero, il gran vermo, le bocche aperse e mostrocci le sanne
Translate: "When Cerberus, the fearsome monster, saw us, opened his mouth and revealed his fangs."

Original: non avea membro che tenesse fermo
Translate: Every part of his anatomy trembled

Original: E ’l duca mio distese le sue spanne, prese la terra, e con piene le pugna la gittò dentro a le bramose canne
Translate: "My teacher extended his arms, grabbed a handful of earth and threw it firmly into the voracious mouth of the monster."

Original: Qual è quel cane ch’abbaiando agogna, e si racqueta poi che ’l pasto morde, ché solo a divorarlo intende e pugna,
Translate: "Similar to a hungry dog that barks and is appeased by the bite that is given to him to eat, he has no other thought than to satisfy his appetite."

Original: cotai si fecer quelle facce lorde de lo demonio Cerbero, che ’ntrona l’anime sì, ch’esser vorrebber sorde
Translate: "The gloomy expression of the dreaded figure of the demon Cerberus calmed down, his howling deafened the souls who wished to remain deaf."

Original: Noi passavam su per l’ombre che adona la greve pioggia, e ponavam le piante sovra lor vanità che par persona
Translate: "We walked among the souls trampled on by the strong downpour, while our steps rested on their fragile forms that resembled those of a human being."

Original: Elle giacean per terra tutte quante, fuor d’una ch’a seder si levò, ratto ch’ella ci vide passarsi davante
Translate: "They were all lying on the earth, except one who immediately sat up as soon as he saw us passing by."

Original: "O tu che se’ per questo ’nferno tratto", mi disse, "riconoscimi, se sai: tu fosti, prima ch’io disfatto, fatto"
Translate: "He said to me, "If you who have been led through Hell can recognize me, prove it to me because I was still alive before you were born."

Original: E io a lui: "L’angoscia che tu hai forse ti tira fuor de la mia mente, sì che non par ch’i’ ti vedessi mai
Translate: "I said to him, "Your suffering is so deep that it makes you unknown, as if we were completely alien to each other."

Original: Ma dimmi chi tu se’ che ’n sì dolente loco se’ messo, e hai sì fatta pena, che, s’altra è maggio, nulla è sì spiacente"
Translate: "Who are you living in this place of suffering, encountering a penance perhaps heavier but not as painful?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "La tua città, ch’è piena d’invidia sì che già trabocca il sacco, seco mi tenne in la vita serena
Translate: "He replied: "My city, so crushed by envy that it was at the end of the line, welcomed me into earthly life."

Original: Voi Cittadini mi chiamaste Ciacco per la dannosa colpa de la gola, come tu vedi, a la pioggia mi fiacco
Translate: "The Florentines have nicknamed me Ciacco for my tendency to exaggerate with food; as you can see, the intense thunderstorm of these days has made me weak."

Original: E io anima trista non son sola, ché tutte queste a simil pena stanno per simil colpa"
Translate: I am not alone in suffering here; other souls share my own punishment for the same sin.

Original: E più non fé parola
Translate: He didn't open his mouth anymore.

Original: Io li rispuosi: "Ciacco, il tuo affanno mi pesa sì, ch’a lagrimar mi ’nvita
Translate: "I replied to Ciacco: "Your suffering is so painful that it provokes tears."

Original: ma dimmi, se tu sai, a che verranno  li cittadin de la città partita
Translate: What future awaits the inhabitants of the divided city?

Original: s’alcun v’è giusto
Translate: if none of them are wrong

Original: e dimmi la cagione per che l’ ha tanta discordia assalita"
Translate: Ask me what was the reason for their disagreement.

Original: E quelli a me: "Dopo lunga tencione verranno al sangue, e la parte selvaggia caccerà l’altra con molta offensione
Translate: ""After a long battle, the action of the country will trigger a violent clash, with heavy consequences for the opposing party""."

Original: Poi appresso convien che questa caggia infra tre soli, e che l’altra sormonti con la forza di tal che testé piaggia
Translate: "It is predestined that the Whites surrender power within three years, with the advent of a new alliance led by a man whose opinions are divided between the two factions."

Original: Alte terrà lungo tempo le fronti, tenendo l’altra sotto gravi pesi, come che di ciò pianga o che n’aonti
Translate: "Even if the Whites complain vigorously, the Blacks will continue to govern and impose severe penalties."

Original: Giusti son due, e non vi sono intesi
Translate: "Only two Florentines are right, but no one listens to them."

Original: superbia, invidia e avarizia sono le tre faville c’ hanno i cuori accesi"
Translate: "The hearts are inflamed because of pride, envy and greed."

Original: Qui puose fine al lagrimabil suono
Translate: He stopped talking in a sad tone.

Original: E io a lui: "Ancor vo’ che mi ’nsegni e che di più parlar mi facci dono
Translate: I asked him to explain other things to me and to keep talking to me.

Original: Farinata e ’l Tegghiaio, che fuor sì degni, Iacopo Rusticucci, Arrigo e ’l Mosca e li altri ch’a ben far puoser li ’ngegni, dimmi ove sono e fa ch’io li conosca
Translate: "Tell me about the fate of Farinata Degli Uberti, the Tegghiaio and the other wise Ghibelline citizens such as Iacopo Rusticucci, Arrigo, Mosca dei Lamberti: get an idea of what the end had to do to improve the situation."

Original: ché gran disio mi stringe di savere se ’l ciel li addolcia o lo ’nferno li attosca"
Translate: I have a great interest in knowing whether Heaven offers them blessings or Hell causes pain.

Original: E quelli: "Ei son tra l’anime più nere
Translate: He claimed that among them were the most evil souls.

Original: diverse colpe giù li grava al fondo: se tanto scendi, là i potrai vedere
Translate: "They condemn them to the deepest of Hell and if you descend to such levels, you will see them."

Original: Ma quando tu sarai nel dolce mondo, priegoti ch’a la mente altrui mi rechi: più non ti dico e più non ti rispondo"
Translate: "When I hope that you will return to the world in which we live, please think of me with affection: I add nothing else and do not repeat anymore."

Original: Li diritti occhi torse allora in biechi
Translate: Then Ciacco opened his eyes.

Original: guardommi un poco e poi chinò la testa: cadde con essa a par de li altri ciechi
Translate: "He glanced and looked down, as he joined the other condemned spirits."

Original: E ’l duca disse a me: "Più non si desta di qua dal suon de l’angelica tromba, quando verrà la nimica podesta:
Translate: The teacher told me that he will not rise again until they hear the trumpet of the angels sound and the enemy authority will be present.

Original: ciascun rivederà la trista tomba, ripiglierà sua carne e sua figura, udirà quel ch’in etterno rimbomba"
Translate: "Each of them will return to pay homage to the sad grave, wearing his mortal clothes again and listening to the final sentence."

Original: Sì trapassammo per sozza mistura de l’ombre e de la pioggia, a passi lenti, toccando un poco la vita futura
Translate: "We headed with deliberate pace beyond the atrocious mixture of souls and rain, just conversing about the existence other than our world."

Original: per ch’io dissi: "Maestro, esti tormenti crescerann’ei dopo la gran sentenza, o fier minori, o saran sì cocenti?"
Translate: "Then I asked the Master: "After the final sentence, will these sanctions increase, decrease or remain unchanged?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Ritorna a tua scïenza, che vuol, quanto la cosa è più perfetta, più senta il bene, e così la doglienza
Translate: "He told me to return to my scientific experience, for the more perfect the creature is the greater his perception of pleasure and suffering."

Original: Tutto che questa gente maladetta in vera perfezion già mai non vada, di là più che di qua essere aspetta"
Translate: "Although these sinners will never be impeccable, yet with the final Judgment they will attain the fullness of their being."

Original: Noi aggirammo a tondo quella strada, parlando più assai ch’i’ non ridico
Translate: "We were moving around the Circle, telling many other stories that I don't bring back."

Original: venimmo al punto dove si digrada:
Translate: We arrived at the place where we went down into the Fourth Circle.

Original: quivi trovammo Pluto, il gran nemico
Translate: "and here we met Pluto, the great antagonist"

Original: "Pape Satàn, pape Satàn aleppe",
Translate: "Oh, Satan, oh, Satan, Lord of the Abyss"

Original: cominciò Pluto con la voce chioccia
Translate: Pluto began with a roaring voice.

Original: e quel savio gentil, che tutto seppe, disse per confortarmi: "Non ti noccia la tua paura
Translate: "and that kind wise man who knew everything, to cheer me up, said, "Don't let fear overcome you."

Original: ché, poder ch’elli abbia, non ci torrà lo scender questa roccia"
Translate: "Despite the existence of this demon, we will not be held back from climbing down from this rock."

Original: Poi si rivolse a quella ’nfiata labbia, e disse: "Taci, maladetto lupo
Translate: "She turned an acidic look at her angry face and replied: "Enough, evil goose."

Original: consuma dentro te con la tua rabbia
Translate: channel your anger into something positive.

Original: Non è sanza cagion l’andare al cupo: vuolsi ne l’alto, là dove Michele fé la vendetta del superbo strupo"
Translate: "Through the Divine will, the archangel Michael carried out revenge against Lucifer for his haughty sin through a journey to the bottom of Hell."

Original: Quali dal vento le gonfiate vele caggiono avvolte, poi che l’alber fiacca, tal cadde a terra la fiera crudele
Translate: "As a sail that is torn from the wind, when the tree of the ship breaks, so the cruel beast fell to the ground."

Original: Così scendemmo ne la quarta lacca, pigliando più de la dolente ripa che ’l mal de l’universo tutto insacca
Translate: "We descended into the depths of the Fourth Circle, sinking into that painful abyss that guards all the wickedness of the world."

Original: Ahi giustizia di Dio
Translate: "Ahinoi, supernatural justice"

Original: tante chi stipa nove travaglie e pene quant’io viddi? e perché nostra colpa sì ne scipa?
Translate: Who could accumulate as much suffering and pain as I have seen in that place? And why does our lack hit us so hard?

Original: Come fa l’onda là sovra Cariddi, che si frange con quella in cui s’intoppa, così convien che qui la gente riddi
Translate: "As the wave near Cariddi and the wave coming from Scylla collide, so those damned have to dance a hectic dance."

Original: Qui vid’i’ gente più ch’altrove troppa, e d’una parte e d’altra, con grand’urli, voltando pesi per forza di poppa
Translate: "In this place inhabited by the condemned, I saw more people than anywhere else in Hell, forcefully pushing large boulders on one side and on the other screaming."

Original: Percotëansi ’ncontro
Translate: They collided with each other.

Original: e poscia pur lì si rivolgea ciascun, voltando a retro, gridando: "Perché tieni?" e "Perché burli?"
Translate: "so, each side turned back and cried out to each other, "Why do you keep the stone firmly?" and ""What are you rolling it for?""

Original: Così tornavan per lo cerchio tetro da ogne mano a l’opposito punto, gridandosi anche loro ontoso metro
Translate: "Continuing to shout offensive words, they returned to the opposite point in the dark circle from both extremes."

Original: poi si volgea ciascun, quand’era giunto, per lo suo mezzo cerchio a l’altra giostra
Translate: "Once they got to the goal, they would turn around and start their dance again in the round."

Original: E io, ch’avea lo cor quasi compunto,  dissi: "Maestro mio, or mi dimostra che gente è questa, e se tutti fuor cherci questi chercuti a la sinistra nostra"
Translate: "I, with my heart afflicted with despair, asked: "Master, tell me who these damned ones are and if those with the tonsure we have on our left were all religious."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Tutti quanti fuor guerci sì de la mente in la vita primaia, che con misura nullo spendio ferci
Translate: "But that I shall break down and consume all things with vanity" He said to me: "The men of all ages have spent without moderation, dissipating their wealth with pride and arrogance"."

Original: Assai la voce lor chiaro l’abbaia, quando vegnono a’ due punti del cerchio dove colpa contraria li dispaia
Translate: "When they meet at the dividing line of the Circle, their contrasting reaction is well evidenced by their different voices."

Original: Questi fuor cherci, che non han coperchio piloso al capo, e papi e cardinali, in cui usa avarizia il suo soperchio"
Translate: "Those who were hairless on the head became priests, pontiffs and members of the College of Cardinals, and were overwhelmed by greed in all its exaggeration."

Original: E io: "Maestro, tra questi cotali dovre’ io ben riconoscere alcuni che furo immondi di cotesti mali"
Translate: "I should, no doubt, identify some of those who were guilty of these terrible crimes, asking the Master for confirmation."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Vano pensiero aduni: la sconoscente vita che i fé sozzi, ad ogne conoscenza or li fa bruni
Translate: I said to him: "The consequences of the mistakes made have changed everything so much that it makes them completely unrecognizable."

Original: In etterno verranno a li due cozzi: questi resurgeranno del sepulcro col pugno chiuso, e questi coi crin mozzi
Translate: "The greedy shall come out of the afterlife with their hands pressed with their fists, while the greedy men shall appear again with their heads scarred; they shall fight until death do separate them."

Original: Mal dare e mal tener lo mondo pulcro ha tolto loro, e posti a questa zuffa: qual ella sia, parole non ci appulcro
Translate: "Their excessive spending and saving has wiped them out of the possibility of having Paradise, putting them in this competitiveness; I will not use other words to depict their pain."

Original: Or puoi, figliuol, veder la corta buffa d’i ben che son commessi a la fortuna, per che l’umana gente si rabuffa
Translate: "Now, my son, you can see how ephemeral the duration of the goods managed by fate is, so people work so hard."

Original: ché tutto l’oro ch’è sotto la luna e che già fu, di quest’anime stanche non poterebbe farne posare una"
Translate: "All the riches accumulated in the past, no matter how great they were, could not have calmed down even one of these souls."

Original: "Maestro mio", diss’io, "or mi dì anche: questa fortuna di che tu mi tocche, che è, che i ben del mondo ha sì tra branche?"
Translate: "I asked my teacher: "What is this wealth you speak of, with the goods of the world to his possession?"

Original: E quelli a me: "Oh creature sciocche, quanta ignoranza è quella che v’offende
Translate: "And he said to me, 'Oh, you foolish men! How your ignorance endangers you!'

Original: Or vo’ che tu mia sentenza ne ’mbocche
Translate: Now please pay attention to my words.

Original: Colui lo cui saver tutto trascende, fece li cieli e diè lor chi conduce sì, ch’ogne parte ad ogne parte splende,  distribuendo igualmente la luce
Translate: "The All-Knowing One who transcends every limit created the heavens and established the spheres of angels to govern them, so that his light might be reflected in an eternal circle of refractions among the stars of the Universe."

Original: Similemente a li splendor mondani ordinò general ministra e duce  che permutasse a tempo li ben vani di gente in gente e d’uno in altro sangue, oltre la difension d’i senni umani
Translate: "So he established a wisdom that he could manage and administer the earthly goods, transfer them at the appropriate time among the various families and tribes, despite the opposition of human reason."

Original: per ch’una gente impera e l’altra langue, seguendo lo giudicio di costei, che è occulto come in erba l’angue
Translate: "According to the inexorable sentence of fortune, which is hidden like a snake hidden in the grass, some families get rich while others are ruined."

Original: Vostro saver non ha contasto a lei: questa provede, giudica, e persegue suo regno come il loro li altri dèi
Translate: "There is no one else who can counter your deep wisdom: it deals with making decisions, judging and acting like other heavenly minds."

Original: Le sue permutazion non hanno triegue: necessità la fa esser veloce
Translate: There is no peace in his transformations.

Original: sì spesso vien chi vicenda consegue
Translate: He must act quickly to fulfill the divine will.

Original: Quest’è colei ch’è tanto posta in croce pur da color che le dovrien dar lode, dandole biasmo a torto e mala voce
Translate: In number of cases there is a change of situation.

Original: ma ella s’è beata e ciò non ode: con l’altre prime creature lieta volve sua spera e beata si gode
Translate: "She is happy and does not feel any pain: along with the other primordial beings she joyfully swirls in her orbit and savors her joy."

Original: Or discendiamo omai a maggior pieta
