Translate: It is time to immerse yourself in a deep state of anguish.

Original: già ogne stella cade che saliva quand’io mi mossi, e ’l troppo star si vieta"
Translate: The stars that shone at the time of my departure from Limbo have now vanished and we cannot waste any more time.

Original: Noi ricidemmo il cerchio a l’altra riva sovr’una fonte che bolle e riversa per un fossato che da lei deriva
Translate: "We surpassed the Circle to the other shore, fed by a spring flowing along a moat starting right there."

Original: L’acqua era buia assai più che persa
Translate: The water had a dark colouration.

Original: e noi, in compagnia de l’onde bige, intrammo giù per una via diversa
Translate: "flying along the black waves, we followed a difficult path"

Original: In la palude va c’ ha nome Stige questo tristo ruscel, quand’è disceso al piè de le maligne piagge grige
Translate: "This sad stream flows towards the swamp known as Stige, after rushing down from the dark side of hell."

Original: E io, che di mirare stava inteso, vidi genti fangose in quel pantano, ignude tutte, con sembiante offeso
Translate: "I was looking with interest, and I saw unlucky people trapped in that muddy bump; they were all stripped and had an expression of disappointment."

Original: Queste si percotean non pur con mano, ma con la testa e col petto e coi piedi, troncandosi co’ denti a brano a brano
Translate: "They attacked themselves not only with their hands, but also with their heads, breasts and feet, biting themselves with bites."

Original: Lo buon maestro disse: "Figlio, or vedi l’anime di color cui vinse l’ira
Translate: "The good teacher exhorted: "Look, boy, the souls that have been overwhelmed by anger."

Original: e anche vo’ che tu per certo credi  che sotto l’acqua è gente che sospira, e fanno pullular quest’acqua al summo, come l’occhio ti dice, u’ che s’aggira
Translate: "I want you to know for sure that underneath the surface of the water there are souls that glide, emitting gurgles and noises similar to those that can be perceived wherever you look."

Original: Fitti nel limo dicon: "Tristi fummo ne l'aere dolce che dal sol s'allegra, portando dentro accidïoso fummo:  or ci attristiam ne la belletta negra"
Translate: "Hunted by the mild heat that stirred joy under the sun, with repressed anger and sadness within us, we now have the overwhelming melancholy brought by these black mud puddles."

Original: Quest’inno si gorgoglian ne la strozza, ché dir nol posson con parola integra"
Translate: "They light these words in their throats, for they cannot say it safely."

Original: Così girammo de la lorda pozza grand’arco, tra la ripa secca e ’l mézzo, con li occhi vòlti a chi del fango ingozza
Translate: "We headed along the fetid swamp for a significant stretch, between the embankment rich in rocks and the water liquid, with the pupils looking at the alms imprisoned in the mud."

Original: Venimmo al piè d’una torre al da sezzo
Translate: Finally, we reached the base of a high tower.

Original: Io dico, seguitando, ch’assai prima che noi fossimo al piè de l’alta torre, li occhi nostri n’andar suso a la cima per due fiammette che i vedemmo porre,
Translate: "Continuing, I can say that well before reaching the foot of the very high tower, our eyes were heading towards the top and they saw two flames placed there by someone."

Original: e un’altra da lungi render cenno, tanto ch’a pena il potea l’occhio tòrre
Translate: "to the challengesAnother tower, so remote that it could barely glimpse itself, responded to provocations."

Original: E io mi volsi al mar di tutto ’l senno
Translate: "I turned to Virgil, who possessed an immense wisdom like the sea."

Original: dissi: "Questo che dice? e che risponde quell’altro foco? e chi son quei che ’l fenno?"
Translate: "I asked: ""What is the meaning of that sign? What does the other represent? And who did all this?""

Original: Ed elli a me: "Su per le sucide onde già scorgere puoi quello che s’aspetta, se ’l fummo del pantan nol ti nasconde"
Translate: "You can already see, along the murky waters, the one we are waiting for if the steam of the swamp does not hide it from us from our observation."

Original: Corda non pinse mai da sé saetta che sì corresse via per l’aere snella, com’io vidi una nave piccioletta  venir per l’acqua verso noi in quella,
Translate: Never had an arrow hurled with the bow seen the air so fast as when we looked at the little boat sailing towards us in the water at that time.

Original: sotto ’l governo d’un sol galeoto, che gridava: "Or se' giunta, anima fella
Translate: "One man at the helm, who said, "Behold, the evil soul is here!"

Original: "Flegïàs, Flegïàs, tu gridi a vòto", disse lo mio segnore, "a questa volta: più non ci avrai che sol passando il loto"
Translate: "My teacher said: "Flegias, do not shout unnecessarily this time: we will be with you only to pass through the swamp."

Original: Qual è colui che grande inganno ascolta che li sia fatto, e poi se ne rammarca, fecesi Flegïàs ne l’ira accolta
Translate: "Flegias broke out, angry, after hearing the deception that had been perpetrated and felt regret."

Original: Lo duca mio discese ne la barca, e poi mi fece intrare appresso lui
Translate: My chaperone preceded me on the boat and then invited me up.

Original: e sol quand’io fui dentro parve carca
Translate: "At that point, the boat seemed to have a load."

Original: Tosto che ’l duca e io nel legno fui, segando se ne va l’antica prora de l’acqua più che non suol con altrui
Translate: "As soon as Virgilio and I boarded, the boat pulled off the ground more forcefully than usual."

Original: Mentre noi corravam la morta gora, dinanzi mi si fece un pien di fango, e disse: "Chi se’ tu che vieni anzi ora?"
Translate: "While we were passing through that murky swamp, a creature stained with mud approached me and asked, "Who are you who arrives in Hell before destiny?"

Original: E io a lui: "S’i’ vegno, non rimango
Translate: "I replied for a long time: "If I came, my stay would be limited"

Original: ma tu chi se’, che sì se’ fatto brutto?"
Translate: "Who are you, since they made you unrecognizable?"

Original: Rispuose: "Vedi che son un che piango"
Translate: "She replied: "As you can see, I am tremendously suffering"

Original: E io a lui: "Con piangere e con lutto, spirito maladetto, ti rimani
Translate: "And I said to him, "Be sad and grieving, evil spirit."

Original: ch’i’ ti conosco, ancor sie lordo tutto"
Translate: "Despite all your mud growing, I recognize you."

Original: Allor distese al legno ambo le mani
Translate: Then the cursed man leaned with both hands towards the boat.

Original: per che ’l maestro accorto lo sospinse, dicendo: "Via costà con li altri cani"
Translate: "The master, prudent, I cast him out, commanding him: "Get out of here immediately and return with your fellows"

Original: Lo collo poi con le braccia mi cinse
Translate: He held me tightly around my neck with his arms.

Original: basciommi ’l volto e disse: "Alma sdegnosa, benedetta colei che ’n te s’incinse
Translate: He gave her a kiss on her face and exclaimed: "O magnificent soul, blessed is he who has begotten you!"

Original: Quei fu al mondo persona orgogliosa
Translate: He boasted that he was an authoritative figure in the world.

Original: bontà non è che sua memoria fregi: così s’è l’ombra sua qui furïosa
Translate: "There is no noble gesture that justifies his reputation, so his soul is still here, in a state of rage."

Original: Quanti si tegnon or là sù gran regi che qui staranno come porci in brago, di sé lasciando orribili dispregi"
Translate: "Many men believe they have a royal existence, but in Hell they become as insignificant as frogs in the mud, leaving on their passage an unpleasant memory."

Original: E io: "Maestro, molto sarei vago di vederlo attuffare in questa broda prima che noi uscissimo del lago"
Translate: "And I: "Master, I have an immense desire to see him sink into the marsh before he comes out of the marsh."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Avante che la proda ti si lasci veder, tu sarai sazio: di tal disïo convien che tu goda"
Translate: "Before you reach the shore, you will be happy: it is important that your desire be fulfilled."

Original: Dopo ciò poco vid’io quello strazio far di costui a le fangose genti, che Dio ancor ne lodo e ne ringrazio
Translate: "Soon afterward I saw that the condemned immersed in the mud made him a great sacrifice, for which I still praise him and thank God."

Original: Tutti gridavano: "A Filippo Argenti"
Translate: ""The execrates gained strength, screaming: "Contro Filippo Argenti!""

Original: e ’l fiorentino spirito bizzarro in sé medesmo si volvea co’ denti
Translate: The unique Florentine temperament nibbled itself with its own teeth.

Original: Quivi il lasciammo, che più non ne narro
Translate: I didn't say anything else about him after I left him here.

Original: ma ne l’orecchie mi percosse un duolo, per ch’io avante l’occhio intento sbarro
Translate: "While I listened, I heard a desolate chorus that alarmed me to the point of raising my head."

Original: Lo buon maestro disse: "Omai, figliuolo, s’appressa la città c’ ha nome Dite, coi gravi cittadin, col grande stuolo"
Translate: "The master of goodness exclaimed: "Nearby, my heir, there is the afflicted city known as the Dite inhabited by its poor inhabitants and a huge array of demons."

Original: E io: "Maestro, già le sue meschite là entro certe ne la valle cerno, vermiglie come se di foco uscite  fossero"
Translate: "I cried out to my master, "I look at his mosques in the distance, like a living flame, of a burning red.""

Original: Ed ei mi disse: "Il foco etterno ch’entro l’affoca le dimostra rosse, come tu vedi in questo basso inferno"
Translate: He told me: "The glowing flames in this low Hell are what the color tints you can admire.

Original: Noi pur giungemmo dentro a l’alte fosse che vallan quella terra sconsolata: le mura mi parean che ferro fosse
Translate: We reached the deep ravines that surrounded that desolate land: the walls appeared to me as made of iron.

Original: Non sanza prima far grande aggirata, venimmo in parte dove il nocchier forte "Usciteci", gridò: "qui è l’intrata"
Translate: "After having made a wide tour, we finally arrived at the destination where the horrible ferryman shouted: "Get off, this is the stage!"

Original: Io vidi più di mille in su le porte da ciel piovuti, che stizzosamente dicean: "Chi è costui che sanza morte  va per lo regno de la morta gente?"
Translate: "While I was heading toward the gates, I heard a gloomy sound and sound coming from above: over a thousand evil beings had come down from the heavens screaming with rage: "For what recklessness does this creature dare to cross the kingdom of the extinct?"

Original: E ’l savio mio maestro fece segno di voler lor parlar segretamente
Translate: My wise teacher pointed to the desire to speak with them individually.

Original: Allor chiusero un poco il gran disdegno e disser: "Vien tu solo, e quei sen vada che sì ardito intrò per questo regno
Translate: "They calmed their indignation a little and declared: "You come alone, while the other must go away for having dared to enter this abode"."

Original: Sol si ritorni per la folle strada:
Translate: "Take on your own the path you chose at a hectic pace, if you're bold enough."

Original: pruovi, se sa ché tu qui rimarrai, che li ha’ iscorta sì buia contrada"
Translate: "In fact, you showed their path in the dark, so you have to stay here."

Original: Pensa, lettor, se io mi sconfortai nel suon de le parole maladette, ché non credetti ritornarci mai
Translate: "I remembered, reader, how comforted I felt despite those cursed words: I had faith that one day I would return to Earth."

Original: "O caro duca mio, che più di sette volte m’ hai sicurtà renduta e tratto d’alto periglio che ’ncontra mi stette,  non mi lasciar", diss’io, "così disfatto
Translate: "I turned to my precious guide, who had always provided protection and saved me from a grave danger, begging her not to abandon me in that situation."

Original: e se ’l passar più oltre ci è negato, ritroviam l’orme nostre insieme ratto"
Translate: "If we can't move forward, let's try to make our way back."

Original: E quel segnor che lì m’avea menato, mi disse:
Translate: The master who had accompanied me to that point said to me:

Original: "Non temer ché ’l nostro passo non ci può tòrre alcun: da tal n’è dato
Translate: "Do not be afraid, for nothing can hinder our journey, decreed by God."

Original: Ma qui m’attendi, e lo spirito lasso conforta e ciba di speranza buona, ch’i’ non ti lascerò nel mondo basso"
Translate: "Stay here, and give yourself some positive hope because I will never abandon you to hell."

Original: Così sen va, e quivi m’abbandona lo dolce padre, e io rimagno in forse, che sì e no nel capo mi tenciona
Translate: "So the loving father left the scene, leaving me behind with enormous uncertainty about what might have happened."

Original: Udir non potti quello ch’a lor porse
Translate: I could not hear what he said to the devils.

Original: ma ei non stette là con essi guari, che ciascun dentro a pruova si ricorse
Translate: "However, they didn't stay and argue for long, for each of them quickly resumed the path where the city walls led him."

Original: Chiuser le porte que’ nostri avversari nel petto al mio segnor, che fuor rimase e rivolsesi a me con passi rari
Translate: "Our opponents blocked access to my teacher, who had to go back to me with sedentary pace."

Original: Li occhi a la terra e le ciglia avea rase d’ogne baldanza, e dicea ne’ sospiri: "Chi m' ha negate le dolenti case"
Translate: "His head was bowed down, extremely insecure; while he sighed and wondered, "Who prevented me from entering the painful city?"."

Original: E a me disse: "Tu, perch’io m’adiri, non sbigottir, ch’io vincerò la prova, qual ch’a la difension dentro s’aggiri
Translate: "He said to me: "Do not lose hope, even though I am angry. The outcome of the trial will be in my favor, whatever the defensive plan they have prepared in the city"."

Original: Questa lor tracotanza non è nova
Translate: Their air of superiority is nothing new.

Original: ché già l’usaro a men segreta porta, la qual sanza serrame ancor si trova
Translate: "They used this door to defend a less hidden entrance, which still remains unhindered today."

Original: Sovr’essa vedestù la scritta morta:
Translate: The threatening inscription was imprinted on it.

Original: e già di qua da lei discende l’erta, passando per li cerchi sanza scorta,  tal che per lui ne fia la terra aperta"
Translate: "A heavenly messenger descends along the descent, crossing the Circles in the absence of a guard and will give rise to a path for us."

Original: Quel color che viltà di fuor mi pinse veggendo il duca mio tornare in volta, più tosto dentro il suo novo ristrinse
Translate: "My fear that had been painted on my face, seeing my guide turn back, made Virgil keep his doubts to himself."

Original: Attento si fermò com’uom ch’ascolta
Translate: "He stopped, carrying his ear to hear."

Original: ché l’occhio nol potea menare a lunga per l’aere nero e per la nebbia folta
Translate: "Despite the darkness and thick fog, he couldn't see much in the distance."

Original: "Pur a noi converrà vincer la punga", cominciò el, "se non tal ne s’offerse
Translate: "From abroad" he exclaimed: "Only if foreign support is not guaranteed, it is certain that we will succeed in triumphing in the enterprise!"

Original: Oh quanto tarda a me ch’altri qui giunga"
Translate: I hope he gets here soon.

Original: I’ vidi ben sì com’ei ricoperse lo cominciar con l’altro che poi venne, che fur parole a le prime diverse
Translate: "if he understood that I understood that, if he understood the situation, his speech would be different from the initial one."

Original: ma nondimen paura il suo dir dienne, perch’io traeva la parola tronca forse a peggior sentenzia che non tenne
Translate: "Even though his words caused me fear, I interpreted the sentence interrupted in a more negative way than it really was."

Original: "In questo fondo de la trista conca discende mai alcun del primo grado, che sol per pena ha la speranza cionca?"
Translate: "Has it ever occurred that a soul from the First Heaven, whose fate and doomed to lack hope to save itself, has reached the deepest Hell?"

Original: Questa question fec’io
Translate: I questioned Virgilio on this subject.

Original: e quei "Di rado incontra", mi rispuose, "che di noi faccia il cammino alcun per qual io vado
Translate: It rarely happens that one of us walks this same path.

Original: Ver è ch’altra fïata qua giù fui, congiurato da quella Eritón cruda che richiamava l’ombre a’ corpi sui
Translate: "Nevertheless, I was called down here by Eritone, the cruel magician who invited souls to take back their bodies."

Original: Di poco era di me la carne nuda, ch’ella mi fece intrar dentr’a quel muro, per trarne un spirto del cerchio di Giuda
Translate: "I had recently detached myself from my physique, when she led me into those walls to evoke an essence from Judecca."

Original: Quell’è ’l più basso loco e ’l più oscuro, e ’l più lontan dal ciel che tutto gira: ben so ’l cammin però ti fa sicuro
Translate: "That is such an extreme place in hell, the most remote from the First Mobile: I know how to get down there, so don't worry."

Original: Questa palude che ’l gran puzzo spira cigne dintorno la città dolente, u’ non potemo intrare omai sanz’ira"
Translate: "The city of Dite is surrounded by the smelly swamp, which we cannot deceive except by forcing the will of the demons."

Original: E altro disse, ma non l’ ho a mente
Translate: "He added something else, but I don't remember."

Original: però che l’occhio m’avea tutto tratto ver’ l’alta torre a la cima rovente,
Translate: The view of the high bell tower with glowing edges caught my attention.

Original: dove in un punto furon dritte ratto tre furïe infernal di sangue tinte, che membra feminine avieno e atto,  e con idre verdissime eran cinte
Translate: "At one point the three Infernal Furies had been shown, whose body was stained with blood and their attitude attributable to the feminine one; surrounded by idres emanating an intense green."

Original: serpentelli e ceraste avien per crine, onde le fiere tempie erano avvinte
Translate: "they had hair intertwined with snakes and waxers, draped around the temples."

Original: E quei, che ben conobbe le meschine de la regina de l’etterno pianto, "Guarda", mi disse, "le feroci Erine
Translate: "Virgilio, immediately recognizing the maidens of the queen of Hell, pointed out to me: "Look at the fearsome Erinni."

Original: Quest’è Megera dal sinistro canto
Translate: Megera is on the left.

Original: quella che piange dal destro è Aletto
Translate: Aletto's the one who's crying on the right.

Original: Tesifón è nel mezzo"
Translate: Thesis is located in the center.

Original: e tacque a tanto
Translate: At that point he remained silent.

Original: Con l’unghie si fendea ciascuna il petto
Translate: Each tore his chest with his fingernails

Original: battiensi a palme e gridavan sì alto, ch’i’ mi strinsi al poeta per sospetto
Translate: "They collided beating their hands and screaming so loud that I, terrified, clinged to Virgilio."

Original: "Vegna Medusa: sì ’l farem di smalto",
Translate: "We call on Medusa to turn this person into a stone."

Original: dicevan tutte riguardando in giuso
Translate: They all looked down.

Original: "mal non vengiammo in Tesëo l’assalto"
Translate: We should have avenged Theseo's assault.

Original: "Volgiti ’n dietro e tien lo viso chiuso
Translate: Turn around and keep your eyes closed.

Original: ché se ’l Gorgón si mostra e tu ’l vedessi, nulla sarebbe di tornar mai suso"
Translate: "If you had the audacity to look at the Gorgone, there would be no chance for you to return to Earth."

Original: Così disse ’l maestro
Translate: The Master uttered such words

Original: ed elli stessi mi volse, e non si tenne a le mie mani, che con le sue ancor non mi chiudessi
Translate: "He took the task of making me cover my eyes, going far beyond: he went to complete the work by joining his hands with mine."

Original: O voi ch'avete li 'ntelletti sani, mirate la dottrina che s'asconde sotto 'l velame de li versi strani
Translate: "Those who enjoy acute intelligence take note of the wisdom hidden under my enigmatic words."

Original: E già venìa su per le torbide onde un fracasso d’un suon, pien di spavento, per cui tremavano amendue le sponde,  non altrimenti fatto che d’un vento impetüoso per li avversi ardori, che fier la selva e sanz’alcun rattento  li rami schianta, abbatte e porta fori
Translate: "Along the muddy waters of the Styx spread a deafening noise, inciting terror so intense that it made both sides tremble; it was like the strong wind that hits the forest with its temperature changes without having any consideration in destroying and dragging away the trees."

Original: dinanzi polveroso va superbo, e fa fuggir le fiere e li pastori
Translate: "It provokes in the air of challenge between the earth swept by the wind, instilling fear to the fairs and peasants."

Original: Li occhi mi sciolse e disse: "Or drizza il nerbo del viso su per quella schiuma antica per indi ove quel fummo è più acerbo"
Translate: "Virgilio gave me the inspiration to stare at that far-off swamp, where a thick fog clouded."

Original: Come le rane innanzi a la nimica biscia per l’acqua si dileguan tutte,
Translate: "Like frogs, they all escape when they see their enemy, the biscuit."

Original: fin ch’a la terra ciascuna s’abbica,
Translate: until each land lands on the mainland

Original: vid’io più di mille anime distrutte fuggir così dinanzi ad un ch’al passo passava Stige con le piante asciutte
Translate: "I saw more than a thousand angry souls fleeing frightened in front of those who crossed the Stige, without getting wet their feet."

Original: Dal volto rimovea quell’aere grasso, menando la sinistra innanzi spesso
Translate: Smoke was often removed from his face with his left hand.

Original: e sol di quell’angoscia parea lasso
Translate: It seemed that this was his only annoyance.

Original: Ben m’accorsi ch’elli era da ciel messo, e volsimi al maestro
Translate: Instantly I realized that he was the angel sent and addressed my greeting to the teacher.

Original: e quei fé segno ch’i’ stessi queto ed inchinassi ad esso
Translate: He gave me a sign of staying calm and bowing down as a sign of respect for the newcomer.

Original: Ahi quanto mi parea pien di disdegno
Translate: "Oh, how disdainful it seemed to me."

Original: Venne a la porta e con una verghetta l’aperse, che non v’ebbe alcun ritegno
Translate: "He came to Dite's door and entered, without resistance, thanks to a stick."

Original: "O cacciati del ciel, gente dispetta", cominciò elli in su l’orribil soglia, "ond’esta oltracotanza in voi s’alletta?
Translate: "Would you have been banished from Heaven, despised people - how can your pride be so deep?" he began to declare on the frightening door."

Original: Perché recalcitrate a quella voglia a cui non puote il fin mai esser mozzo, e che più volte v’ ha cresciuta doglia?
Translate: "Why do you oppose that will that will inevitably bring benefits and has already caused you suffering on several occasions?"

Original: Che giova ne le fata dar di cozzo? Cerbero vostro, se ben vi ricorda, ne porta ancor pelato il mento e ’l gozzo"
Translate: "To resist destiny brings with it severe consequences, as in the case of "your Cerberus," which still shows the signs of punishment suffered for doing so."

Original: Poi si rivolse per la strada lorda, e non fé motto a noi, ma fé sembiante d’omo cui altra cura stringa e morda  che quella di colui che li è davante
Translate: "Afterwards he returned with tired passage through the mud, without telling us a word, but it seemed that he had much bigger issues for the mind than he would have to deal with."

Original: e noi movemmo i piedi inver’ la terra, sicuri appresso le parole sante
Translate: "We headed to the earth with confidence, thanks to the blessings we had received."

Original: Dentro li ’ntrammo sanz’alcuna guerra
Translate: "Without encountering difficulties, we entered the city."

Original: e io, ch’avea di riguardar disio la condizion che tal fortezza serra,  com’io fui dentro, l’occhio intorno invio: e veggio ad ogne man grande campagna, piena di duolo e di tormento rio
Translate: "I had a strong desire to examine the situation of the souls locked up in that fortress, so as soon as I was inside, I looked around. Dissonant presences - sorrows and bitter torments - floated around me on a vast plain."

Original: Sì come ad Arli, ove Rodano stagna, sì com’a Pola, presso del Carnaro ch’Italia chiude e suoi termini bagna,  fanno i sepulcri tutt’il loco varo, così facevan quivi d’ogne parte, salvo che ’l modo v’era più amaro
Translate: "As in Arles, the Rhône palutes itself and as in Pula where the Gulf of Kvarner languishes Italy, desolation is penetrating in the surrounding cemeteries; however here it produced more pain."

Original: ché tra li avelli fiamme erano sparte, per le quali eran sì del tutto accesi, che ferro più non chiede verun’arte
Translate: The flames scattered between the tombs were so hot that they did not require a hotter iron than the one used in handcrafting.

Original: Tutti li lor coperchi eran sospesi, e fuor n’uscivan sì duri lamenti, che ben parean di miseri e d’offesi
Translate: "All the covers were lifted up and supported, with so heartbreaking groaning that they seemed to belong to lost souls."

Original: E io: "Maestro, quai son quelle genti che, seppellite dentro da quell’arche, si fan sentir coi sospiri dolenti?"
Translate: "I said, "Master, who is it that emits those sad sighs from buried graves?"

Original: E quelli a me: "Qui son li eresïarche con lor seguaci, d’ogne setta, e molto più che non credi son le tombe carche
Translate: "and he replied, "Here lie the heresiarchs with their followers of every sect; they are much more numerous than you can imagine"."

Original: Simile qui con simile è sepolto, e i monimenti son più e men caldi"
Translate: "Everyone considered heretical has been buried with others of its kind, with tombs that vary in terms of temperature."

Original: E poi ch’a la man destra si fu vòlto,  passammo tra i martìri e li alti spaldi
Translate: "Once he had turned right, we set out for graves and high railings."

Original: Ora sen va per un secreto calle, tra ’l muro de la terra e li martìri, lo mio maestro, e io dopo le spalle
Translate: "At that point my teacher headed along a hidden path, between the walls and the burials, and I followed him."

Original: "O virtù somma, che per li empi giri mi volvi", cominciai, "com’a te piace, parlami, e sodisfammi a’ miei disiri
Translate: "?I knelt before the ruler of wisdom and begged him to lead me through the sections of Hell, fulfill my longing and explain his sordid mysteries to me?"

Original: La gente che per li sepolcri giace potrebbesi veder? già son levati tutt’i coperchi, e nessun guardia face"
Translate: Could the condemned be seen lying in the graves? Each sarcophagus is unlocked and there is no demon watching over them.

Original: E quelli a me: "Tutti saran serrati quando di Iosafàt qui torneranno coi corpi che là sù hanno lasciati
Translate: "And he, referring to the dead: "When the souls return from the valley of Jehoshaphat and have reunited their bodies left on Earth, they will all be closed in themselves."

Original: Suo cimitero da questa parte hanno con Epicuro tutti suoi seguaci, che l’anima col corpo morta fanno
Translate: "Epicuro and his supporters, who believed in the immortality of the soul, were deprived of this place of the cemetery."

Original: Però a la dimanda che mi faci quinc’entro satisfatto sarà tosto, e al disio ancor che tu mi taci"
Translate: "Soon will come the desires that you have revealed to me, and also the one that you do not want to talk about."

Original: E io: "Buon duca, non tegno riposto a te mio cuor se non per dicer poco, e tu m’ hai non pur mo a ciò disposto"
Translate: "I exclaimed: "You, my kind counselor, although I am generally quite cheap in words I am certainly not holding back my feelings; you have taught me this rule several times"."

Original: "O Tosco che per la città del foco vivo ten vai così parlando onesto, piacciati di restare in questo loco
Translate: "A little "O you, native of Tuscany that you are heading towards the City of Fire speaking so noble, it would be courteous of you if we stayed a little "."

Original: La tua loquela ti fa manifesto di quella nobil patrïa natio, a la qual forse fui troppo molesto"
Translate: "The accent that you have revealed that you were born in the same land that I was perhaps too intrusive for."

Original: Subitamente questo suono uscìo d’una de l’arche
Translate: An unexpected sound rose from the grave.

Original: però m’accostai, temendo, un poco più al duca mio
Translate: I felt fear and approached my teacher.

Original: Ed el mi disse: "Volgiti
Translate: He invited me to turn around.

Original: Che fai? Vedi là Farinata che s’è dritto: da la cintola in sù tutto ’l vedrai"
Translate: Don't you notice over there that Farinata has risen? You can see it in part from the belt upwards.

Original: Io avea già il mio viso nel suo fitto
Translate: I had already pointed my eyes at hers.

Original: ed el s’ergea col petto e con la fronte com’avesse l’inferno a gran dispitto
Translate: "He stood straight, raising his head and back proudly, as if he were challenging the entire Abyss."

Original: E l’animose man del duca e pronte mi pinser tra le sepulture a lui, dicendo: "Le parole tue sien conte"
Translate: "With his strong and fearless hands, Virgil guided me through the cemetery to him. My mentor said, "Make sure your eloquence is thought"."

Original: Com’io al piè de la sua tomba fui, guardommi un poco, e poi, quasi sdegnoso, mi dimandò: "Chi fuor li maggior tui?"
Translate: "When I stood before his burial, he turned to me with an expression of indignation on my face and asked me, "What are your origins?"

Original: Io ch’era d’ubidir disideroso, non gliel celai, ma tutto gliel’apersi
Translate: I showed my readiness to obey and answered his questions thoroughly.

Original: ond’ei levò le ciglia un poco in suso
Translate: Then he raised his eyebrows imperceptibly.

Original: poi disse: "Fieramente furo avversi a me e a miei primi e a mia parte, sì che per due fïate li dispersi"
Translate: "Afterwards he said: "They were fierce enemies of my family, of my origins and of the party to which I belonged so much that I had to drive them out twice from the city of Florence"."

Original: "S’ei fur cacciati, ei tornar d’ogne parte", rispuos’io lui, "l’una e l’altra fïata
Translate: "I replied: "Despite being driven out, they returned from all directions in both cases."

Original: ma i vostri non appreser ben quell’arte"
Translate: "Your ancestors, on the contrary, were not so capable."

Original: Allor surse a la vista scoperchiata un’ombra, lungo questa, infino al mento: credo che s’era in ginocchie levata
Translate: "A soul appeared on the ground at our sight, kneeling on the ground next to Farinata until the chin: I think it was so."

Original: Dintorno mi guardò, come talento avesse di veder s’altri era meco
Translate: "He looked around, like he was trying to figure out if I was alone."

Original: e poi che ’l sospecciar fu tutto spento,  piangendo disse: "Se per questo cieco carcere vai per altezza d’ingegno, mio figlio ov’è? e perché non è teco?"
Translate: "He asked me crying, "If you were imprisoned for your intellect, where is my son? Why isn't he here with you?" Once he had stopped observing."

Original: E io a lui: "Da me stesso non vegno: colui ch’attende là, per qui mi mena forse cui Guido vostro ebbe a disdegno"
Translate: "I said to him, "Don't give me all the credit, someone who lies there has accompanied me through the flames of Hell in the direction of her whom your son Guido may have refused."

Original: Le sue parole e ’l modo de la pena m’avean di costui già letto il nome
Translate: "I knew who he was because of his words, which revealed his belonging to Epicurean philosophy."

Original: però fu la risposta così piena
Translate: "As a result, I reacted immediately."

Original: Di sùbito drizzato gridò: "Come? dicesti "elli ebbe"? non viv’elli ancora? non fiere li occhi suoi lo dolce lume?"
Translate: He leaped up and shouted, "What did you say? Is Guido no longer here with us? Doesn't the radiant sun brighten his blue eyes anymore?"

Original: Quando s’accorse d’alcuna dimora ch’io facëa dinanzi a la risposta, supin ricadde e più non parve fora
Translate: "When he realized that I hesitated to answer, he fell backwards and no longer emerged from the grave."

Original: Ma quell’altro magnanimo, a cui posta restato m’era, non mutò aspetto, né mosse collo, né piegò sua costa
Translate: "But that other condemned noble, to whom I had answered the question, did not change the expression, nor did he seem at all disturbed by what happened."

Original: e sé continüando al primo detto, "S’elli han quell’arte", disse, "male appresa, ciò mi tormenta più che questo letto
Translate: "Resuming what he had said, he said: "I have more pain for the lack of education of my ancestors on how to return to Florence than for this tomb."

Original: Ma non cinquanta volte fia raccesa la faccia de la donna che qui regge, che tu saprai quanto quell’arte pesa
Translate: "Fifty phases of the moon, you'll understand how painful that art is."

Original: E se tu mai nel dolce mondo regge, dimmi: perché quel popolo è sì empio incontr’a’ miei in ciascuna sua legge?"
Translate: Why is this how the Florentines handle the measures against my family?

Original: Ond’io a lui: "Lo strazio e ’l grande scempio che fece l’Arbia colorata in rosso, tal orazion fa far nel nostro tempio"
Translate: "With the sad tragic events of Montaperti, which stained the Arbia with blood, it is precisely for this reason that we have come to the conclusion of issuing such laws."

Original: Poi ch’ebbe sospirando il capo mosso, "A ciò non fu’ io sol", disse, "né certo sanza cagion con li altri sarei mosso
Translate: "Shooking the head sadly, he said: "Mine was only a small part in the struggle; I would not go against my will for no valid reason."

Original: Ma fu’ io solo, là dove sofferto fu per ciascun di tòrre via Fiorenza, colui che la difesi a viso aperto"
Translate: "I committed myself to being the only voice in defense of Florence, when every Ghibelline leader threatened to destroy its city completely."

Original: "Deh, se riposi mai vostra semenza", prega’ io lui, "solvetemi quel nodo che qui ha ’nviluppata mia sentenza
Translate: "Then I begged: "Please, may your descendants find serenity: clarify to me the dilemma that torments me."

Original: El par che voi veggiate, se ben odo, dinanzi quel che ’l tempo seco adduce, e nel presente tenete altro modo"
Translate: "It seems that you, damned, are able to see future events, if I have interpreted correctly, while you have a limited understanding of the present."

Original: "Noi veggiam, come quei c’ ha mala luce, le cose", disse, "che ne son lontano
Translate: " or in space as closer than they really are," he said: "We can have the tendency, like those who suffer from an imperfect vision, to perceive distant events in time and space as if they were closer to reality."

Original: cotanto ancor ne splende il sommo duce
Translate: God allows us only this

Original: Quando s’appressano o son, tutto è vano nostro intelletto e s’altri non ci apporta,
Translate: "We can't understand what's going on unless others give us some information."

Original: nulla sapem di vostro stato umano
Translate: Ignoring the Human Situation of Your Family

Original: Però comprender puoi che tutta morta fia nostra conoscenza da quel punto che del futuro fia chiusa la porta"
Translate: "It can be deduced that all our knowledge will become obliterated once it arrives at the Day of Judgment, which symbolizes the door to the future."

Original: Allor, come di mia colpa compunto, dissi: "Or direte dunque a quel caduto che ’l suo nato è co’ vivi ancor congiunto
Translate: Then I confessed my guilt and declared: "Inform the wretched man that his son is still alive."

Original: e s’i’ fui, dianzi, a la risposta muto, fate i saper che ’l fei perché pensava già ne l’error che m’avete soluto"
Translate: "If I didn't respond immediately before, tell him it was because I was still trying to understand the mistake you explained to me."

Original: E già ’l maestro mio mi richiamava
Translate: Virgil was calling me

Original: per ch’i’ pregai lo spirto più avaccio che mi dicesse chi con lu’ istava
Translate: So I quickly begged the spirit that he might reveal to me his fellow prisoners.

Original: Dissemi: "Qui con più di mille giaccio: qua dentro è ’l secondo Federico e ’l Cardinale
Translate: "He replied: "Here we find more than a thousand damned souls, including Frederick II of Swabia and Cardinal Ottaviano of the Ubaldini."

Original: e de li altri mi taccio"
Translate: I'm not gonna give you any information about the others.

Original: Indi s’ascose
Translate: "As a result, he returned to the grave."

Original: e io inver’ l’antico poeta volsi i passi, ripensando a quel parlar che mi parea nemico
Translate: "Getting away from the ancient poet, I thought about the words that had struck me so hostilely."

Original: Elli si mosse
Translate: Virgil took his path.

Original: e poi, così andando, mi disse: "Perché se’ tu sì smarrito?"
Translate: "Was he walking, asking me why I was so worried?"

Original: E io li sodisfeci al suo dimando
Translate: I gave him an explanation

Original: "La mente tua conservi quel ch’udito hai contra te", mi comandò quel saggio
Translate: "That wise man advised me to give his memory what I received as criticism.

Original: "e ora attendi qui", e drizzò ’l dito:  "quando sarai dinanzi al dolce raggio di quella il cui bell’occhio tutto vede, da lei saprai di tua vita il vïaggio"
Translate: "When you present yourself to the bright eyes of the one who sees everything, you will discover your destiny for the future."

Original: Appresso mosse a man sinistra il piede: lasciammo il muro e gimmo inver’ lo mezzo per un sentier ch’a una valle fiede,  che ’nfin là sù facea spiacer suo lezzo
Translate: Then we changed direction, away from the wall: we took the path that led to a valley where the air was unbearable

Original: In su l’estremità d’un’alta ripa che facevan gran pietre rotte in cerchio, venimmo sopra più crudele stipa
Translate: "We arrived at the foot of a high cliff on which the rocks were piled in a circle, a few steps ahead of the next Circle."

Original: e quivi, per l’orribile soperchio del puzzo che ’l profondo abisso gitta, ci raccostammo, in dietro, ad un coperchio  d’un grand’avello,
Translate: "We hid behind the lid of a great grave, horrified by the terrible stench coming from the depths of hell."

Original: ov’io vidi una scritta che dicea: ’Anastasio papa guardo, lo qual trasse Fotin de la via dritta’
Translate: "Lessi a script that recited: "Anastasio papa, led off the right road by Fotino"."

Original: "Lo nostro scender conviene esser tardo, sì che s’ausi un poco in prima il senso al tristo fiato
Translate: "It's gonna take a while before we get used to the bad smell, so it would be better to wait before we go down."

Original: e poi no i fia riguardo"
Translate: There will be no more courtesy to be respected.

Original: Così ’l maestro
Translate: "Virgilio, so he affirmed."

Original: e io "Alcun compenso", dissi lui, "trova che ’l tempo non passi perduto"
Translate: I advised him to look for a way not to waste time.

Original: Ed elli: "Vedi ch’a ciò penso"
Translate: He said, "I think so."

Original: "Figliuol mio, dentro da cotesti sassi", cominciò poi a dir, "son tre cerchietti di grado in grado, come que’ che lassi
Translate: "He began to say: "My son, under these stones there is a succession of three Circles, superimposed like the others you have seen."

Original: Tutti son pien di spirti maladetti
Translate: They all have evil spirits persecuting them.

Original: ma perché poi ti basti pur la vista, intendi come e perché son costretti
Translate: "Listen carefully how and why they are together, so as to be satisfied with their relationship in the future."

Original: D'ogne malizia, ch'odio in cielo acquista, ingiuria è 'l fine, ed ogne fin cotale o con forza o con frode altrui contrista
Translate: "The desired result of every wicked act that is hated by God is offense, and it is achieved by force or dishonesty."

Original: Ma perché frode è de l’uom proprio male, più spiace a Dio
Translate: "Deception is a crime that only man commits, therefore it is not well accepted before God."

Original: e però stan di sotto li frodolenti, e più dolor li assale
Translate: Lawbreakers are considered low - stature and severely punished.

Original: Di vïolenti il primo cerchio è tutto
Translate: The first circle is reserved for those who have committed acts of violence.

Original: ma perché si fa forza a tre persone, in tre gironi è distinto e costrutto
Translate: "As violence can be exercised on three different objectives, it is divided into three groups."

Original: A Dio, a sé, al prossimo si pòne far forza, dico in loro e in lor cose, come udirai con aperta ragione
Translate: "You can apply violence to God, to yourself, to your neighbor, to people and to their things; later I will expose you to a rational explanation."

Original: Morte per forza e ferute dogliose nel prossimo si danno, e nel suo avere ruine, incendi e tollette dannose
Translate: "You can cause your neighbor death, painful injuries, and destroy his belongings with looting, fires and robberies."

Original: onde omicide e ciascun che mal fiere, guastatori e predon, tutti tormenta lo giron primo per diverse schiere
Translate: "All those who commit murders, thefts and violence suffer punishment in the first sphere of Hell."

Original: Puote omo avere in sé man vïolenta e ne’ suoi beni
Translate: Man can be aggressive toward himself and in his possessions.

Original: e però nel secondo giron convien che sanza pro si penta  qualunque priva sé del vostro mondo, biscazza e fonde la sua facultade, e piange là dov’esser de’ giocondo
Translate: "Whoever committed suicide and who spent or dissipated his money, in vain yearns to enter the second round, but it would have been better if he had chosen to live happily instead of weeping on the property left on earth."

Original: Puossi far forza ne la deïtade, col cor negando e bestemmiando quella, e spregiando natura e sua bontade
Translate: "You can express violence against God, through distrust of Him and not recognize Him, or neglecting respect for nature and ignoring its benevolence."

Original: e però lo minor giron suggella del segno suo e Soddoma e Caorsa e chi, spregiando Dio col cor, favella
Translate: "Therefore, the third group imposes sanctions on those who commit homosexuality and usury, as well as those who turn against God in a reckless way in their hearts."

Original: La frode, ond'ogne coscïenza è morsa, può l'omo usare in colui che 'n lui fida e in quel che fidanza non imborsa
Translate: "The fraud, from which can arouse deep remorse of conscience, could be perpetrated by men both towards those in whom one trusts and towards those to whom one does not believe."

Original: Questo modo di retro par ch’incida pur lo vinco d’amor che fa natura
Translate: This seems to break only the bond of love that nature has drawn.

Original: onde nel cerchio secondo s’annida  ipocresia, lusinghe e chi affattura, falsità, ladroneccio e simonia, ruffian, baratti e simile lordura
Translate: "Therefore in the second circle are found punished hypocrites, flatterers, sorcerers, forgers, thieves, simonians, corrupters of young maidens and disloyal merchants."

Original: Per l’altro modo quell’amor s’oblia che fa natura, e quel ch’è poi aggiunto, di che la fede spezïal si cria
Translate: "Unlearning, you also lose the natural love and the connection of fidelity that often unites people."

Original: onde nel cerchio minore, ov’è ’l punto de l’universo in su che Dite siede, qualunque trade in etterno è consunto"
Translate: "Lucifer presides over the smallest circle, where traitors are destined to endure eternal punishment."

Original: E io: "Maestro, assai chiara procede la tua ragione, e assai ben distingue questo baràtro e ’l popol ch’e’ possiede
Translate: "I said to the Master: ""Your explanation is understandable and clearly shows this abyss along with those who have been condemned to it"."

Original: Ma dimmi: quei de la palude pingue, che mena il vento, e che batte la pioggia, e che s’incontran con sì aspre lingue,
Translate: "Those who find themselves in the muddy swamp, those overwhelmed by the storm, the wet with the rain and the angry with each other exchanging words of contempt."

Original: perché non dentro da la città roggia sono ei puniti, se Dio li ha in ira? e se non li ha, perché sono a tal foggia?"
Translate: "If God does not hate them, why are they punished in Hell instead of in the city of Dite?"

Original: Ed elli a me "Perché tanto delira", disse, "lo ’ngegno tuo da quel che sòle?
Translate: He asked me: "Why do you so far away from your usual paths?"

Original: o ver la mente dove altrove mira?
Translate: Where does he ever look at your mind instead?

Original: Non ti rimembra di quelle parole con le quai la tua Etica pertratta le tre disposizion che ’l ciel non vole,
Translate: Remember those words with which Aristotle discusses the three sins that attract the condemnation of Heaven?

Original: incontenenza, malizia e la matta bestialitade?
Translate: "Great transgressions, malice and cruel racism."

Original: e come incontenenza men Dio offende e men biasimo accatta?
Translate: How does excess break divine law less and thus be punished with a lower penalty?

Original: Se tu riguardi ben questa sentenza, e rechiti a la mente chi son quelli che sù di fuor sostegnon penitenza,  tu vedrai ben perché da questi felli sien dipartiti, e perché men crucciata la divina vendetta li martelli"
Translate: "If you consider this statement and think of those condemned who are excluded from this city, you will understand well why they are separated from the guilty and why they receive a lesser punishment from divine justice."

Original: "O sol che sani ogne vista turbata, tu mi contenti sì quando tu solvi, che, non men che saver, dubbiar m'aggrata
Translate: "I exclaimed: "Ah, Sun that shines and heals every troubled look, you rejoice so much when you dissipute my doubt, that even asking questions gives me joy as to having wisdom."

Original: Ancora in dietro un poco ti rivolvi", diss’io, "là dove di’ ch’usura offende la divina bontade, e ’l groppo solvi"
Translate: "Go back again to the point where you claimed that wear is an insult to divine goodness, and clarify my doubt."

Original: "Filosofia", mi disse, "a chi la ’ntende, nota, non pure in una sola parte, come natura lo suo corso prende  dal divino ’ntelletto e da sua arte
Translate: "He told me that philosophy, for those who are able to understand it, claims that nature is governed by divine intelligence and dynamism through more books."

Original: e se tu ben la tua Fisica note, tu troverai, non dopo molte carte,  che l’arte vostra quella, quanto pote, segue, come ’l maestro fa ’l discente
Translate: "If you read the Physics carefully, you will realize that our work is similar to that of God, just as a disciple follows the example of his teacher."

Original: sì che vostr’arte a Dio quasi è nepote
Translate: so that your diligent activity is almost from God.

Original: Da queste due, se tu ti rechi a mente lo Genesì dal principio, convene prender sua vita e avanzar la gente
Translate: "If we examine Genesis, it emerges that man must gain his livelihood and progress through productive work."

Original: e perché l’usuriere altra via tene, per sé natura e per la sua seguace dispregia, poi ch’in altro pon la spene
Translate: "Following a way other than the usurer, he moves away from nature and sees in his industriousness only a submissive means to which he entrusts his trust rather than as a goal to be achieved."

Original: Ma seguimi oramai che ’l gir mi piace
Translate: "Come with me, for I think we should proceed."

Original: ché i Pesci guizzan su per l’orizzonta, e ’l Carro tutto sovra ’l Coro giace,  e ’l balzo via là oltra si dismonta"
Translate: "To reach the Circle below, we have to take another road. As the Pisces slide on the horizon, the Circle emerges far above the Chorus."

Original: Era lo loco ov’a scender la riva venimmo, alpestro e, per quel che v’er’anco, tal, ch’ogne vista ne sarebbe schiva
Translate: "To the destination we arrived to access the next Ring was impervious and, even with what it contained, so as not to want to see it."

Original: Qual è quella ruina che nel fianco di qua da Trento l’Adice percosse, o per tremoto o per sostegno manco,
Translate: "Like a landslide that occurred in the Adige bed near Trento, caused by an earthquake or lack of support."

Original: che da cima del monte, onde si mosse, al piano è sì la roccia discoscesa, ch’alcuna via darebbe a chi sù fosse:
Translate: "the rock is steep, starting from the plateau to the plain, but whoever tried to climb it could reach the ground below."

Original: cotal di quel burrato era la scesa
Translate: So the Dante's ravine came down.

Original: e ’n su la punta de la rotta lacca l’infamïa di Creti era distesa  che fu concetta ne la falsa vacca
Translate: "At the beginning of a escarpment was the shame of Crete, which had been conceived by an imitation bull."

Original: e quando vide noi, sé stesso morse, sì come quei cui l’ira dentro fiacca
Translate: "and when he saw them, he bit himself like he was overwhelmed with anger."

Original: Lo savio mio inver’ lui gridò: "Forse tu credi che qui sia ’l duca d’Atene, che sù nel mondo la morte ti porse?
Translate: "My teacher yelled at him: "Do you really think that the Duke of Athens is here, the one who caused you to disappear into the world?"

Original: Pàrtiti, bestia, ché questi non vene ammaestrato da la tua sorella, ma vassi per veder le vostre pene"
Translate: "Go away, you beast, as your sister has told you, do not come back here until you have endured your punishment."

Original: Qual è quel toro che si slaccia in quella c’ ha ricevuto già ’l colpo mortale, che gir non sa, ma qua e là saltella,  vid’io lo Minotauro far cotale
Translate: "Like a bull that has been struck to death and can no longer move without overwhelming, so I saw the Minotaur agitate after finally breaking the chains."

Original: e quello accorto gridò: "Corri al varco
Translate: "In imperious tone, Virgil cried, "Move quickly towards the passage!""

Original: mentre ch’e’ ’nfuria, è buon che tu ti cale"
Translate: You'd better get down while the monster's in a lot of turmoil.

Original: Così prendemmo via giù per lo scarco di quelle pietre, che spesso moviensi sotto i miei piedi per lo novo carco
Translate: "We ventured down the escarpment of those rocks, which sometimes trembled at my pace because of the load they weren't used to."

Original: Io gia pensando
Translate: I was thinking on my way.

Original: e quei disse: "Tu pensi forse a questa ruina, ch’è guardata da quell’ira bestial ch’i’ ora spensi
Translate: "Virgilio asked: "Are you thinking of this landslide, watched over by the angry monster that I have just appeased"

Original: Or vo’ che sappi che l’altra fïata ch’i’ discesi qua giù nel basso inferno, questa roccia non era ancor cascata
Translate: "Now I want you to know that when this time I went all the way down to Hell, the rock hadn't collapsed yet."

Original: Ma certo poco pria, se ben discerno, che venisse colui che la gran preda levò a Dite del cerchio superno,  da tutte parti l’alta valle feda tremò sì, ch’i’ pensai che l’universo sentisse amor, per lo qual è chi creda  più volte il mondo in caòsso converso
Translate: "If before, as I believe I understood, came the One who drew from the First Circle the spirits of the patriarchs, a fearsome tremble crossed the deep and smelling valley and I thought that even the Universe felt such love as to lead some to believe that the world was repeatedly converting into chaos."

Original: e in quel punto questa vecchia roccia, qui e altrove, tal fece riverso
Translate: "In that moment, the old rock, both here and elsewhere, fell to the ground."

Original: Ma ficca li occhi a valle, ché s’approccia la riviera del sangue in la qual bolle qual che per vïolenza in altrui noccia"
Translate: "But look downstream, for the stream of blood that boils up of those who do violence to others is approaching."

Original: Oh cieca cupidigia e ira folle, che sì ci sproni ne la vita corta, e ne l’etterna poi sì mal c’immolle
Translate: "The blind greed and mad anger that torment us during our short existence, give life to a descent into eternity so painful."

Original: Io vidi un’ampia fossa in arco torta, come quella che tutto ’l piano abbraccia, secondo ch’avea detto la mia scorta
Translate: "I watched a large half moon moon moat embracing the flat area, just as my guide predicted."

Original: e tra ’l piè de la ripa ed essa, in traccia corrien centauri, armati di saette, come solien nel mondo andare a caccia
Translate: "Between the stony and the moat, a row of centaurs armed with bows and arrows was crossing, just as was the practice in the world of hunting."

Original: Veggendoci calar, ciascun ristette, e de la schiera tre si dipartiro con archi e asticciuole prima elette
Translate: "As we descended, three people separated from the group, armed with the bows and arrows they had previously chosen."

Original: e l’un gridò da lungi: "A qual martiro venite voi che scendete la costa? Ditel costinci se non, l’arco tiro"
Translate: "From afar it was heard shouting: "What is the reason why you descend down the descent? Tell us, otherwise an arrow will strike you"."

Original: Lo mio maestro disse: "La risposta farem noi a Chirón costà di presso: mal fu la voglia tua sempre sì tosta"
Translate: "The teacher said to him, "When we are near Chiron, we will give him the answer; it is a sin that you have always acted with impulse and put yourself in trouble."

Original: Poi mi tentò, e disse: "Quelli è Nesso, che morì per la bella Deianira, e fé di sé la vendetta elli stesso
Translate: "Then Virgilio shook my arm and exclaimed: "Here is Nesso, the warrior who fell because of the beautiful Deianira but who found his own vengeance."

Translate: "After fucking the big mouth, he asked his friends: "Did you realize that? The one behind is doing something that touches. The feet of the deceased do not normally move like this"

Translate: "My good teacher, who was already one step away from the place where the two essences were in one, replied: "Surely Dante is alive and he alone must be the one to see the dark valley"."

Translate: "necessity leads him to come, not choice."

Translate: "Chirone turned his head to the right and said to Nesso: "Return, and guide them, set aside those who may hinder you."

Original: quivi è Alessandro, e Dïonisio fero che fé Cicilia aver dolorosi anni

Translate: The dark-haired goddamn guy is Ezzelino.

Translate: "Obizzo d'Este, the blond, unfortunately met his end because of the killing by the stepson in earthly life."

Translate: "The poet looked at me, and declared: "Make me a guide first, I will follow afterward."

Translate: Immediately after the centaur he encountered condemned men who seemed to spring from the depths of hell to the throat.

Translate: Then I saw convicts who kept their heads and thorax out of the river's waters.

Translate: of these I identify several

Translate: "At that point, the number of goddamn feet melted by heat decreased more and more."

Original: e quindi fu del fosso il nostro passo

Translate: The centaur claimed that from his position he could see how the level of the bulicame gradually decreased.

Translate: "I would like you to believe that as it flows further down the river, the bottom gradually decreases to the point where the despots groan."

Translate: "Divine justice inflicts punishment on Attila, the one who has sown destruction and terror on Earth, as well as on Pyrrhus and Sixth."

Original: e in etterno munge  le lagrime, che col bollor diserra, a Rinier da Corneto, a Rinier Pazzo, che fecero a le strade tanta guerra"
Translate: "Rinieri da Corneto and Rinieri dei Pazzi, who had caused many wars in the region, shed rivers of boiling tears that would never cease."

Original: Poi si rivolse e ripassossi ’l guazzo
Translate: "He turned around, going back to cross the swamp again."

Original: Non era ancor di là Nesso arrivato, quando noi ci mettemmo per un bosco che da neun sentiero era segnato
Translate: "Despite the fact that Nesso had not yet reached the other shore, we decided to enter a forest without paths."

Original: Non fronda verde, ma di color fosco
Translate: The leaves did not have a green hue but were of a dark colour.

Original: non rami schietti, ma nodosi e ’nvolti
Translate: "The ramifications were not smooth, but nodated and twisted."

Original: non pomi v’eran, ma stecchi con tòsco
Translate: "there was no fruit present, only poisonous thorns."

Original: Non han sì aspri sterpi né sì folti quelle fiere selvagge che ’n odio hanno tra Cecina e Corneto i luoghi cólti
Translate: "Those ferocious animals that are kept away from the inhabited places along the strip of land between Cecina and Corneto in the Maremma, do not have at their disposal such an intricate and dense undergrowth."

Original: fanno lamenti in su li alberi strani
Translate: Moaning The Strange Trees

Translate: "Before entering the forest, the master said to me, "Remember that we are in the Second Girone and we will stay there until we are in the fiery sand."

Translate: "So be careful, because you'll see things you couldn't believe if you only described them in words."

Translate: "I felt a chorus of groans coming from all directions, but I couldn't see who was issuing them."

Original: per ch’io tutto smarrito m’arrestai
Translate: "I went down a little tone, surprised"

Translate: "I think Virgilio thought I imagined so many voices coming out of those bushes, expression of souls that remained hidden from us."

Original: Però disse ’l maestro: "Se tu tronchi qualche fraschetta d’una d’este piante, li pensier c’ hai si faran tutti monchi"
Translate: "The teacher said that if you broke some branch from one of those plants, your thoughts would become meaningless."

Original: Allor porsi la mano un poco avante e colsi un ramicel da un gran pruno
Translate: Then he stretched out his hand slightly and cut off a twig from a big plum.

Original: e ’l tronco suo gridò: "Perché mi schiante?"

Translate: "After she lost a great deal of blood, she began to beg: "Why do you keep tormenting me? Do you have no compassion?"

Original: Uomini fummo, e or siam fatti sterpi: ben dovrebb’esser la tua man più pia, se state fossimo anime di serpi"
Translate: "As men, we are now reduced to bushes; your mercy would be more generous if we had been souls of serpent."

Original: sì de la scheggia rotta usciva insieme parole e sangue

Original: ond’io lasciai la cima cadere, e stetti come l’uom che teme

Original: E ’l tronco: "Sì col dolce dir m’adeschi, ch’i’ non posso tacere
Translate: "You hypnotized me with your sweet words, which prevent me from remaining silent."

Original: e voi non gravi perch’ïo un poco a ragionar m’inveschi
Translate: And it's not annoying to you if I take some time to talk about myself.

Translate: "As the owner of the two keys that opened the heart of Frederick II, I managed to keep his secrets mostly inaccessible through the skill with which I manipulated them."

Original: fede portai al glorïoso offizio, tanto ch’i’ ne perde’ li sonni e ’ polsi
Translate: "I kept my high mandate with absolute dedication, even sacrificing peace and my own life."

Translate: "The prostitute, who has always had a dissolute look at the emperor's palace and the vice of the courts, died with all prejudices directed against me."

Original: e li ’nfiammati infiammar sì Augusto, che ’ lieti onor tornaro in tristi lutti
Translate: "The success they achieved with the emperor filled him with enthusiasm, to the point of making me fall into a deep sadness."

Original: L’animo mio, per disdegnoso gusto, credendo col morir fuggir disdegno, ingiusto fece me contra me giusto
Translate: "My spirit, driven by deep sorrow, thinking of avoiding shame by death, led me to be unjust to myself, while I had no guilt."

Original: Per le nove radici d’esto legno vi giuro che già mai non ruppi fede al mio segnor, che fu d’onor sì degno
Translate: "I swear that I have never failed to be loyal to my lord, so worthy of respect, for the new roots of this tree."

Original: E se di voi alcun nel mondo riede, conforti la memoria mia, che giace ancor del colpo che ’nvidia le diede"
Translate: "If any of you return to our world, ask that my memory be restored, still marked by the injuries caused by envy."

Original: Un poco attese, e poi "Da ch’el si tace", disse ’l poeta a me, "non perder l’ora
Translate: "Virgilio remained silent for a few moments, except then say: "If you keep your mouth sewn, don't waste time."

Original: ma parla, e chiedi a lui, se più ti piace"
Translate: Ask a question and wait for the answer.

Original: Ond’ïo a lui: "Domandal tu ancora di quel che credi ch’a me satisfaccia

Original: ch’i’ non potrei, tanta pietà m’accora"
Translate: I can't control my tension.

Translate: "Virgilio then resumed: "That what your words have begged may occur, you locked up spirit: I beseech you again to reveal to us how the soul joins these carcasses."

Original: e dinne, se tu puoi, s’alcuna mai di tai membra si spiega"
Translate: "Ask us, if that's possible, if there's ever been a case of someone who managed to get rid of these plants."

Original: Allor soffiò il tronco forte, e poi si convertì quel vento in cotal voce: "Brievemente sarà risposto a voi
Translate: "The tree whispered with force, then his words resonated in the air: "I will give you a brief answer"

Original: Quando si parte l’anima feroce dal corpo ond’ella stessa s’è disvelta, Minòs la manda a la settima foce
Translate: "of HellWhen the fiera soul departs from the body to which it has made the final farewell, Minos has destined it to the seventh Bolgia of Hades."

Original: Cade in la selva, e non l’è parte scelta
Translate: You get lost in the jungle without getting to your destination.

Original: ma là dove fortuna la balestra, quivi germoglia come gran di spelta
Translate: "Where destiny condemns it, there it blooms like a grain of wheat."

Original: Surge in vermena e in pianta silvestra: l’Arpie, pascendo poi de le sue foglie, fanno dolore, e al dolor fenestra
Translate: "The Harpie nourishes of its leaves, growing like a wild shrub, which triggers pain and allows the aforementioned to escape."

Original: Come l’altre verrem per nostre spoglie, ma non però ch’alcuna sen rivesta, ché non è giusto aver ciò ch’om si toglie
Translate: "We will not get back what we have left, for like the other souls we will go and take our bodies not to dress again but only for justified reasons."

Original: Qui le strascineremo, e per la mesta selva saranno i nostri corpi appesi, ciascuno al prun de l’ombra sua molesta"
Translate: "We will be brought here and our bodies will be exposed in the sad forest, each to the tree of his enemy shadow."

Original: Noi eravamo ancora al tronco attesi, credendo ch’altro ne volesse dire,
Translate: "We stood at the foot of the tree, assuming that he could add something more."

Original: quando noi fummo d’un romor sorpresi,  similemente a colui che venire sente ’l porco e la caccia a la sua posta, ch’ode le bestie, e le frasche stormire
Translate: "When there was a sudden noise, like the one that is felt for the approach of a boar and the team of hounds to his pursuit, sensing the barrito of the beasts and the whispering branches of the trees."

Original: Quel dinanzi: "Or accorri, accorri, morte"
Translate: "The being in front was screaming: "Come quickly, help us, run, or die!"

Original: E l’altro, cui pareva tardar troppo, gridava: "Lano, sì non furo accorte  le gambe tue a le giostre dal Toppo"
Translate: "The second, feeling too slow, exclaimed: "Lano, you didn't go so fast to the festivals of Pieve del Toppo!"

Original: E poi che forse li fallia la lena, di sé e d’un cespuglio fece un groppo
Translate: "Because it was airless, it hid by a shrub."

Translate: "Behind them the forest was inhabited by herds of black bitches, who ran hungry like dogs followed by crazy."

Translate: They tore up the miscapitated man who had concealed himself and tore him to pieces.

Original: poi sen portar quelle membra dolenti
Translate: They took his wounds still buttons

Translate: "Then my guide led me through the broken and bloody branches, to the bush that wept in vain."

Translate: ""O Iacopo from St. Andrew, how did you think I would serve you by using me as a shield? What fault do I have of your immoral conduct?"""

Translate: "The teacher immobilized himself before him, asking the question: "What life have you brought in to make so much suffering flow and shed tears so bitter?"

Original: Ed elli a noi: "O anime che giunte siete a veder lo strazio disonesto c’ ha le mie fronde sì da me disgiunte,  raccoglietele al piè del tristo cesto

Original: I’ fui de la città che nel Batista mutò ’l primo padrone
Translate: The first protection of the city was dedicated to St. John the Baptist by me.

Original: ond’ei per questo  sempre con l’arte sua la farà trista
Translate: "always, his art will remind him how sad that moment was"

Translate: "And if it had not been for a rest of his statue, found on the Arno Bridge, the citizens who had dedicated their energy and commitment to rebuild what Attila had destroyed would have been doomed to failure."

Original: Io fei gibetto a me de le mie case"
Translate: I killed myself in my home.

Original: Poi che la carità del natio loco mi strinse, raunai le fronde sparte e rende’ le a colui, ch’era già fioco
Translate: "Love for my land excited me so much that I picked up the scattered branches and brought them to the roots of the tree, where the spirit had abandoned all hope."

Original: Indi venimmo al fine ove si parte lo secondo giron dal terzo, e dove si vede di giustizia orribil arte
Translate: Finally, we reached the place where the second group was divided from the third and were able to observe the terrifying divine punishment.

Original: A ben manifestar le cose nove, dico che arrivammo ad una landa che dal suo letto ogne pianta rimove
Translate: We reached a plain where no vegetation could prosper.

Original: La dolorosa selva l’è ghirlanda intorno, come ’l fosso tristo ad essa
Translate: "Like a Flegeton around his crown, the Jungle of Suicides is her circle."

Original: quivi fermammo i passi a randa a randa
Translate: We supported our steps right on the edge

Original: Lo spazzo era una rena arida e spessa, non d’altra foggia fatta che colei che fu da’ piè di Caton già soppressa
Translate: "The soil was formed by a consistent and dry sand, similar to that trampled on by the footsteps of the great Cato Uticense."

Original: O vendetta di Dio, quanto tu dei esser temuta da ciascun che legge ciò che fu manifesto a li occhi mei
Translate: "Ah, divine justice, what terror must awaken in the readers who listen to what I have seen with my own eyes!"

Original: D’anime nude vidi molte gregge che piangean tutte assai miseramente, e parea posta lor diversa legge
Translate: "I looked at many undressed souls, all crying desperately, and had the impression that each one followed distinctive principles."

Original: Supin giacea in terra alcuna gente, alcuna si sedea tutta raccolta, e altra andava continüamente
Translate: "Some souls were lying on the ground, while others were sitting in recollection and some were still moving unceasingly."

Original: Quella che giva ’ntorno era più molta, e quella men che giacëa al tormento, ma più al duolo avea la lingua sciolta
Translate: "There were more souls running around in circles, but less lying down; yet the ones on the ground complained more."

Original: Sovra tutto ’l sabbion, d’un cader lento, piovean di foco dilatate falde, come di neve in alpe sanza vento
Translate: "The slow rain of fiery sand fell from above, as if they were snowflakes gliding on a mountain without the slightest breath of wind."

Original: Quali Alessandro in quelle parti calde d’Indïa vide sopra ’l süo stuolo fiamme cadere infino a terra salde,
Translate: "Similar to the myth of Alexander the Great, in warm India the hero's troops were amazed at the blazing meteorites rushing to the ground."

Original: per ch’ei provide a scalpitar lo suolo con le sue schiere, acciò che lo vapore mei si stingueva mentre ch’era solo:
Translate: He ordered the soldiers to beat the ground with their boots so that the steam would disperse before it spread.

Original: tale scendeva l’etternale ardore
Translate: Eternal flames spread down.

Original: onde la rena s’accendea, com’esca sotto focile, a doppiar lo dolore
Translate: "As if the ignition of a spark with the flagship increased the pain, the sand itself shone."

Original: Sanza riposo mai era la tresca de le misere mani, or quindi or quinci escotendo da sé l’arsura fresca
Translate: "The poor and exhausted hands did not stop dancing, waving from one side to the other at the sound of the new flame."

Original: I’ cominciai: "Maestro, tu che vinci tutte le cose, fuor che ’ demon duri ch’a l’intrar de la porta incontra uscinci,
Translate: "I began: "Master, you who overcome every obstacle except the difficulties caused by the rebel devils we met on the threshold of the door."

Original: chi è quel grande che non par che curi lo ’ncendio e giace dispettoso e torto, sì che la pioggia non par che ’l marturi?"
Translate: "Who is the great character who lies ignorant in front of the fire, corrupted and alien to the disastrous force of devastation?"

Original: E quel medesmo, che si fu accorto ch’io domandava il mio duca di lui, gridò: "Qual io fui vivo, tal son morto
Translate: "He who had been destined for Hell, understanding the question that I had asked my guide, cried out: "I am still the same damned as when I was alive."

Original: Se Giove stanchi ’l suo fabbro da cui crucciato prese la folgore aguta onde l’ultimo dì percosso fui
Translate: "Even if Jupiter had tired his blacksmith, angry, he would have taken possession of the sharp lightning that struck me on the day of my death."

Original: o s’elli stanchi li altri a muta a muta in Mongibello a la focina negra, chiamando "Buon Vulcano, aiuta, aiuta",
Translate: "The other Cyclops, exhausted from fatigue in Etna, under the dark furnace, called with a loud voice ""Vulcan! Let us pray to you once more, have mercy on us!"

Original: sì com’el fece a la pugna di Flegra, e me saetti con tutta sua forza: non ne potrebbe aver vendetta allegra"
Translate: "As if he had unleashed his fury at the battle of Flegra, he would not be able to take revenge on me."

Original: Allora il duca mio parlò di forza tanto, ch’i’ non l’avea sì forte udito:
Translate: "My teacher had such a loud tone of voice, unlike what I had heard before."

Original: "O Capaneo, in ciò che non s’ammorza  la tua superbia, se’ tu più punito
Translate: "Despite your arrogance has not diminished, Capaneo, you have suffered a more severe punishment."

Original: nullo martiro, fuor che la tua rabbia, sarebbe al tuo furor dolor compito"
Translate: "No punishment could ever be measured by your indignation, except your own heat."

Original: Poi si rivolse a me con miglior labbia, dicendo: "Quei fu l’un d’i sette regi ch’assiser Tebe
Translate: "When he turned to me with greater calm, he told me: "He was one of the seven sovereigns who pressed Thebes."

Original: ed ebbe e par ch’elli abbia  Dio in disdegno, e poco par che ’l pregi
Translate: "and despised God, and it seems that it is still so, as if it did not take into account his power."

Original: ma, com’io dissi lui, li suoi dispetti sono al suo petto assai debiti fregi
Translate: "as I said, his indignation is a decorum for his chest."

Original: Or mi vien dietro, e guarda che non metti, ancor, li piedi ne la rena arsiccia
Translate: Follow me carefully and don't put your feet in the hot sand.

Original: ma sempre al bosco tien li piedi stretti"
Translate: Keep them tight at the forest all the time.

Original: Tacendo divenimmo là ’ve spiccia fuor de la selva un picciol fiumicello, lo cui rossore ancor mi raccapriccia
Translate: "We arrived at the point where at the edge of the forest there was a stream, the memory of its red colour still fills me with disgust."

Original: Quale del Bulicame esce ruscello che parton poi tra lor le peccatrici, tal per la rena giù sen giva quello
Translate: "Along the sand, the river that came from Bulicame flowed as the prostitutes split."

Original: Lo fondo suo e ambo le pendici fatt’era ’n pietra, e ’ margini dallato
Translate: The embankments and the seabed were both built with stone.

Original: per ch’io m’accorsi che ’l passo era lici
Translate: I knew the key to access was there.

Original: "Tra tutto l’altro ch’i’ t’ ho dimostrato, poscia che noi intrammo per la porta lo cui sogliare a nessuno è negato,
Translate: Among all that I have shown you after crossing the infernal threshold whose passage is denied to no one

Original: cosa non fu da li tuoi occhi scorta notabile com’è ’l presente rio, che sovra sé tutte fiammelle ammorta"
Translate: Never before had your eyes encountered something as fascinating as the river that extinguishes in itself all the sparks of the flame.

Original: Queste parole fuor del duca mio
Translate: My guide told me these words.

Original: per ch’io ’l pregai che mi largisse ’l pasto di cui largito m’avëa il disio
Translate: Then I begged him to get me the food that made me want to.

Original: "In mezzo mar siede un paese guasto", diss’elli allora, "che s’appella Creta, sotto ’l cui rege fu già ’l mondo casto
Translate: "He said that in the Mediterranean there was an historical earthly time, Crete was his name, and it is now decrepit. This place was ruled in times past by a king and life here was naive."

Original: Una montagna v’è che già fu lieta d’acqua e di fronde, che si chiamò Ida
Translate: "Once upon a time there was a mountain known as Ida, covered by dense forests and rich in water streams."

Original: or è diserta come cosa vieta
Translate: forgotten as something ancient

Original: Rëa la scelse già per cuna fida del suo figliuolo, e per celarlo meglio, quando piangea, vi facea far le grida
Translate: "Rea chose this place as a refuge for her child, and to further obscure its traces, when she cried she made him scream aloud."

Original: Dentro dal monte sta dritto un gran veglio, che tien volte le spalle inver’ Dammiata e Roma guarda come süo speglio
Translate: "An elder, who turns his back on Damietta, stands inside the mountain, as if Rome were his reflection."

Original: La sua testa è di fin oro formata, e puro argento son le braccia e ’l petto, poi è di rame infino a la forcata
Translate: "His head is made of pure gold, while his arms and chest are made of pure silver. Following then to the groin they turn out to be of copper."

Original: da indi in giuso è tutto ferro eletto, salvo che ’l destro piede è terra cotta
Translate: "From that point on, everything is made of iron except the right foot that is formed by terracotta."

Original: e sta ’n su quel, più che ’n su l’altro, eretto
Translate: is more based on this than on that

Original: Ciascuna parte, fuor che l’oro, è rotta d’una fessura che lagrime goccia, le quali, accolte, fóran quella grotta
Translate: "The statue, except the head, is split by a crack from which tears flow that go to rain on the rock below and gather at the feet."

Original: lor corso in questa valle si diroccia
Translate: A river flows into the hellish abyss.

Original: fanno Acheronte, Stige e Flegetonta
Translate: "they feed the Acheron, feed the Stige, and feed the Flegeton."

Original: poi sen van giù per questa stretta doccia,  infin, là ove più non si dismonta, fanno Cocito
Translate: "They go down the path even more hidden, until you reach the end of the road, where Cocito comes to life."

Original: e qual sia quello stagno tu lo vedrai, però qui non si conta"
Translate: "You can see what that lake refers to, so let's not discuss the subject now."

Original: E io a lui: "Se ’l presente rigagno si diriva così dal nostro mondo, perché ci appar pur a questo vivagno?"
Translate: "I asked him: "Why is it only now, on the edge of the Circle, that we can see this little river if it was born from the earthly world?"."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Tu sai che ’l loco è tondo
Translate: He asked me: "Can you understand that this hole is round?"

Original: e tutto che tu sie venuto molto, pur a sinistra, giù calando al fondo,  non se’ ancor per tutto ’l cerchio vòlto
Translate: "Despite you making good progress on the left, you haven't completed the circle yet."

Original: per che, se cosa n’apparisce nova, non de’ addur maraviglia al tuo volto"
Translate: "If you see an unusual situation, you shouldn't be surprised."

Original: E io ancor: "Maestro, ove si trova Flegetonta e Letè? ché de l’un taci, e l’altro di’ che si fa d’esta piova"
Translate: "I reworded: ""Master, the Flegeton is produced by this rain of tears, but what is the source of the Lete I cannot tell you"""

Original: "In tutte tue question certo mi piaci", rispuose, "ma ’l bollor de l’acqua rossa dovea ben solver l’una che tu faci
Translate: "I love all your questions, but the blood red color of the water should have removed one of your questions."

Original: Letè vedrai, ma fuor di questa fossa, là dove vanno l’anime a lavarsi quando la colpa pentuta è rimossa"
Translate: "You will see the Lete, beyond Hell, where souls go to purify themselves when they have atone for their sins and forsaken them."

Original: Poi disse: "Omai è tempo da scostarsi dal bosco
Translate: "At that point, he suggested heading away from the forest."

Original: fa che di retro a me vegne: li margini fan via, che non son arsi,  e sopra loro ogne vapor si spegne"
Translate: "Follow me along the banks of the river, for they have been preserved by the bursting rain, and all the flashes of fire melt over them."

Original: Ora cen porta l’un de’ duri margini
Translate: The rocky embankment is driving us away from the forest right now.

Original: e ’l fummo del ruscel di sopra aduggia, sì che dal foco salva l’acqua e li argini
Translate: "Flegeton's smoke wraps up water and banks, offering otherwise inaccessible shelter from fire."

Original: Quali Fiamminghi tra Guizzante e Bruggia, temendo ’l fiotto che ’nver’ lor s’avventa, fanno lo schermo perché ’l mar si fuggia
Translate: "Like the Flemish between Wissant and Bruges, fearing that the waves reverberate upon them, they built dams to keep the tide at bay."

Original: e quali Padoan lungo la Brenta, per difender lor ville e lor castelli, anzi che Carentana il caldo senta:
