Translate: The Paduans guarded their cities and castles along the Brenta before Carinthia felt the heat wave.

Original: a tale imagine eran fatti quelli, tutto che né sì alti né sì grossi, qual che si fosse, lo maestro félli
Translate: "The banks had been built this way, even though their creator had no intention of making them so massive and grand."

Original: Già eravam da la selva rimossi tanto, ch’i’ non avrei visto dov’era, perch’io in dietro rivolto mi fossi,
Translate: "We had traveled so far that the forest was out of our sight, even if I had looked back."

Original: quando incontrammo d’anime una schiera che venian lungo l’argine, e ciascuna ci riguardava come suol da sera  guardare uno altro sotto nuova luna
Translate: "when we came across a siege of souls flowing along the embankment, searching with our eyes as if it were a new moon's night."

Original: e sì ver’ noi aguzzavan le ciglia come ’l vecchio sartor fa ne la cruna
Translate: And they looked at us like an old tailor, and put the needle in the eye.

Original: Così adocchiato da cotal famiglia, fui conosciuto da un, che mi prese per lo lembo e gridò: "Qual maraviglia"
Translate: "While the condemned were watching me with surprise, one of them recognized my presence and grabbed my robe exclaiming: "What amazement!"

Original: E io, quando ’l suo braccio a me distese, ficcaï li occhi per lo cotto aspetto, sì che ’l viso abbrusciato non difese  la conoscenza süa al mio ’ntelletto
Translate: "When he held my arm, I stared at his face with such intensity that I recognized him even though he was all burned."

Original: e chinando la mano a la sua faccia, rispuosi: "Siete voi qui, ser Brunetto?"
Translate: "I brought my hand close to his face and said, "Ser Brunetto, is she right here?"

Original: E quelli: "O figliuol mio, non ti dispiaccia se Brunetto Latino un poco teco ritorna ’n dietro e lascia andar la traccia"
Translate: "And he said, "Son, don't take it from me if Brunetto Latini stays behind and lets you go to the head of the torma."

Original: I’ dissi lui: "Quanto posso, ven preco
Translate: I begged him with all my energy.

Original: e se volete che con voi m’asseggia, faròl, se piace a costui che vo seco"
Translate: "If you want me to stay with you, I will if the guide I rely on agrees."

Original: "O figliuol", disse, "qual di questa greggia s’arresta punto, giace poi cent’anni sanz’arrostarsi quando ’l foco il feggia
Translate: "He declared: "My son, if one of this assembly stops even for a moment, he will have to sleep a hundred years without answers when the fire strikes him."

Original: Però va oltre: i’ ti verrò a’ panni
Translate: "I'll keep you behind me, so go ahead."

Original: e poi rigiugnerò la mia masnada, che va piangendo i suoi etterni danni"
Translate: "In the end, I will join my companions who cry desperate for their endless condemnation."

Original: Io non osava scender de la strada per andar par di lui
Translate: I didn't have the courage to go down the bank to join him.

Original: ma ’l capo chino tenea com’uom che reverente vada
Translate: "I held my head bow, as a demonstration of my deep respect"

Original: El cominciò: "Qual fortuna o destino anzi l’ultimo dì qua giù ti mena? e chi è questi che mostra ’l cammino?"
Translate: He began to say, "What brought you down here before you disappeared? And who is this that is driving your journey?"

Original: "Là sù di sopra, in la vita serena", rispuos’io lui, "mi smarri’ in una valle, avanti che l’età mia fosse piena
Translate: "I replied to him: "In a serene existence, I had been lost in a valley before I had reached the maximum of my existence"."

Original: Pur ier mattina le volsi le spalle: questi m’apparve, tornand’ïo in quella, e reducemi a ca per questo calle"
Translate: "Yesterday morning, on my way home, there he came and accompanied me on the way."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Se tu segui tua stella, non puoi fallire a glorïoso porto, se ben m’accorsi ne la vita bella
Translate: ""Following your star, there is no doubt that you will achieve your literary and political goals, as I intuitioned while I was still among you," he said to me."

Original: e s’io non fossi sì per tempo morto, veggendo il cielo a te così benigno, dato t’avrei a l’opera conforto
Translate: "If I had not sadly lost my life at a young age, being destiny so kind to you, I would have been of help to you to carry out your project."

Original: Ma quello ingrato popolo maligno che discese di Fiesole ab antico, e tiene ancor del monte e del macigno,  ti si farà, per tuo ben far, nimico
Translate: "That ancient Fiesolian people, who have preserved the rudeness of the mountaineers, will turn into an enemy for your altruism."

Original: ed è ragion, ché tra li lazzi sorbi si disconvien fruttare al dolce fico
Translate: It is not appropriate for the sweet fig tree to blossom between bitter fruit

Original: Vecchia fama nel mondo li chiama orbi
Translate: A popular saying says they're blind as rats.

Original: gent’è avara, invidiosa e superba: dai lor costumi fa che tu ti forbi
Translate: "Avoid getting involved in their greedy, envious, and proud attitudes."

Original: La tua fortuna tanto onor ti serba, che l’una parte e l’altra avranno fame di te
Translate: "Your prosperity will certainly unleash envy from both sides, and because of your success you will be the object of their hostility."

Original: ma lungi fia dal becco l’erba
Translate: the goat will not be near the grass

Original: Faccian le bestie fiesolane strame di lor medesme, e non tocchin la pianta, s’alcuna surge ancora in lor letame,
Translate: "Fiesole's creatures devour each other and don't touch the plant if it ever blossoms again in their manure."

Original: in cui riviva la sementa santa di que’ Roman che vi rimaser quando fu fatto il nido di malizia tanta"
Translate: "in the places where the spirit of those Romans still resounds, who, when a den of malice was created, chose to remain in Florence."

Original: "Se fosse tutto pieno il mio dimando", rispuos’io lui, "voi non sareste ancora de l’umana natura posto in bando
Translate: "I said to her: "If I had the chance to fulfill all my dreams, you would still be here with us"."

Original: ché ’n la mente m’è fitta, e or m’accora, la cara e buona imagine paterna di voi quando nel mondo ad ora ad ora  m’insegnavate come l’uom s’etterna:
Translate: I remember with great affection the fatherly image of you teaching me how a man can become famous forever.

Original: e quant’io l’abbia in grado, mentr’io vivo convien che ne la mia lingua si scerna
Translate: "As long as I live, my words will express all the joy I feel."

Original: Ciò che narrate di mio corso scrivo, e serbolo a chiosar con altro testo a donna che saprà, s’a lei arrivo
Translate: "I write down everything that has been told about my life, and if I can find a woman able to do so, I will ask her to interpret it together with another prophecy."

Original: Tanto vogl’io che vi sia manifesto, pur che mia coscïenza non mi garra, ch’a la Fortuna, come vuol, son presto
Translate: ""I will do whatever happens, but for myself - without feeling guilty"."

Original: Non è nuova a li orecchi miei tal arra: però giri Fortuna la sua rota come le piace, e ’l villan la sua marra"
Translate: "Such prophecy is not new to my ears; therefore, let luck turn as it pleases and the peasant maneuver his hoe."

Original: Lo mio maestro allora in su la gota destra si volse in dietro e riguardommi
Translate: "My teacher, turning his head to the right, looked at me then."

Original: poi disse: "Bene ascolta chi la nota"
Translate: He is said to be a good listener who remembers the things he is told.

Original: Né per tanto di men parlando vommi con ser Brunetto, e dimando chi sono li suoi compagni più noti e più sommi
Translate: "Despite this, I kept talking to Ser Brunetto and asked him who his most significant companions were in condemnation."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Saper d’alcuno è buono
Translate: "He said to me, "Know some of them is important.""

Original: de li altri fia laudabile tacerci, ché ’l tempo saria corto a tanto suono
Translate: "It would be better not to talk about others, for it would take too long to list them all."

Original: In somma sappi che tutti fur cherci e litterati grandi e di gran fama, d’un peccato medesmo al mondo lerci
Translate: "These were great letters of fame, as well as important clerics; yet their lives were stained by the same sin."

Original: Priscian sen va con quella turba grama, e Francesco d’Accorso anche
Translate: "Prisciano joins the troop of ugly men, as well as Francesco d'Accorso."

Original: e vedervi, s’avessi avuto di tal tigna brama,  colui potei che dal servo de’ servi fu trasmutato d’Arno in Bacchiglione, dove lasciò li mal protesi nervi
Translate: "If you have the desire to see a shabby figure, you could look at those whom the servant of the servants brought from Florence to Vicenza and subsequently breathed away leaving his wandering character as a legacy."

Original: Di più direi
Translate: I could tell you more.

Original: ma ’l venire e ’l sermone più lungo esser non può, però ch’i’ veggio là surger nuovo fummo del sabbione
Translate: "since the smoke of the sand is rising, we can no longer go down the road or continue the conversation."

Original: Gente vien con la quale esser non deggio
Translate: I don't have to join the group of souls that are coming.

Original: Sieti raccomandato il mio Tesoro, nel qual io vivo ancora, e più non cheggio"
Translate: "I recommend you keep my treasure, a great symbol of my fame, and I have no other demands."

Original: Poi si rivolse, e parve di coloro che corrono a Verona il drappo verde per la campagna
Translate: "It turned around, as one of the participants in the palio race that takes place annually in the Verona countryside for the green drape."

Original: e parve di costoro  quelli che vince, non colui che perde
Translate: "he seemed to have won, not lost."

Original: Già era in loco onde s’udia ’l rimbombo de l’acqua che cadea ne l’altro giro, simile a quel che l’arnie fanno rombo,
Translate: "I was already at a point where one could hear the echo of the water falling into the Circle below, similar to the buzz of the bees inside the arnia."

Original: quando tre ombre insieme si partiro, correndo, d’una torma che passava sotto la pioggia de l’aspro martiro
Translate: "Three souls were divided among a crowd that, under the hostile rain of fire, was advancing along the road in running."

Original: Venian ver’ noi, e ciascuna gridava: "Sòstati tu ch’a l’abito ne sembri essere alcun di nostra terra prava"
Translate: "They proceeded toward us and each one exclaimed: "Halte-there, you who look like a fellow countryman of our dishonest homeland."

Original: Ahimè, che piaghe vidi ne’ lor membri, ricenti e vecchie, da le fiamme incese
Translate: "Oh, what wounds I saw on their bodies, both recent and historically dated, caused by the glowing flames."

Original: Ancor men duol pur ch’i’ me ne rimembri
Translate: "I sadly remember this even today, just thinking about it."

Original: A le lor grida il mio dottor s’attese
Translate: "To their cries, the teacher of whom I was a pupil stopped."

Original: volse ’l viso ver’ me, e "Or aspetta", disse, "a costor si vuole esser cortese
Translate: She looked at me and said, "We must be kind to these wretched people."

Original: E se non fosse il foco che saetta la natura del loco, i’ dicerei che meglio stesse a te che a lor la fretta"
Translate: "If it weren't for the rain that fills this place with heat, I could tell you for sure that you're faster than they are."

Original: Ricominciar, come noi restammo, ei l’antico verso
Translate: "As soon as our conversation broke down, they kept chatting like before."

Original: e quando a noi fuor giunti, fenno una rota di sé tutti e trei
Translate: "When they reached each other, all three began to form a circle walking."

Original: Qual sogliono i campion far nudi e unti, avvisando lor presa e lor vantaggio, prima che sien tra lor battuti e punti,
Translate: "The ancient fighters used to examine their opponents, sprinkled with oil and naked, before clashing with attempts to seize and inflict mutual wounds."

Original: così rotando, ciascuno il visaggio drizzava a me, sì che ’n contraro il collo faceva ai piè continüo vïaggio
Translate: "turning his head to the right and left, each of the three damned torches his neck in the opposite direction to his own steps as he stared at me with his gaze."

Original: E "Se miseria d’esto loco sollo rende in dispetto noi e nostri prieghi", cominciò l’uno, "e ’l tinto aspetto e brollo,
Translate: "If the ugliness of the desolate landscape and our sun - burned robes arouse contempt for us and in the words that run away from our mouths,"

Original: la fama nostra il tuo animo pieghi a dirne chi tu se’, che i vivi piedi così sicuro per lo ’nferno freghi
Translate: "despite our reputation, show us who you are as you sail so safely into Hell."

Original: Questi, l’orme di cui pestar mi vedi, tutto che nudo e dipelato vada, fu di grado maggior che tu non credi:
Translate: "Even though this person, whom you see below my feet, is devoid of goods and clothing, he has had a higher rank than you might think."

Original: nepote fu de la buona Gualdrada
Translate: "was Gualdrada's niece, a valiant woman"

Original: Guido Guerra ebbe nome, e in sua vita fece col senno assai e con la spada
Translate: "The illustrious Guido Guerra, known for his extraordinary works realized through wisdom and war skills, gained notoriety during his life."

Original: L’altro, ch’appresso me la rena trita, è Tegghiaio Aldobrandi, la cui voce nel mondo sù dovria esser gradita
Translate: ". Aldobrandi, who is walking behind me in the sand, should have been more respected all over the world."

Original: E io, che posto son con loro in croce, Iacopo Rusticucci fui,
Translate: "I, who understood their suffering, was Iacopo Rusticucci."

Original: e certo la fiera moglie più ch’altro mi nuoce"
Translate: My intractable wife was my greatest misfortune.

Original: S’i’ fossi stato dal foco coperto, gittato mi sarei tra lor di sotto, e credo che ’l dottor l’avria sofferto
Translate: "If I had a barrier of protection from flames, I would have thrown myself into the sandbox and I think the master would have accepted it."

Original: ma perch’io mi sarei brusciato e cotto, vinse paura la mia buona voglia che di loro abbracciar mi facea ghiotto
Translate: The fear of being burned has led me to give up my desire to embrace them.

Original: Poi cominciai: "Non dispetto, ma doglia la vostra condizion dentro mi fisse, tanta che tardi tutta si dispoglia,
Translate: "By starting I felt sadness instead of disdain for you, so soon as I disappeared."

Original: tosto che questo mio segnor mi disse parole per le quali i’ mi pensai che qual voi siete, tal gente venisse
Translate: "Since the moment my teacher told me that friendly people like you would arrive, I thought noble people had arrived."

Original: Di vostra terra sono, e sempre mai l’ovra di voi e li onorati nomi con affezion ritrassi e ascoltai
Translate: "I have always had great respect for your works and honorable names, being of Florence."

Original: Lascio lo fele e vo per dolci pomi promessi a me per lo verace duca
Translate: I turn away from an adverse existence and seek the help that my trusted guide had assured me.

Original: ma ’nfino al centro pria convien ch’i’ tomi"
Translate: I have to go down to the depths of Hell first.

Original: "Se lungamente l’anima conduca le membra tue", rispuose quelli ancora, "e se la fama tua dopo te luca,
Translate: "May your life continue, and you may enjoy a famous immortality after death."

Original: cortesia e valor dì se dimora ne la nostra città sì come suole, o se del tutto se n’è gita fora
Translate: "We want to know if courtesy and value can still be found in our city, or if they have been totally abandoned."

Original: ché Guiglielmo Borsiere, il qual si duole con noi per poco e va là coi compagni, assai ne cruccia con le sue parole"
Translate: "Guglielmo Borsiere, who recently joined our group, gives us some relief when he talks about his Florence as he wanders among us."

Original: "La gente nuova e i sùbiti guadagni orgoglio e dismisura han generata, Fiorenza, in te, sì che tu già ten piagni"
Translate: "The new people who live in the city and the sudden profits have caused in you, Florence, a magniloquity and exaggeration to the point of making you mourn the consequences."

Original: Così gridai con la faccia levata
Translate: I lifted up my face and cried loudly

Original: e i tre, che ciò inteser per risposta, guardar l’un l’altro com’al ver si guata
Translate: "The three, reading my answer, stared at each other as if they had discovered something unpleasant."

Original: "Se l’altre volte sì poco ti costa", rispuoser tutti, "il satisfare altrui, felice te se sì parli a tua posta
Translate: "Everyone replied in the affirmative to the hypothesis that it was a small effort for the demands of others, and expressed a loud appreciation for the capacity of the person in question to report immediately."

Original: Però, se campi d’esti luoghi bui e torni a riveder le belle stelle, quando ti gioverà dicere "I’ fui",  fa che di noi a la gente favelle"
Translate: "When you return under the stars and want to share your experience in Hell, tell others what we have experienced."

Original: Indi rupper la rota, e a fuggirsi ali sembiar le gambe loro isnelle
Translate: So they moved in a straight line so quickly that they seemed to have developed wings from their slender legs.

Original: Un amen non saria possuto dirsi tosto così com’e’ fuoro spariti
Translate: "It was not possible to say an "amen" before they disappeared."

Original: per ch’al maestro parve di partirsi
Translate: The teacher thought it advisable for us to go farther.

Original: Io lo seguiva, e poco eravam iti, che ’l suon de l’acqua n’era sì vicino, che per parlar saremmo a pena uditi
Translate: "I was following him, and we still hadn't come a long way when the sound of the water was so close that if we had spoken they would have just been perceptible."

Original: Come quel fiume c’ ha proprio cammino prima dal Monte Viso ’nver’ levante, da la sinistra costa d’Apennino,
Translate: "Like a stream that begins its path from the Monviso, north of the Apennines chain, advancing east."

Original: che si chiama Acquacheta suso, avante che si divalli giù nel basso letto, e a Forlì di quel nome è vacante,
Translate: "From Acquacheta, the watercourse rises to the heights and then descends to the plain and change name to Forlì."

Original: rimbomba là sovra San Benedetto de l’Alpe per cadere ad una scesa ove dovea per mille esser recetto
Translate: It resounds above San Benedetto dell'Alpe before gathering in a unique stream of water where otherwise it would be welcomed by thousands of small waterfalls.

Original: così, giù d’una ripa discoscesa, trovammo risonar quell’acqua tinta, sì che ’n poc’ora avria l’orecchia offesa
Translate: "We continued that the red river fell into a steep abyss, with such a noise that it could soon harm the hearing."

Original: Io avea una corda intorno cinta, e con essa pensai alcuna volta prender la lonza a la pelle dipinta
Translate: "I had tied a rope around my life, with which I had previously thought to take the spotted animal."

Original: Poscia ch’io l’ebbi tutta da me sciolta, sì come ’l duca m’avea comandato, porsila a lui aggroppata e ravvolta
Translate: "Once I loosened it, according to Virgil's instructions, I wrapped it tightly and gave it to him."

Original: Ond’ei si volse inver’ lo destro lato, e alquanto di lunge da la sponda la gittò giuso in quell’alto burrato
Translate: "So, keeping away from the edge of the slope, he threw it down into the deep abyss to his right."

Original: ’E’ pur convien che novità risponda’, dicea fra me medesmo, ’al novo cenno che ’l maestro con l’occhio sì seconda’
Translate: "While I thought for myself, it was obvious that something innovative had to join the signal of my driving, so carefully observed."

Original: Ahi quanto cauti li uomini esser dienno presso a color che non veggion pur l'ovra, ma per entro i pensier miran col senno
Translate: "Oh how cautious men should be when they are in the presence of people who are not able to read only the actions but are endowed with the gift of investigating the most hidden thoughts."

Original: El disse a me: "Tosto verrà di sovra ciò ch’io attendo e che il tuo pensier sogna
Translate: "While we were talking, he said that what I was waiting for and imagining would come soon."

Original: tosto convien ch’al tuo viso si scovra"
Translate: Meeting with your pupils is now near.

Original: Sempre a quel ver c' ha faccia di menzogna de' l'uom chiuder le labbra fin ch'el puote, però che sanza colpa fa vergogna
Translate: "Man must always refrain from presenting as truth something that can be perceived as false, in order not to incur the suspicion of lies."

Original: ma qui tacer nol posso
Translate: I can't help talking here.

Original: e per le note di questa comedìa, lettor, ti giuro, s’elle non sien di lunga grazia vòte,
Translate: "I, as a reader, promise to stick to the words contained in this Comedy"

Original: ch’i’ vidi per quell’ aere grosso e scuro venir notando una figura in suso, maravigliosa ad ogne cor sicuro,
Translate: "A figure approached floating in the dense and dark air, an event that would arouse astonishment even in the most courageous heart."

Original: sì come torna colui che va giuso talora a solver l’àncora ch’aggrappa o scoglio o altro che nel mare è chiuso,  che ’n sù si stende e da piè si rattrappa
Translate: "Like the sailor who plunges into the sea to untie the stuck anchor or remove any obstacle, he stretches his arms upward and lowers his legs."

Original: "Ecco la fiera con la coda aguzza, che passa i monti e rompe i muri e l'armi
Translate: "Here is the fair with its sharp tail, which winds through the mountains and breaks down walls and barricades."

Original: Ecco colei che tutto 'l mondo appuzza"
Translate: "Look at it there, it's smelling so pungent that it clouds every other scent on the planet."

Original: Sì cominciò lo mio duca a parlarmi
Translate: My teacher began to speak to me

Original: e accennolle che venisse a proda, vicino al fin d’i passeggiati marmi
Translate: "He hinted at the monster to approach the end of the Circle, near the stony."

Original: E quella sozza imagine di froda sen venne, e arrivò la testa e ’l busto, ma ’n su la riva non trasse la coda
Translate: "The dirty photo of cheating approached, causing the head and trunk to sprout but keeping the tail well away from the edge."

Original: La faccia sua era faccia d’uom giusto, tanto benigna avea di fuor la pelle, e d’un serpente tutto l’altro fusto
Translate: "He had a reassuring appearance, which allowed him to glimpse the traits of a righteous man, while the rest of the body was that of a serpent."

Original: due branche avea pilose insin l’ascelle
Translate: On his hairy body there were two legs that came up close to the armpits.

Original: lo dosso e ’l petto e ambedue le coste dipinti avea di nodi e di rotelle
Translate: The back and front of the body were both painted with drawings of knots and circles.

Original: Con più color, sommesse e sovraposte non fer mai drappi Tartari né Turchi, né fuor tai tele per Aragne imposte
Translate: "The Tartars and the Turks have never been able to produce fabrics with a wealth of colors, patterns in relief and in the background as Aracne ever created."

Original: Come talvolta stanno a riva i burchi, che parte sono in acqua e parte in terra, e come là tra li Tedeschi lurchi  lo bivero s’assetta a far sua guerra,
Translate: "Sometimes, like a beaver lurking to catch the prey among the good Germans, so some caterpillars keep part of their barge in the water and part on the shore."

Original: così la fiera pessima si stava su l’orlo ch’è di pietra e ’l sabbion serra
Translate: Thus the horrible creature stood firm in front of a stone barrier that girded the sandbell.

Original: Nel vano tutta sua coda guizzava, torcendo in sù la venenosa forca ch’a guisa di scorpion la punta armava
Translate: "His tail moved slightly in the vastness of the void, wielding high the menacing scissors that loomed like the sting of a scorpion."

Original: Lo duca disse: "Or convien che si torca la nostra via un poco insino a quella bestia malvagia che colà si corca"
Translate: "The master suggested that I go a little off the road to that evil creature, huddled in the distance."

Original: Però scendemmo a la destra mammella, e diece passi femmo in su lo stremo, per ben cessar la rena e la fiammella
Translate: "So we descended from the river bank on the right side, and walked with caution for ten steps along the margin of depression, careful to dodge the sand and the rains of fire."

Original: E quando noi a lei venuti semo, poco più oltre veggio in su la rena gente seder propinqua al loco scemo
Translate: "When we arrived at her, I saw the condemned sitting in the sand, near the edge of the precipice not far."

Original: Quivi ’l maestro "Acciò che tutta piena esperïenza d’esto giron porti", mi disse, "va, e vedi la lor mena
Translate: "The teacher suggested that in order to complete my experience in this group, I should go and see how they faced their punishment."

Original: Li tuoi ragionamenti sian là corti
Translate: Don't get too long in your speeches.

Original: mentre che torni, parlerò con questa, che ne conceda i suoi omeri forti"
Translate: "While I await your arrival, I will try to persuade the beast to give us a ride on its strong shoulders."

Original: Così ancor su per la strema testa di quel settimo cerchio tutto solo andai, dove sedea la gente mesta
Translate: "Guided by despair, I proceeded to the extreme borders of the VII Hell Circle, where the condemned poor people were forced to suffer eternal torture."

Original: Per li occhi fora scoppiava lor duolo
Translate: Suffering was evident from their pupils.

Original: di qua, di là soccorrien con le mani quando a’ vapori, e quando al caldo suolo:
Translate: They tried to shelter themselves from the glowing rain and the burning sand by using their hands.

Original: non altrimenti fan di state i cani or col ceffo or col piè, quando son morsi o da pulci o da mosche o da tafani
Translate: "The dogs, with the snout and with the paw, when they are stinged by fleas, flies or tafani do no different in summer."

Original: Poi che nel viso a certi li occhi porsi, ne’ quali ’l doloroso foco casca, non ne conobbi alcun
Translate: "After searching the faces of some of them, who suffered the fury of the flames, I couldn't identify any of them."

Original: ma io m’accorsi  che dal collo a ciascun pendea una tasca ch’avea certo colore e certo segno, e quindi par che ’l loro occhio si pasca
Translate: "I saw that everyone was hanging a bag around his neck, of which a colour and a mark stood out; and it appeared as if their eyes were nourishing from it."

Original: E com’io riguardando tra lor vegno, in una borsa gialla vidi azzurro che d’un leone avea faccia e contegno
Translate: "While I was looking at them, I noticed a blue lion-shaped figure on a yellow purse that emanated great royalty."

Original: Poi, procedendo di mio sguardo il curro, vidine un’altra come sangue rossa, mostrando un’oca bianca più che burro
Translate: "By directing my gaze further away, I saw another blood-red structure with the shape of a goose with the most intense white of butter."

Original: E un che d’una scrofa azzurra e grossa segnato avea lo suo sacchetto bianco, mi disse: "Che fai tu in questa fossa?  Or te ne va
Translate: "!A damned man, with a white bag depicting a huge blue sow, apostrophe me: "What are you doing here in this Hell? Get out of here!"

Original: e perché se’ vivo anco, sappi che ’l mio vicin Vitalïano sederà qui dal mio sinistro fianco
Translate: "Being Vitalian of the Tooth still alive, he will soon be sitting on my left."

Original: Con questi Fiorentin son padoano: spesse fïate mi ’ntronan li orecchi gridando: "Vegna ’l cavalier sovrano,  che recherà la tasca con tre becchi"
Translate: "I, originally from Padua, am here among the Florentines and often hear their screams in my ears invoking: "Let the noble knight come with the bag of the three goats"."

Original: Qui distorse la bocca e di fuor trasse la lingua, come bue che ’l naso lecchi
Translate: "At that point he made a smile and pulled out his tongue, as if it were an ox licking his nose."

Original: E io, temendo no ’l più star crucciasse lui che di poco star m’avea ’mmonito, torna’ mi in dietro da l’anime lasse
Translate: "I was afraid that staying longer might irritate the one who warned me not to stop, so I went away from those melancholy souls."

Original: Trova’ il duca mio ch’era salito già su la groppa del fiero animale, e disse a me: "Or sie forte e ardito
Translate: "I found my master riding the formidable quadruped, and he urged me: "Don't be afraid; show courage!"

Original: Omai si scende per sì fatte scale
Translate: We must proceed in this way.

Original: monta dinanzi, ch’i’ voglio esser mezzo, sì che la coda non possa far male"
Translate: "Get down between me and the tail, so that I can protect you from any danger."

Original: Qual è colui che sì presso ha ’l riprezzo de la quartana, c’ ha già l’unghie smorte, e triema tutto pur guardando ’l rezzo,  tal divenn’io a le parole porte
Translate: "As someone who is near the terror of being struck by the fourth fever with nails similar to those of the dead and trembles alone in the shadows, so I became hearing those words."

Original: ma vergogna mi fé le sue minacce, che innanzi a buon segnor fa servo forte
Translate: "My shame obstructed my courage in front of a good master, threatening me."

Original: I’ m’assettai in su quelle spallacce
Translate: I took a stand on those horrible shoulders.

Original: sì volli dir, ma la voce non venne com’io credetti: ’Fa che tu m’abbracce’
Translate: I couldn't say "Hug me strong" to Virgil as I wanted.

Original: Ma esso, ch’altra volta mi sovvenne ad altro forse, tosto ch’i’ montai con le braccia m’avvinse e mi sostenne
Translate: "Virgilio, who had already given me a hand in the past, tight in his arms supported me as soon as I went up."

Original: e disse: "Gerïon, moviti omai: le rote larghe, e lo scender sia poco
Translate: "Jerion, the hour has come for a rotating flight; come down slowly and gently, while you make big circles in the air."

Original: pensa la nova soma che tu hai"
Translate: Pay attention to the load you carry and you're not used to handling.

Original: Come la navicella esce di loco in dietro in dietro, sì quindi si tolse
Translate: "of the cliffThe ship that moving away following the opposite of the direction of the journey, was corresponding to the way in which Gerion was subtracting itself from the cliff."

Original: e poi ch’al tutto si sentì a gioco,  là ’v’era ’l petto, la coda rivolse, e quella tesa, come anguilla, mosse, e con le branche l’aere a sé raccolse
Translate: "As soon as he felt comfortable, he rotated the body where the tail was before and began to swing like a fish, pushing his hairy legs into the air to swim."

Original: Maggior paura non credo che fosse quando Fetonte abbandonò li freni, per che ’l ciel, come pare ancor, si cosse
Translate: "Despite the fact that Fetonte did not seem scared anymore when he dropped the reins, the sky inflamed immediately."

Original: né quando Icaro misero le reni sentì spennar per la scaldata cera, gridando il padre a lui "Mala via tieni",
Translate: "He could come down more Poor Icarus, while he felt the overheated wax that melted his feathers from his back, heard his father screaming, "You're making a mistake!" but he didn't have a chance to go back."

Original: che fu la mia, quando vidi ch’i’ era ne l’aere d’ogne parte, e vidi spenta ogne veduta fuor che de la fera
Translate: that had eyes like burning coalsI was tremendously afraid when I found myself surrounded by nothing but the air and saw the beast with bright eyes like briars.

Original: Ella sen va notando lenta lenta
Translate: She was advancing at a slow pace in the water.

Original: rota e discende, ma non me n’accorgo se non che al viso e di sotto mi venta
Translate: "While it was spinning up and down, the wind hit my face and I could feel it under my legs."

Original: Io sentia già da la man destra il gorgo far sotto noi un orribile scroscio, per che con li occhi ’n giù la testa sporgo
Translate: "Already from the right I felt the horrible noise of the waterfall falling under us, so I lowered my head and looked."

Original: Allor fu’ io più timido a lo stoscio, però ch’i’ vidi fuochi e senti’ pianti
Translate: I was terribly worried about falling because I noticed flames and heard wailing.

Original: ond’io tremando tutto mi raccoscio
Translate: "then, my legs folded on my chest waiting, I was paralyzed by fear."

Original: E vidi poi, ché nol vedea davanti, lo scendere e ’l girar per li gran mali che s’appressavan da diversi canti
Translate: "I could no longer fail to see what was happening: we were going downhill and turning on ourselves, while the terrible punishments inflicted on those who are condemned approached from all sides."

Original: Come ’l falcon ch’è stato assai su l’ali, che sanza veder logoro o uccello fa dire al falconiere "Omè, tu cali",
Translate: "As the falcon who had gone away without identifying a prey or another bird, the falconer lamented: "Oh, you must return!."

Original: discende lasso onde si move isnello, per cento rote, e da lunge si pone dal suo maestro, disdegnoso e fello
Translate: "It flies in the air 100 times, then glides away from the owner, with irritation and bad mood. Tired gets off where it started agilely."

Original: così ne puose al fondo Gerïone al piè al piè de la stagliata rocca, e, discarcate le nostre persone,  si dileguò come da corda cocca
Translate: "Jerion dumped us at the bottom of that overhanging abyss and, as fast as a bolt, vanished into thin air."

Original: Luogo è in inferno detto Malebolge, tutto di pietra di color ferrigno, come la cerchia che dintorno il volge
Translate: "Malebolge is a place of torment, which surrounds all its rocky walls in a color similar to iron."

Original: Nel dritto mezzo del campo maligno vaneggia un pozzo assai largo e profondo, di cui suo loco dicerò l’ordigno
Translate: "In the midst of the desolate plain appears a vast and deep well, whose characteristics will be explained later."

Original: Quel cinghio che rimane adunque è tondo tra ’l pozzo e ’l piè de l’alta ripa dura, e ha distinto in dieci valli il fondo
Translate: The space between the well and the rocky wall has a circular shape and is divided into ten valleys.

Original: Quale, dove per guardia de le mura più e più fossi cingon li castelli, la parte dove son rende figura,  tale imagine quivi facean quelli
Translate: The ditches that surround the castles, protected the walls with them, create a vision similar to the spheres present

Original: e come a tai fortezze da’ lor sogli a la ripa di fuor son ponticelli,
Translate: "As a wooden bridge joining their thresholds to the shores of the ditches, such fortresses are joined."

Original: così da imo de la roccia scogli movien che ricidien li argini e ’ fossi infino al pozzo che i tronca e raccogli
Translate: "The stone bridges, which started from one point at the base of the rock and crossed banks and ditches, were interrupted only by the central well that brought them together."

Original: In questo luogo, de la schiena scossi di Gerïon, trovammoci
Translate: "We found ourselves in this place once Gerion had dumped us from his back."

Original: e ’l poeta tenne a sinistra, e io dietro mi mossi
Translate: "Virgilio headed left, I followed him."

Original: A la man destra vidi nova pieta, novo tormento e novi frustatori, di che la prima bolgia era repleta
Translate: "On the right, I noticed an unprecedented suffering, an unusual torment and new Satyrs filling the First Bolgia."

Original: Nel fondo erano ignudi i peccatori
Translate: The sinners were at the bottom of the Bolgia, naked

Original: dal mezzo in qua ci venien verso ’l volto, di là con noi, ma con passi maggiori,
Translate: "In the outer part of the moat we walked towards them, while those in its interior were in rapid movement from the opposite direction."

Original: come i Roman per l’essercito molto, l’anno del giubileo, su per lo ponte hanno a passar la gente modo colto,
Translate: "To allow the great multitude of people who flowed in the year of the Jubilee, the Romans found a way to get them across the bridge."

Original: che da l’un lato tutti hanno la fronte verso ’l castello e vanno a Santo Pietro, da l’altra sponda vanno verso ’l monte
Translate: They proceed on one side towards St Peter's and on the other they reach Mount Giordano.

Original: Di qua, di là, su per lo sasso tetro vidi demon cornuti con gran ferze, che li battien crudelmente di retro
Translate: "On the two sides of the dark rock I saw evil spirits with horns, armed with whips; they were beating their backs mercilessly."

Original: Ahi come facean lor levar le berze a le prime percosse
Translate: "Oh, how quickly they knew how to escape the threat of punishment!"

Original: già nessuno le seconde aspettava né le terze
Translate: Nobody expected to get hit twice or three times.

Original: Mentr’io andava, li occhi miei in uno furo scontrati
Translate: "While I was walking, my eyes crossed paths with those of one of the unfortunate people."

Original: e io sì tosto dissi: "Già di veder costui non son digiuno"
Translate: I immediately remembered, "This is not the first time I've met this person."

Original: Per ch’ïo a figurarlo i piedi affissi
Translate: I stopped for a better observation.

Original: e ’l dolce duca meco si ristette, e assentio ch’alquanto in dietro gissi
Translate: And my dear guide stayed with me and approved that I should go back a little.

Original: E quel frustato celar si credette bassando ’l viso
Translate: The face of that whipped person fell as he realized that his only choice was to hide.

Original: ma poco li valse, ch’io dissi: "O tu che l’occhio a terra gette,  se le fazion che porti non son false, Venedico se’ tu Caccianemico
Translate: "Alas, to what seems to be the gaze lowered to the ground did not serve him at all because I pronounced the phrase: 'You must be Hunting Venedic, if your features are not false!'"

Original: Ma che ti mena a sì pungenti salse?"
Translate: What have you done so badly that you deserve such severe punishment?

Original: Ed elli a me: "Mal volontier lo dico
Translate: "He told me reluctantly."

Original: ma sforzami la tua chiara favella, che mi fa sovvenir del mondo antico
Translate: Your clear voice reminds me of the things of real life

Original: I’ fui colui che la Ghisolabella condussi a far la voglia del marchese, come che suoni la sconcia novella
Translate: "I am the one who accompanied my sister Ghisolabella to satisfy the wishes of the Marquis, even if this story will have a remarkable spread."

Original: E non pur io qui piango bolognese
Translate: I'm not the only Bolognese to shed tears here.

Original: anzi n’è questo loco tanto pieno, che tante lingue non son ora apprese  a dicer ’sipa’ tra Sàvena e Reno
Translate: "This Bolgia is so crowded that it is not even recognized by the oldest languages, that they have not yet learned to say 'sipa' between Savena and Reno."

Original: e se di ciò vuoi fede o testimonio, rècati a mente il nostro avaro seno"
Translate: "If you want a sure proof of our tendency to be greedy, think about it."

Original: Così parlando il percosse un demonio de la sua scurïada, e disse: "Via, ruffian
Translate: "While he was talking, a demon punished him with his whip and shouted to him, "Get out of here, you rascal!""

Original: qui non son femmine da conio"
Translate: There are no women here for sale.

Original: I’ mi raggiunsi con la scorta mia
Translate: I'll reunite with my guide.

Original: poscia con pochi passi divenimmo là ’v’uno scoglio de la ripa uscia
Translate: in a few moves we would arrive at the place where an ancient stone bridge came up from the mountain

Original: Assai leggeramente quel salimmo
Translate: We climbed on it without difficulty.

Original: e vòlti a destra su per la sua scheggia, da quelle cerchie etterne ci partimmo
Translate: "We turned away from that eternal turning, turning to the right and going up along it."

Original: Quando noi fummo là dov’el vaneggia di sotto per dar passo a li sferzati, lo duca disse:
Translate: "At the point where a bridge formed a lake to give vent to the waves, the master said:"

Original: "Attienti, e fa che feggia  lo viso in te di quest’altri mal nati, ai quali ancor non vedesti la faccia però che son con noi insieme andati"
Translate: "Keep your attention to make sure you see the faces of these other wretches, even if we proceed in the same direction."

Original: Del vecchio ponte guardavam la traccia che venìa verso noi da l’altra banda, e che la ferza similmente scaccia
Translate: "From the other side of the old bridge, we saw a line moving towards us and being incited by whips."

Original: E ’l buon maestro, sanza mia dimanda, mi disse: "Guarda quel grande che vene, e per dolor non par lagrime spanda:
Translate: "The teacher, without me asking anything, said to me: "Look at him who is advancing there and does not seem to cry for his pain"."

Original: quanto aspetto reale ancor ritene
Translate: the residence?What royal shine is still present in the abode?

Original: Quelli è Iasón, che per cuore e per senno li Colchi del monton privati féne
Translate: "Jason, thanks to his boldness and ingenuity, successfully took away the fleece of gold from the Colchi."

Original: Ello passò per l’isola di Lenno poi che l’ardite femmine spietate tutti li maschi loro a morte dienno
Translate: "After the women of Lemno had committed the merciless atrocity of killing all their husbands, He passed through the island."

Original: Ivi con segni e con parole ornate Isifile ingannò, la giovinetta che prima avea tutte l’altre ingannate
Translate: "Isifile, the young woman who had cheated everyone else, was in turn deceived by gestures and words of sophistication by those who were there."

Original: Lasciolla quivi, gravida, soletta
Translate: "She left here, pregnant and without help."

Original: tal colpa a tal martiro lui condanna
Translate: This crime involves this punishment.

Original: e anche di Medea si fa vendetta
Translate: "Medea was deceived, and the perpetrator was punished for his action."

Original: Con lui sen va chi da tal parte inganna
Translate: Those who try to deceive him go on like this.

Original: e questo basti de la prima valle sapere e di color che ’n sé assanna"
Translate: You just need to know this about Bolgia I and her convicted people being punished.

Original: Già eravam là ’ve lo stretto calle con l’argine secondo s’incrocicchia, e fa di quello ad un altr’arco spalle
Translate: "The extreme points of the rocky bridge joined the second embankment, from which another path began."

Original: Quindi sentimmo gente che si nicchia ne l’altra bolgia e che col muso scuffa, e sé medesma con le palme picchia
Translate: "We heard lamentations coming from the next Bolgia, with the sound of the nasal and oral breath, accompanied by blows given with the hands."

Original: Le ripe eran grommate d’una muffa, per l’alito di giù che vi s’appasta, che con li occhi e col naso facea zuffa
Translate: "The layers of mold encrusted on the walls of Bolgia were so thick that they irritated eyes and nostrils because of the afa coming from the depths, kneading on the walls."

Original: Lo fondo è cupo sì, che non ci basta loco a veder sanza montare al dosso de l’arco, ove lo scoglio più sovrasta
Translate: "We couldn't see anything except climbing up to the apex of the arch, the position from which the bridge surmounted the moat, since it was extremely dark there."

Original: Quivi venimmo
Translate: we got here

Original: e quindi giù nel fosso vidi gente attuffata in uno sterco che da li uman privadi parea mosso
Translate: I saw at the base of the hellish people who seemed to be in a dungeon from the sewers of humanity.

Original: E mentre ch’io là giù con l’occhio cerco, vidi un col capo sì di merda lordo, che non parëa s’era laico o cherco
Translate: "While I was peering from above, I saw a man who had such an abundance of excrements on his head that he could not determine whether he was cleric or layman."

Original: Quei mi sgridò: "Perché se’ tu sì gordo di riguardar più me che li altri brutti?"
Translate: He told me, "Why are you staring at me longer than the others who have been damned?"

Original: E io a lui: "Perché, se ben ricordo,  già t’ ho veduto coi capelli asciutti, e se’ Alessio Interminei da Lucca: però t’adocchio più che li altri tutti"
Translate: "I remember well, you are Alessio Interminelli from Lucca, and it was remarkable to see you with dry hair, therefore I fix myself on you more than everyone else."

Original: Ed elli allor, battendosi la zucca: "Qua giù m’ hanno sommerso le lusinghe ond’io non ebbi mai la lingua stucca"
Translate: "Blaming himself on his head, he exclaimed: "I have been flooded with praises and I have never had enough!"

Original: Appresso ciò lo duca "Fa che pinghe", mi disse, "il viso un poco più avante,
Translate: "After that, my guide urged me to look up further."

Original: sì che la faccia ben con l’occhio attinghe  di quella sozza e scapigliata fante che là si graffia con l’unghie merdose, e or s’accoscia e ora è in piedi stante
Translate: "so that you can see the face of that woman with sharpness, and the way she sinks her nails dirty with dung into the skin, bending on herself now from sitting and now from standing."

Original: Taïde è, la puttana che rispuose al drudo suo quando disse "Ho io grazie grandi apo te?": "Anzi maravigliose"
Translate: ""When his lover asked, "Do I have great value for you?""Taide, the prostitute, replied enthusiastically to him, ""I would say yes, a great one"."

Original: E quinci sian le nostre viste sazie"
Translate: We can contemplate with pleasure what we have created.

Original: O Simon mago, o miseri seguaci che le cose di Dio, che di bontate deon essere spose, e voi rapaci per oro e per argento avolterate,
Translate: "Oh Simon the Magician and his wretched followers, who greedily prostitute God's things for gold and silver that should be exhibited to goodness."

Original: or convien che per voi suoni la tromba, però che ne la terza bolgia state
Translate: "You're in III Bolgia, so it's time for you to play the trumpet."

Original: Già eravamo, a la seguente tomba, montati de lo scoglio in quella parte ch’a punto sovra mezzo ’l fosso piomba
Translate: "We climbed on a bridge in the next Bolagia until the vertical line passed straight through the middle of the chasm."

Original: O somma sapïenza, quanta è l'arte che mostri in cielo, in terra e nel mal mondo, e quanto giusto tua virtù comparte
Translate: "Oh, great wisdom! How perfect is your manifestation in heaven, on earth, and in hell, and with what great justice your goodness rewards and punishes!"

Original: Io vidi per le coste e per lo fondo piena la pietra livida di fóri, d’un largo tutti e ciascun era tondo
Translate: "I noticed the dark wall dotted with roundish holes of the same size, which surrounded the entire area and bottom of the pit."

Original: Non mi parean men ampi né maggiori che que’ che son nel mio bel San Giovanni, fatti per loco d’i battezzatori
Translate: They were no longer narrower or more extensive than the fountains used as sources for baptism in the well-known Baptistery of St. John in Florence.

Original: l’un de li quali, ancor non è molt’anni, rupp’io per un che dentro v’annegava: e questo sia suggel ch’ogn’omo sganni
Translate: "I broke one a few years ago to save someone who was drowning, with the intention of correcting the misinformation of those who were ill-advised."

Original: Fuor de la bocca a ciascun soperchiava d’un peccator li piedi e de le gambe infino al grosso, e l’altro dentro stava
Translate: "The feet and legs of a sinner sprang up from the edges of every hole, to the thighs, while the upper part of the body remained within it."

Original: Le piante erano a tutti accese intrambe
Translate: His feet were lit up.

Original: per che sì forte guizzavan le giunte, che spezzate averien ritorte e strambe
Translate: "with a force that would break the strongest strings, the damned ones would kick with all their joints."

Original: Qual suole il fiammeggiar de le cose unte muoversi pur su per la strema buccia, tal era lì dai calcagni a le punte
Translate: "As small rays of light, those flames moved from the heel to the tip of the feet like a flame that barely touches the surface of the anointed things."

Original: "Chi è colui, maestro, che si cruccia guizzando più che li altri suoi consorti", diss’io, "e cui più roggia fiamma succia?"
Translate: "I asked my teacher who was the miscapitated one who was suffering more than the others, and on whom there seemed to be a burning flame?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Se tu vuo’ ch’i’ ti porti là giù per quella ripa che più giace, da lui saprai di sé e de’ suoi torti"
Translate: "And he said to me, "If you want me to take you to the bottom along the sweetest slope, you will ask him yourself who he is and what his sin is."

Original: E io: "Tanto m'è bel, quanto a te piace: tu se' segnore, e sai ch'i' non mi parto dal tuo volere, e sai quel che si tace"
Translate: "I: "I follow your guide, I understand what you are saying to me even without you expressing it clearly. What I like is fine"."

Original: Allor venimmo in su l’argine quarto
Translate: We reached the next embankment

Original: volgemmo e discendemmo a mano stanca là giù nel fondo foracchiato e arto
Translate: "We started to cross the bottom of the Bolgia, flanked by holes and narrow streets, turning to the left."

Original: Lo buon maestro ancor de la sua anca non mi dipuose, sì mi giunse al rotto di quel che si piangeva con la zanca
Translate: "The good teacher did not let me go, standing by my side until we reached the pit where the wretched one was lying with her legs."

Original: "O qual che se’ che ’l di sù tien di sotto, anima trista come pal commessa", comincia’ io a dir, "se puoi, fa motto"
Translate: "I began to beg: "Whatever your name is, now that you are turned down, melancholy spirit like a stake thrown into the earth, you would do well to answer me."

Original: Io stava come ’l frate che confessa lo perfido assessin, che, poi ch’è fitto, richiama lui per che la morte cessa
Translate: "I was there like a friar who listened to the confession of the evildoer, who, after being dropped into the pit, called him desperately to delay execution."

Original: Ed el gridò: "Se' tu già costì ritto, se' tu già costì ritto, Bonifazio? Di parecchi anni mi mentì lo scritto
Translate: "He cried out, "Boniface, are you up yet? The book of the future had deceived me for several years!"

Original: Se’ tu sì tosto di quell’aver sazio per lo qual non temesti tòrre a ’nganno la bella donna, e poi di farne strazio?"
Translate: "Have you exhausted your hunger for wealth, having no hesitation in deceiving that beautiful woman and then abusing her?"

Original: Tal mi fec’io, quai son color che stanno, per non intender ciò ch’è lor risposto, quasi scornati, e risponder non sanno
Translate: "I became similar to those who fail to interpret the answer received, so they feel dismayed and do not know how to reply."

Original: Allor Virgilio disse: "Dilli tosto: "Non son colui, non son colui che credi""
Translate: Virgil ordered: "Tell her immediately: 'I am not who you think'"

Original: e io rispuosi come a me fu imposto
Translate: "As I was commanded, I gave an answer."

Original: Per che lo spirto tutti storse i piedi
Translate: The spirit bent its feet completely

Original: poi, sospirando e con voce di pianto, mi disse: "Dunque che a me richiedi?
Translate: "With a deep sigh, he said in a sad tone, "What is your question?"

Original: Se di saper ch’i’ sia ti cal cotanto, che tu abbi però la ripa corsa, sappi ch’i’ fui vestito del gran manto
Translate: I wore the papal cloak if you were curious enough to come down here to know who I am.

Original: e veramente fui figliuol de l’orsa, cupido sì per avanzar li orsatti, che sù l’avere e qui me misi in borsa
Translate: "I became a legitimate son of the bear, so eager to improve the fate of my family members that I sacrificed everything I had to get it - including myself."

Original: Di sotto al capo mio son li altri tratti che precedetter me simoneggiando, per le fessure de la pietra piatti
Translate: "The others who preceded me in the practice of simony are crushed at the bottom, under my head, in the cracks of the rock."

Original: Là giù cascherò io altresì quando verrà colui ch’i’ credea che tu fossi, allor ch’i’ feci ’l sùbito dimando
Translate: "I'll end up there when whoever I thought you were coming, reminding me of the question I suddenly asked you."

Original: Ma più è ’l tempo già che i piè mi cossi e ch’i’ son stato così sottosopra, ch’el non starà piantato coi piè rossi:
Translate: I spent more time agonizing for my tired feet and contrary to what will happen to him with his reddish.

Original: ché dopo lui verrà di più laida opra, di ver’ ponente, un pastor sanza legge, tal che convien che lui e me ricuopra
Translate: "of mud We will follow another pope from the west, who will not respect any law and will do even worse than him; this will cover me with dishonor."

Original: Nuovo Iasón sarà, di cui si legge ne’ Maccabei
Translate: The story of a new Jason is narrated in the Book of Maccabees.

Original: e come a quel fu molle suo re, così fia lui chi Francia regge"
Translate: The king of France will be just as condescending with the pope as he had been with him.

Original: Io non so s’i’ mi fui qui troppo folle, ch’i’ pur rispuosi lui a questo metro:
Translate: "I'm not sure if my reaction was too rude, since I answered him in that tone."

Original: "Deh, or mi dì: quanto tesoro volle  Nostro Segnore in prima da san Pietro ch’ei ponesse le chiavi in sua balìa?
Translate: "Before giving St Peter the keys to the kingdom of heaven, our Lord how much money did he want?"

Original: Certo non chiese se non "Viemmi retro"
Translate: "She just said, "Come with me."

Original: Né Pier né li altri tolsero a Matia oro od argento, quando fu sortito al loco che perdé l’anima ria
Translate: "Peter and the others took nothing from Matthias, when he was appointed to take the place that Judah had forsaken."

Original: Però ti sta, ché tu se’ ben punito
Translate: Stay here as punishment.

Original: e guarda ben la mal tolta moneta ch’esser ti fece contra Carlo ardito
Translate: "Keep the fruit of a trap, which made you dare to challenge Charles of Anjou."

Original: E se non fosse ch’ancor lo mi vieta la reverenza de le somme chiavi che tu tenesti ne la vita lieta,  io userei parole ancor più gravi
Translate: "If it weren't for the deep respect I have for the fundamental values you protected during your existence here on earth, I would use even stronger words."

Original: ché la vostra avarizia il mondo attrista, calcando i buoni e sollevando i pravi
Translate: "In fact, your avarice brings sadness to the world, crushing those who are of good heart and exalting those who have no scruples."

Original: Di voi pastor s’accorse il Vangelista, quando colei che siede sopra l’acque puttaneggiar coi regi a lui fu vista
Translate: The Evangelist realized the wickedness of the shepherds when he saw the street woman sitting on the water making prostitution with the rulers.

Original: quella che con le sette teste nacque, e da le diece corna ebbe argomento, fin che virtute al suo marito piacque
Translate: "She was born with seven heads and took strength from the ten horns, until her husband appreciated her virtues."

Original: Fatto v’avete dio d’oro e d’argento
Translate: You created a god of gold and silver.

Original: e che altro è da voi a l’idolatre, se non ch’elli uno, e voi ne orate cento?
Translate: "What is the distinction between you and the pagan, except that which one worships only one god while the other prays more divinity?"

Original: Ahi, Costantin, di quanto mal fu matre, non la tua conversion, ma quella dote che da te prese il primo ricco patre"
Translate: "Alas, Constantine, how much evil has been inflicted not by your conversion but because of the enormous donation you made to the first wealthy pope."

Original: E mentr’io li cantava cotai note, o ira o coscïenza che ’l mordesse, forte spingava con ambo le piote
Translate: "While I was addressing him with those words, the damned man was agitated with strength both out of anger and regret."

Original: I’ credo ben ch’al mio duca piacesse, con sì contenta labbia sempre attese lo suon de le parole vere espresse
Translate: "I believe my teacher approved, for he listened with a peaceful face to my sincere presentation."

Original: Però con ambo le braccia mi prese
Translate: He held me tight with both arms.

Original: e poi che tutto su mi s’ebbe al petto, rimontò per la via onde discese
Translate: "After that, hugging me tight to his chest, he climbed up the same road from which he had descended."

Original: Né si stancò d’avermi a sé distretto, sì men portò sovra ’l colmo de l’arco che dal quarto al quinto argine è tragetto
Translate: "He didn't tire of holding me tight until he took me to the top of the bridge, which connects embankment number four with the fifth."

Original: Quivi soavemente spuose il carco, soave per lo scoglio sconcio ed erto che sarebbe a le capre duro varco
Translate: "He kindly laid the load on the ground, whose sweetness was not enough to face the climbing on steep and steep rock; a path that would have been difficult even for the goats."

Original: Indi un altro vallon mi fu scoperto
Translate: I was taken to another Bolgia from that place.

Original: Di nova pena mi conven far versi e dar matera al ventesimo canto de la prima canzon, ch’è d’i sommersi
Translate: "I must write verses concerning a new punishment and thus provide material for the last Song of the First Song, dedicated to the condemned."

Original: Io era già disposto tutto quanto a riguardar ne lo scoperto fondo, che si bagnava d’angoscioso pianto
Translate: "I was determined to descend into the depths of Bolgia, filled with tears of despair."

Original: e vidi gente per lo vallon tondo venir, tacendo e lagrimando, al passo che fanno le letane in questo mondo
Translate: "I saw condemned souls proceeding with a sad and silent pace in the round moat, as if they were parading a funeral procession."

Original: Come ’l viso mi scese in lor più basso, mirabilmente apparve esser travolto ciascun tra ’l mento e ’l principio del casso,
Translate: "As soon as I looked at them more closely, it seemed to me that everyone had a deep throat sunk between the chin and the beginning of the chest."

Original: ché da le reni era tornato ’l volto, e in dietro venir li convenia, perché ’l veder dinanzi era lor tolto
Translate: "They could not look to the future, since the face was turned to their backs and so they were forced to go back."

Original: Forse per forza già di parlasia si travolse così alcun del tutto
Translate: It could be that someone was struck by a paralysis so severe that it made him unrecognizable.

Original: ma io nol vidi, né credo che sia
Translate: I have no memory of it and I doubt it ever happened.

Original: Se Dio ti lasci, lettor, prender frutto di tua lezione,
Translate: "May you, readers, take the lesson to a good degree."

Original: or pensa per te stesso com'io potea tener lo viso asciutto,
Translate: Think how I could have held back my tears.

Original: quando la nostra imagine di presso vidi sì torta, che ’l pianto de li occhi le natiche bagnava per lo fesso
Translate: "When I found myself in the presence of a desperate human figure crying aloud, with tears flowing along the crack on the back."

Original: Certo io piangea, poggiato a un de’ rocchi del duro scoglio, sì che la mia scorta mi disse:
Translate: "While I was standing there on one of the bosses of the rock and venting my tears, my guide addressed these words to me:"

Original: "Ancor se' tu de li altri sciocchi?  Qui vive la pietà quand’è ben morta
Translate: Are you also a member of those who have no compassion? Here forgiveness is appreciated only if it no longer exists.

Original: chi è più scellerato che colui che al giudicio divin passion comporta?
Translate: "Who is more wicked than the one who tries to deceive the will of Heaven, foreshadowing what will happen?"

Original: Drizza la testa, drizza, e vedi a cui s’aperse a li occhi d’i Teban la terra
Translate: "Rise up your sight, lift it up, and behold him who divided the ground to the Thebans under their own eyes."

Original: per ch’ei gridavan tutti: "Dove rui,  Anfïarao? perché lasci la guerra?"
Translate: "Everyone shouted out loud, "Amphiaraus, why did you leave the battle? Where are you going?""

Original: E non restò di ruinare a valle fino a Minòs che ciascheduno afferra
Translate: He continued to fall until he reached Minos who took every soul destined for damnation.

Original: Mira c' ha fatto petto de le spalle
Translate: See how he turned toward the future, and now he has a strong chest ahead.

Original: perché volse veder troppo davante, di retro guarda e fa retroso calle
Translate: "He is now returning to the past, having looked beyond what he wanted."

Original: Vedi Tiresia, che mutò sembiante quando di maschio femmina divenne, cangiandosi le membra tutte quante
Translate: "Tiresia, who experienced the change from man to woman by changing every limb of hers, was seen."

Original: e prima, poi, ribatter li convenne li duo serpenti avvolti, con la verga, che rïavesse le maschili penne
Translate: "In order to recover his male prerogatives, he had to collide with his own symbols of power using the same rod to repel the two snakes that enveloped his body."

Original: Aronta è quel ch’al ventre li s’atterga, che ne’ monti di Luni, dove ronca lo Carrarese che di sotto alberga, ebbe tra ’ bianchi marmi la spelonca per sua dimora
Translate: "Arunte, who lived in the cavern nestled among the white rocks of the mountains of Luni, has his back resting on his belly; under him the Carraresi present in the plain were deforested."

Original: onde a guardar le stelle e ’l mar non li era la veduta tronca
Translate: "From the position he was in, he had a spectacular view of the stars and the ocean."

Original: E quella che ricuopre le mammelle, che tu non vedi, con le trecce sciolte, e ha di là ogne pilosa pelle,  Manto fu, che cercò per terre molte
Translate: "Manto, who visited a multitude of places, is covered with loose braids and has hair on every part of the body except those you do not see."

Original: poscia si puose là dove nacqu’ io
Translate: Then he chose to set up his own residence in my hometown.

Original: onde un poco mi piace che m’ascolte
Translate: I'd like you to take some time to listen to me now.

Original: Poscia che ’l padre suo di vita uscìo e venne serva la città di Baco, questa gran tempo per lo mondo gio
Translate: "After the death of her father and that the hometown became a place of worship for Bacchus, she traveled for a long time in the world."

Original: Suso in Italia bella giace un laco, a piè de l’Alpe che serra Lamagna sovra Tiralli, c’ ha nome Benaco
Translate: "In Tyrol, on the border between Italy and Germany, lies Lake Benaco at the foot of the Alps."

Original: Per mille fonti, credo, e più si bagna tra Garda e Val Camonica e Pennino de l’acqua che nel detto laco stagna
Translate: "Thousands and more sources feed the lake that is located in the territory between Garda, Valcamonica and the Pennine Alps, generating an abundant water reserve."

Original: Loco è nel mezzo là dove ’l trentino pastore e quel di Brescia e ’l veronese segnar poria, s’e’ fesse quel cammino
Translate: "In the center of that area the bishops of Trento, Brescia and Verona could converge to receive a blessing if they wanted to undertake that journey."

Original: Siede Peschiera, bello e forte arnese da fronteggiar Bresciani e Bergamaschi, ove la riva ’ntorno più discese
Translate: "It rises in Peschiera, beautiful and solid fortress built at a point where the shore is lower; it serves to counter the Bresciani and Bergamaschi."

Original: Ivi convien che tutto quanto caschi ciò che ’n grembo a Benaco star non può, e fassi fiume giù per verdi paschi
Translate: From here the excess water to the lake basin flows into a stream that winds through the green meadows.

Original: Tosto che l’acqua a correr mette co, non più Benaco, ma Mencio si chiama fino a Governol, dove cade in Po
Translate: "Once it has begun to flow, the water takes the name of Mincio to the point of arrival in Govèrnolo, where it enters the Po."

Original: Non molto ha corso, ch’el trova una lama, ne la qual si distende e la ’mpaluda
Translate: "Following its flow, a large depression was dug into the surface, producing a swamp."

Original: e suol di state talor esser grama
Translate: Sometimes in summer it's dry.

Original: Quindi passando la vergine cruda vide terra, nel mezzo del pantano, sanza coltura e d’abitanti nuda
Translate: " As she passed by, the heartless woman noticed an uncultivated and uninhabited trait in the midst of the marshes."

Original: Lì, per fuggire ogne consorzio umano, ristette con suoi servi a far sue arti,
Translate: He moved to that area to avoid any kind of relationship with humans and to dedicate himself to his mystical practices along with his servants.

Original: e visse, e vi lasciò suo corpo vano
Translate: She spent her life there and was buried at the end of her existence.

Original: Li uomini poi che ’ntorno erano sparti s’accolsero a quel loco, ch’era forte per lo pantan ch’avea da tutte parti
Translate: "Afterwards, the males who were spreading in that territory gathered there, protected by a swamp surrounding the area."

Original: Fer la città sovra quell’ossa morte
Translate: They built a city on his grave.

Original: e per colei che ’l loco prima elesse, Mantüa l’appellar sanz’altra sorte
Translate: It is said that Mantua took its name from the one who first decided its location and not through other rituals.

Original: Già fuor le genti sue dentro più spesse, prima che la mattia da Casalodi da Pinamonte inganno ricevesse
Translate: "The madness of Pinamonte, the cunning Count of Casalodi, had caused the city to be less inhabited before."

Original: Però t’assenno che, se tu mai odi originar la mia terra altrimenti, la verità nulla menzogna frodi"
Translate: "I warn you that if I come to know different versions of the origin of my land, lies are banished in order to preserve the truth."

Original: E io: "Maestro, i tuoi ragionamenti mi son sì certi e prendon sì mia fede, che li altri mi sarien carboni spenti
Translate: "I tell the Master that his arguments are so precise and convincing, that others cannot stand up to her."

Original: Ma dimmi, de la gente che procede, se tu ne vedi alcun degno di nota
Translate: But tell me if you identify anyone else worthy of note among those convicted who proceed.

Original: ché solo a ciò la mia mente rifiede"
Translate: I have all my attention focused on this.

Original: Allor mi disse: "Quel che da la gota porge la barba in su le spalle brune, fu - quando Grecia fu di maschi vòta,  sì ch’a pena rimaser per le cune -
Translate: "Then he said to me: "When Greece had almost not enough men to feed in the cradles, fate drew on the face of those who had remained a premonitory sign of the beard that would populate its dark shoulders"."

Original: augure, e diede ’l punto con Calcanta in Aulide a tagliar la prima fune
Translate: "He was a prominent figure, and he calculated together with Calcante the most favorable moment in the bay of Aulide so that the Greek navy could sail."

Original: Euripilo ebbe nome, e così ’l canta l’alta mia tragedìa in alcun loco: ben lo sai tu che la sai tutta quanta
Translate: "He was Euripilo, as reported in my long poem; you are aware of it, since you have read it entirely."

Original: Quell’altro che ne’ fianchi è così poco, Michele Scotto fu, che veramente de le magiche frode seppe ’l gioco
Translate: "Michele Scotto, from the physical slenderness and his skillful contests to the game of magic fraud, has become well known."

Original: Vedi Guido Bonatti
Translate: Have you seen Guido Bonatti?

Original: vedi Asdente, ch’avere inteso al cuoio e a lo spago ora vorrebbe, ma tardi si pente
Translate: "Assent understood the mistake he made not by dedicating himself to leather and string, but by now regret arrives too late."

Original: Vedi le triste che lasciaron l’ago, la spuola e ’l fuso, e fecersi ’ndivine
Translate: "Do you watch women move away, abandoning needle, spout and mechanical melt to explore the world of guessing?"

Original: fecer malie con erbe e con imago
Translate: They practiced magic with sacred herbs and amulets.

Original: Ma vienne omai, ché già tiene ’l confine d’amendue li emisperi e tocca l’onda sotto Sobilia Caino e le spine
Translate: "While the moon is about to descend under the sea of Seville after touching the borders of both hemispheres, the time comes for you to leave."

Original: e già iernotte fu la luna tonda: ben ten de’ ricordar, ché non ti nocque alcuna volta per la selva fonda"
Translate: "Yesterday night was full of moon, you should remember that because it helped you once as you walked through the dark forest."

Original: Sì mi parlava, e andavamo introcque
Translate: "While we were walking all the time, she spoke to me like that."

Original: Così di ponte in ponte, altro parlando che la mia comedìa cantar non cura, venimmo
Translate: "While we were chatting about things that had nothing to do with my Comedy, we reached the other bridge."

Original: e tenavamo ’l colmo, quando restammo per veder l’altra fessura di Malebolge e li altri pianti vani
Translate: "We reached the summit, where there was another pit of torment and painful cries of the condemned."

Original: e vidila mirabilmente oscura
Translate: the past with an extraordinary hardness of tones

Original: Quale ne l’arzanà de’ Viniziani bolle l’inverno la tenace pece a rimpalmare i legni lor non sani, ché navicar non ponno
Translate: " during the cold seasonAs a hot glue in the Venetian Arsenal, used to repair their damaged ships, it boils the pitch viscous because they cannot navigate during the coldest months."

Original: - in quella vece chi fa suo legno novo e chi ristoppa le coste a quel che più vïaggi fece
Translate: "Some assemble a fresh factory vessel, while others set up the sides of the boats that have made many crossings at sea."

Original: chi ribatte da proda e chi da poppa
Translate: Some nails beats both at the bow and at the stern.

Original: altri fa remi e altri volge sarte
Translate: Others fix the oars and tidy the tailors.

Original: chi terzeruolo e artimon rintoppa -:
Translate: They repair the trierol and the artimon.

Original: tal, non per foco ma per divin’arte, bollia là giuso una pegola spessa, che ’nviscava la ripa d’ogne parte
Translate: "Downstairs, the Bolgia was imbued with a slimy dark liquid not generated by flames but divinely put into action, which covered every surface of its walls."

Original: I’ vedea lei, ma non vedëa in essa mai che le bolle che ’l bollor levava, e gonfiar tutta, e riseder compressa
Translate: "I watched the pitch, its bubbles coming out on the surface and how it swelled up and then lowered, but no other elements were present."

Original: Mentr’io là giù fisamente mirava, lo duca mio, dicendo "Guarda, guarda", mi trasse a sé del loco dov’io stava
Translate: "As I looked down, my teacher took me by one arm and approached him, whispering, "See? See?"

Original: Allor mi volsi come l’uom cui tarda di veder quel che li convien fuggire e cui paura sùbita sgagliarda,
Translate: "By turning back, as if I were trying to hold back something that I knew was destined to vanish and yet terrified me so much that I took away all courage."

Original: che, per veder, non indugia ’l partire: e vidi dietro a noi un diavol nero correndo su per lo scoglio venire
Translate: "While we were looking back, we noticed a dark figure running fast towards us on the bridge."

Original: Ahi quant’elli era ne l’aspetto fero
Translate: "Ah, how threatening it looked."

Original: e quanto mi parea ne l’atto acerbo, con l’ali aperte e sovra i piè leggero
Translate: "I had found his behavior so hard, as he was running agilely with his feet and wings wide open."

Original: L’omero suo, ch’era aguto e superbo, carcava un peccator con ambo l’anche, e quei tenea de’ piè ghermito ’l nerbo
Translate: "A sinner lay facing with both sides, and the devil shook his ankles; on his sides there was a sharp shoulder holding the weight."

Original: Del nostro ponte disse: "O Malebranche, ecco un de li anzïan di Santa Zita
Translate: "Hey, Malebranche" said the devil while we were on the bridge, "look there at one of the elders of Santa Zita."

Original: Mettetel sotto, ch'i' torno per anche  a quella terra, che n’è ben fornita: ogn’uom v’è barattier, fuor che Bonturo
Translate: "Put it in the pitch, while I return to that city teeming with merchants: all except Bonturo Dati."

Original: del no, per li denar, vi si fa ita"
Translate: "For money, there the refusal is nonexistent and ""no" does not exist."

Original: Là giù ’l buttò, e per lo scoglio duro si volse
Translate: He pushed him into the morch and jumped on the shore of the bridge.

Original: e mai non fu mastino sciolto con tanta fretta a seguitar lo furo
Translate: No German shepherd was so quick to chase the criminal.

Original: Quel s’attuffò, e tornò sù convolto
Translate: The unhappy dive into the water re-emerged with the stained body.

Original: ma i demon che del ponte avean coperchio, gridar: "Qui non ha loco il Santo Volto
Translate: The evil people hid behind the bridge shouted: "There is no Holy Relic here!"

Original: qui si nuota altrimenti che nel Serchio
Translate: You swim differently here than the Serchio River.

Original: Però, se tu non vuo’ di nostri graffi, non far sopra la pegola soverchio"
Translate: "If you want to avoid what might bring you pain, stay hidden in the slime."

Original: Poi l’addentar con più di cento raffi, disser: "Coverto convien che qui balli, sì che, se puoi, nascosamente accaffi"
Translate: "They caught him with hundreds of hooks and said to him, "Here, you'll have to dance covered with pitch; if you're lucky enough, you could steal something without everyone's knowledge."

Original: Non altrimenti i cuoci a’ lor vassalli fanno attuffare in mezzo la caldaia la carne con li uncin, perché non galli
Translate: "The cooks order their maids to keep the meat down in the pot with the hooks, to prevent it from coming out."

Original: Lo buon maestro "Acciò che non si paia che tu ci sia", mi disse, "giù t’acquatta dopo uno scheggio, ch’alcun schermo t’aia
Translate: "The good teacher said to me: "To be not noticed, put yourself behind a rocky ledge, which can serve as a shield for you."

Original: e per nulla offension che mi sia fatta, non temer tu, ch’i’ ho le cose conte, perch’altra volta fui a tal baratta"
Translate: "I will not worry about any offense I may receive, for I know what my duty is after having participated in such a duel before."

Original: Poscia passò di là dal co del ponte
Translate: He arrived at the end of the bridge

Original: e com’el giunse in su la ripa sesta, mestier li fu d’aver sicura fronte
Translate: "As soon as he arrived at the embankment of the next Bolgia, he did his best to show security."

Original: Con quel furore e con quella tempesta ch’escono i cani a dosso al poverello che di sùbito chiede ove s’arresta,
Translate: "With the same intensity with which dogs bark at the beggar who had stopped to beg for alms from that point,"

Original: usciron quei di sotto al ponticello, e volser contra lui tutt’i runcigli
Translate: "Virgilio found himself surrounded by devils coming from under the bridge, all armed with hooked sticks."

Original: ma el gridò: "Nessun di voi sia fello
Translate: But he shouted, "No one dares disrespect me!"

Original: Innanzi che l’uncin vostro mi pigli, traggasi avante l’un di voi che m’oda, e poi d’arruncigliarmi si consigli"
Translate: "Get someone close, listen to me before you make a decision on whether I should ever be hooked."

Original: Tutti gridaron: "Vada Malacoda"
Translate: Everyone shouted, "Go away Malacoda!"

Original: per ch’un si mosse - e li altri stetter fermi - e venne a lui dicendo: "Che li approda?"
Translate: "The devil moved away from the others, and he reached Virgil, exclaiming, "What can he do him well?" My teacher replied later."

Original: "Credi tu, Malacoda, qui vedermi esser venuto", disse ’l mio maestro, "sicuro già da tutti vostri schermi,  sanza voler divino e fato destro?
Translate: "Do you think, Malacoda, to observe me here in total safety outside of the higher will and without the support of fortune?"

Original: Lascian’andar, ché nel cielo è voluto ch’i’ mostri altrui questo cammin silvestro"
Translate: "Let us leave, since destiny has in store for me a difficult expedition to present to others."

Original: Allor li fu l’orgoglio sì caduto, ch’e’ si lasciò cascar l’uncino a’ piedi, e disse a li altri: "Omai non sia feruto"
Translate: "Pride forsook the devil, so much so that he threw away the hook at his feet and begged the others: "Don't hurt yourselves!"

Original: E ’l duca mio a me: "O tu che siedi tra li scheggion del ponte quatto quatto, sicuramente omai a me ti riedi"
Translate: "My teacher spoke to me these words: "Do not be afraid to come out into the open, you who had watered yourself in the rocks of the bridge. Go back to me and you will have nothing to fear."

Original: Per ch’io mi mossi e a lui venni ratto
Translate: I rushed toward him.

Original: e i diavoli si fecer tutti avanti, sì ch’io temetti ch’ei tenesser patto
Translate: The devils approached in such a way that they feared them not to keep their promises.

Original: così vid’ïo già temer li fanti ch’uscivan patteggiati di Caprona, veggendo sé tra nemici cotanti
Translate: "The footmen who came out of the castle of Caprona according to the terms of the surrender, were frightened to observe many opponents around them."

Original: I’ m’accostai con tutta la persona lungo ’l mio duca, e non torceva li occhi da la sembianza lor ch’era non buona
Translate: "I was clinging to my guide, in the midst of a wave of deep concern as I looked at the threatening presence of the devils."

Original: Ei chinavan li raffi e "Vuo’ che ’l tocchi", diceva l’un con l’altro, "in sul groppone?"
Translate: They sharpened their forks and asked each other, "Do we have to hit him on the back?"

Original: E rispondien: "Sì, fa che gliel’accocchi"
Translate: "They said, "Make sure you hit him hard."

Original: Ma quel demonio che tenea sermone col duca mio, si volse tutto presto e disse: "Posa, posa, Scarmiglione"
Translate: "But that wicked man who was speaking with my teacher turned quickly and ordered: "Stay where you are, Scarmiglione"
