Original: Poi disse a noi: "Più oltre andar per questo iscoglio non si può, però che giace tutto spezzato al fondo l’arco sesto
Translate: He told us that the road was blocked because of the bridge collapsed in the sixth Bolgia.

Original: E se l’andare avante pur vi piace, andatevene su per questa grotta
Translate: "If you decide to proceed, follow the direction indicated by the embankment."

Original: presso è un altro scoglio che via face
Translate: Not far away there is another bridge that allows for transit.

Original: Ier, più oltre cinqu’ ore che quest’otta, mille dugento con sessanta sei anni compié che qui la via fu rotta
Translate: "1266 years ago, five hours later than today, the bridge collapsed."

Original: Io mando verso là di questi miei a riguardar s’alcun se ne sciorina
Translate: "Guiding with a firm hand, I send my emissaries to that direction to ensure that no one can escape the trap."

Original: gite con lor, che non saranno rei"
Translate: "Come with them, they'll come up with good behavior."

Original: "Tra’ ti avante, Alichino, e Calcabrina", cominciò elli a dire, "e tu, Cagnazzo
Translate: "Go forward, Alichino and Calcabrina, followed by Cagnazzo!"

Original: e Barbariccia guidi la decina
Translate: Barbariccia should lead the ten demons.

Original: Libicocco vegn’oltre e Draghignazzo, Cirïatto sannuto e Graffiacane e Farfarello e Rubicante pazzo
Translate: "The intervention of Libicocco and Draghignazzo, Ciriatto dagli Ali Grandi, Graffiacane, Farfarello and the crazy Rubican will also be required."

Original: Cercate ’ntorno le boglienti pane
Translate: Carefully examine the viscous boiling pitch

Original: costor sian salvi infino a l’altro scheggio che tutto intero va sovra le tane"
Translate: "Let these two walk the bridge, intact, to the other Bolgia and be protected from all evil."

Original: "Omè, maestro, che è quel ch’i’ veggio?", diss’io, "deh, sanza scorta andianci soli, se tu sa’ ir
Translate: "?Remembering my words, I asked: "Oh master, what do I see? Will it be possible to walk the way without a guide?""

Original: ch’i’ per me non la cheggio
Translate: I'm sure I won't ask.

Original: Se tu se’ sì accorto come suoli, non vedi tu ch’e’ digrignan li denti e con le ciglia ne minaccian duoli?"
Translate: "If he acts like a wise man, can't you notice the devils who show their teeth and appear threatening?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Non vo’ che tu paventi
Translate: He told me I shouldn't be afraid.

Original: lasciali digrignar pur a lor senno, ch’e’ fanno ciò per li lessi dolenti"
Translate: Remove them even when they grind their teeth because of those who are trapped in their destiny of punishment.

Original: Per l’argine sinistro volta dienno
Translate: The devils turned left onto the embankment.

Original: ma prima avea ciascun la lingua stretta coi denti, verso lor duca, per cenno
Translate: "First, everyone had tightened their lips and turned to their guidance as if it were a secret agreement."

Original: ed elli avea del cul fatto trombetta
Translate: and that had produced an indelicate sound with buttocks

Original: Io vidi già cavalier muover campo, e cominciare stormo e far lor mostra, e talvolta partir per loro scampo
Translate: "I had the opportunity to watch the knights leave for the battle, march in parade and sometimes retreat."

Original: corridor vidi per la terra vostra, o Aretini, e vidi gir gualdane, fedir torneamenti e correr giostra
Translate: "I've watched riders in your Aretina, and I've seen them do military raids, compete in team races and alone."

Original: quando con trombe, e quando con campane, con tamburi e con cenni di castella, e con cose nostrali e con istrane
Translate: "I've seen them obey several sounds, from trumpet to bells, from drums to signals from castles, using both typical local and foreign instruments."

Original: né già con sì diversa cennamella cavalier vidi muover né pedoni, né nave a segno di terra o di stella
Translate: "I have never seen knights or infantry move on the music emitted by such a bizarre instrument, nor have I ever watched a boat move in response to an equally singular signal coming from the earth and the air."

Original: Noi andavam con li diece demoni
Translate: We were going along with the ten demons.

Original: Ahi fiera compagnia
Translate: "Alas, fearsome association."

Original: ma ne la chiesa coi santi, e in taverna coi ghiottoni
Translate: "In church you have to add to the saints, while at the tavern you should attend sober people."

Original: Pur a la pegola era la mia ’ntesa, per veder de la bolgia ogne contegno e de la gente ch’entro v’era incesa
Translate: "I had my eyes fixed on pitch, so that I could see everything that was present in Bolgia and the people that had been burned inside."

Original: Come i dalfini, quando fanno segno a’ marinar con l’arco de la schiena che s’argomentin di campar lor legno,
Translate: "so we too can have a sign that indicates to take an action Like dolphins, when they emerge with their backs and provide the sailors with the necessary warning to save the ship, so we too can receive a warning to act."

Original: talor così, ad alleggiar la pena, mostrav’alcun de’ peccatori ’l dosso e nascondea in men che non balena
Translate: "In some cases, to soothe the punishments imposed on their crimes, some evildoers quickly sought refuge by showing their back anointed with pitch and thus avoiding any punishment."

Original: E come a l’orlo de l’acqua d’un fosso stanno i ranocchi pur col muso fuori, sì che celano i piedi e l’altro grosso,
Translate: "Like frogs, who hide their legs and the rest of the body in the water of a ditch with only the head visible above the water's hair."

Original: sì stavan d’ogne parte i peccatori
Translate: Sinners were present everywhere.

Original: ma come s’appressava Barbariccia, così si ritraén sotto i bollori
Translate: "as soon as Barbariccia approached, the poor wretches were brought back into the boiling pitch."

Original: I’ vidi, e anco il cor me n’accapriccia, uno aspettar così, com’elli ’ncontra ch’una rana rimane e l’altra spiccia
Translate: "I felt a moment of terror in my heart, when I saw an unhappy hesitant, just as if a frog had stopped in the middle of the water while the other was passing through it."

Original: e Graffiacan, che li era più di contra, li arruncigliò le ’mpegolate chiome e trassel sù, che mi parve una lontra
Translate: "Graffiacane, who stood before him, grabbed his paw and hooked his hair soaked in pitch and lifted it up as if it were an otter."

Original: I’ sapea già di tutti quanti ’l nome, sì li notai quando fuorono eletti, e poi ch’e’ si chiamaro, attesi come
Translate: "I remembered the names of all the demons, for I noted them when they were chosen and listened as they turned to one another."

Original: "O Rubicante, fa che tu li metti li unghioni a dosso, sì che tu lo scuoi", gridavan tutti insieme i maladetti
Translate: "The wicked were bewitched together, "Rubicant, grab him and subdue him!"

Original: E io: "Maestro mio, fa, se tu puoi, che tu sappi chi è lo sciagurato venuto a man de li avversari suoi"
Translate: I begged my master to make known the fate of the unhappy one who fell into the clutches of his enemies.

Original: Lo duca mio li s’accostò allato
Translate: My teacher approached his side.

Original: domandollo ond’ei fosse, e quei rispuose: "I’ fui del regno di Navarra nato
Translate: He asked her who she was, and she replied: "I was born in the kingdom of Navarre."

Original: Mia madre a servo d’un segnor mi puose, che m’avea generato d’un ribaldo, distruggitor di sé e di sue cose
Translate: "After I was raised by the backwaterer and suicide bomber, my mother entrusted me to a gentleman."

Original: Poi fui famiglia del buon re Tebaldo
Translate: "Afterward, I faithfully served the good king Thebald."

Original: quivi mi misi a far baratteria, di ch’io rendo ragione in questo caldo"
Translate: "I started practicing barterias here, so I paid my time under this sun."

Original: E Cirïatto, a cui di bocca uscia d’ogne parte una sanna come a porco, li fé sentir come l’una sdruscia
Translate: "And Cyriath, with a pair of tusks coming out of the joints of the jaws like in a wild boar, pressed his blades against the flesh and made him feel his presence."

Original: Tra male gatte era venuto ’l sorco
Translate: The mouse was at the mercy of evil cats.

Original: ma Barbariccia il chiuse con le braccia e disse: "State in là, mentr’io lo ’nforco"
Translate: "Barbariccia lifted up his arms and removed them, announcing: "You stay away while I pierc him."

Original: E al maestro mio volse la faccia
Translate: "The demon then turned to Virgil, exhorting him:"

Original: "Domanda", disse, "ancor, se più disii saper da lui, prima ch’altri ’l disfaccia"
Translate: "Ask him again, if you want to know more about him, before someone destroys him."

Original: Lo duca dunque: "Or dì: de li altri rii conosci tu alcun che sia latino sotto la pece?"
Translate: The teacher asked, "Do you know if Italians are among those condemned with boiling pitch?"

Original: E quelli: "I’ mi partii,  poco è, da un che fu di là vicino
Translate: I recently separated myself from someone from a neighbouring nation.

Original: Così foss’io ancor con lui coperto, ch’i’ non temerei unghia né uncino"
Translate: "If I were still at his side, protected from the effects of pitch, I would not be afraid of the claws and forks of the Malebranche."

Original: E Libicocco "Troppo avem sofferto", disse
Translate: "Libicocco exclaimed, "We've held back too long!""

Original: e preseli ’l braccio col runciglio, sì che, stracciando, ne portò un lacerto
Translate: "She grabbed his arm with a hook, ripping off a piece of meat."

Original: Draghignazzo anco i volle dar di piglio giuso a le gambe
Translate: Draghignazzo wanted to explode his victim's legs.

Original: onde ’l decurio loro si volse intorno intorno con mal piglio
Translate: But their supervisor took a severe look at all of them.

Original: Quand’elli un poco rappaciati fuoro, a lui, ch’ancor mirava sua ferita, domandò ’l duca mio sanza dimoro:
Translate: "After those present had calmed down, my teacher immediately asked the damned, still intent on staring at his plague:"

Original: "Chi fu colui da cui mala partita di’ che facesti per venire a proda?"
Translate: Who was the individual from whom you claim to have misdivided yourself before you got to shore?

Original: Ed ei rispuose: "Fu frate Gomita, quel di Gallura, vasel d’ogne froda, ch’ebbe i nemici di suo donno in mano, e fé sì lor, che ciascun se ne loda
Translate: "And he replied: "He had in his lord's hand the enemy of his friar Gomita, of Gallura, a clever and intelligent bandit. He treated them in such a way that every part benefited from it."

Original: Danar si tolse e lasciolli di piano, sì com’e’ dice
Translate: "HistoryAs history tells, he freed them easily after taking the money."

Original: e ne li altri offici anche barattier fu non picciol, ma sovrano
Translate: "He was a superior barter, in non-ordinary roles of responsibility."

Original: Usa con esso donno Michel Zanche di Logodoro
Translate: Usually Messer Michele Zanche of Logudoro is with him.

Original: e a dir di Sardigna le lingue lor non si sentono stanche
Translate: "Their words never cease to celebrate their beauty, when it comes to Sardinia."

Original: Omè, vedete l’altro che digrigna
Translate: "Alas, the devil shows his sharp teeth."

Original: i’ direi anche, ma i’ temo ch’ello non s’apparecchi a grattarmi la tigna"
Translate: "I don't want to suffer, so I won't say anything else for now."

Original: E ’l gran proposto, vòlto a Farfarello che stralunava li occhi per fedire, disse: "Fatti ’n costà, malvagio uccello"
Translate: "The powerful leader turned to Farfarello, who was waving his eyes with the intent of attacking, and said, "Stay away from me, you dark bird."

Original: "Se voi volete vedere o udire", ricominciò lo spaürato appresso, "Toschi o Lombardi, io ne farò venire
Translate: "If you want to meet people from Tuscany or Lombardy, I will bring them here."

Original: ma stieno i Malebranche un poco in cesso, sì ch’ei non teman de le lor vendette
Translate: Let's make sure the Malebronches stay a little back so that they don't arouse fear among the damned.

Original: e io, seggendo in questo loco stesso,  per un ch’io son, ne farò venir sette quand’io suffolerò, com’è nostro uso di fare allor che fori alcun si mette"
Translate: "I, from here in the background, in exchange for one person like I'm going to get seven of them out with a whistle, just like we always do when someone's risen from the abyss."

Original: Cagnazzo a cotal motto levò ’l muso, crollando ’l capo, e disse: "Odi malizia ch’elli ha pensata per gittarsi giuso"
Translate: "Bitch raised his head, shaking his head amazed at the words just heard, and at the cry of "Look what a deception he thought this time to slip into trouble!"," he exclaimed: "Listen how he wants to gabell under the pitch!."

Original: Ond’ei, ch’avea lacciuoli a gran divizia, rispuose: "Malizioso son io troppo, quand’io procuro a’ mia maggior trestizia"
Translate: "The scumbag, expert in the most ingenious plots to evade the twists, retorted: "I wouldn't be less if I added worries to my group."

Original: Alichin non si tenne e, di rintoppo a li altri, disse a lui: "Se tu ti cali, io non ti verrò dietro di gualoppo,  ma batterò sovra la pece l’ali
Translate: "Alichino, without delay, fought back to the damned: "I will be faster than you and I will chase you flying over the pitch, even if you decide to throw yourself."

Original: Lascisi ’l collo, e sia la ripa scudo, a veder se tu sol più di noi vali"
Translate: "Let's leave him alone and save ourselves behind the embankment, so we'll see if he can prove he's worth more than all of us."

Original: O tu che leggi, udirai nuovo ludo: ciascun da l’altra costa li occhi volse, quel prima, ch’a ciò fare era più crudo
Translate: "All the devils took a look at the opposite shore, even though the most hesitant one was struggling to do so. O reader, now be prepared to listen to the new comedy!"

Original: Lo Navarrese ben suo tempo colse
Translate: Navarrese quickly took advantage of the opportunity.

Original: fermò le piante a terra, e in un punto saltò e dal proposto lor si sciolse
Translate: He placed his feet on the rock and with a short jump in a few seconds managed to escape from the leader of the group.

Original: Di che ciascun di colpa fu compunto, ma quei più che cagion fu del difetto
Translate: "Everyone felt responsible for what happened, but above all the author of the gesture."

Original: però si mosse e gridò: "Tu se’ giunto"
Translate: "He stood still and yelled at the damned, "I caught you!""

Original: Ma poco i valse: ché l’ali al sospetto non potero avanzar
Translate: "Despite his wings, the barter was too fast to escape the man."

Original: quelli andò sotto, e quei drizzò volando suso il petto:
Translate: "He stooped and the demon flew up, rising proudly."

Original: non altrimenti l’anitra di botto, quando ’l falcon s’appressa, giù s’attuffa, ed ei ritorna sù crucciato e rotto
Translate: "Just like the duck that, when the falcon approaches, spurs quickly in the water to avoid the raptor, so the latter returns to high disappointed and tried."

Original: Irato Calcabrina de la buffa, volando dietro li tenne, invaghito che quei campasse per aver la zuffa
Translate: "Calcabrina, exasperated by the insult, followed him flying and hoped that the damned man would escape so as to fight with his friend."

Original: e come ’l barattier fu disparito, così volse li artigli al suo compagno, e fu con lui sopra ’l fosso ghermito
Translate: "After the barter disappeared, Alichino found his end when the claws of something grabbed him over the moat."

Original: Ma l’altro fu bene sparvier grifagno ad artigliar ben lui, e amendue cadder nel mezzo del bogliente stagno
Translate: "The other reacted quickly with the firmness of an adult hawk, and counterattacked him by clawing him. Both fell into the fiery liquid that boiled in the pitch pond."

Original: Lo caldo sghermitor sùbito fue
Translate: The heat moved them instantly to separate.

Original: ma però di levarsi era neente, sì avieno inviscate l’ali sue
Translate: "It was impossible to fly high, for their wings were covered with a thick layer of pitch."

Original: Barbariccia, con li altri suoi dolente, quattro ne fé volar da l’altra costa con tutt’i raffi,
Translate: "Barbariccia, shot down with the others, sent four of them to the other side with all the anchors."

Original: e assai prestamente  di qua, di là discesero a la posta
Translate: They moved quickly to their respective places.

Original: porser li uncini verso li ’mpaniati, ch’eran già cotti dentro da la crosta
Translate: "The hooks were offered to the two companions trapped, already boiled in the colorful surface of pitch."

Original: E noi lasciammo lor così ’mpacciati
Translate: and we got away from that difficult situation

Original: Taciti, soli, sanza compagnia n’andavam l’un dinanzi e l’altro dopo, come frati minor vanno per via
Translate: "We walked silent and lonely, without company, one after the other as Franciscan friars moving along the road."

Original: Vòlt’era in su la favola d’Isopo lo mio pensier per la presente rissa, dov’el parlò de la rana e del topo
Translate: "I, thinking of the fight we had witnessed, came to mind the exopic fairy tale of the frog and mouse."

Original: ché più non si pareggia ’mo’ e ’issa’ che l’un con l’altro fa, se ben s’accoppia principio e fine con la mente fissa
Translate: "If we stop to compare the first and the last part, emerges remarkable similarity between the two episodes like the one between ""mo"" and ""hissa""."

Original: E come l’un pensier de l’altro scoppia, così nacque di quello un altro poi, che la prima paura mi fé doppia
Translate: "As from one single idea came another, so from it arose another thought that multiplied the first anxiety."

Original: Io pensava così: ’Questi per noi sono scherniti con danno e con beffa sì fatta, ch’assai credo che lor nòi
Translate: ""I thought that our devils had been reviled with torment, in addition to the damage suffered, and I thought that it had annoyed them not little."

Original: Se l’ira sovra ’l mal voler s’aggueffa, ei ne verranno dietro più crudeli che ’l cane a quella lievre ch’elli acceffa’
Translate: "If anger mixes with malice, they will pursue more fiercely than the dog who wants to catch the hare."

Original: Già mi sentia tutti arricciar li peli de la paura e stava in dietro intento, quand’io dissi: "Maestro, se non celi  te e me tostamente, i’ ho pavento d’i Malebranche
Translate: "I turned back with terror when, afraid, I exclaimed: "Master, we must hide very soon or the Malebranches will make us their prey!"

Original: Noi li avem già dietro
Translate: They're always on us.

Original: io li ’magino sì, che già li sento"
Translate: I feel them like I'm already in front of them.

Original: E quei: "S’i’ fossi di piombato vetro, l’imagine di fuor tua non trarrei più tosto a me, che quella dentro ’mpetro
Translate: "He thought that, if it were a mirror, he would reflect his inner image even before his outward appearance."

Original: Pur mo venieno i tuo’ pensier tra ’ miei, con simile atto e con simile faccia, sì che d’intrambi un sol consiglio fei
Translate: "Your thoughts and ideas met in the same way, with the same attitude and appearance, leading to a single conclusion."

Original: S’elli è che sì la destra costa giaccia, che noi possiam ne l’altra bolgia scendere, noi fuggirem l’imaginata caccia"
Translate: "There will be less resistance if we go down to the right, which will allow us to reach the other Bolgia and thus we will avoid the persecution you predicted."

Original: Già non compié di tal consiglio rendere, ch’io li vidi venir con l’ali tese non molto lungi, per volerne prendere
Translate: "He did not have the opportunity to finish what he was saying, for I noticed the Malebranches heading towards us with their wings spread a short distance, to take us."

Original: Lo duca mio di sùbito mi prese, come la madre ch’al romore è desta e vede presso a sé le fiamme accese,
Translate: "My teacher reacted quickly, like a mother who is suddenly awakened from the noise and sees the flames nearby."

Original: che prende il figlio e fugge e non s’arresta, avendo più di lui che di sé cura, tanto che solo una camiscia vesta
Translate: "And so, worrying more about her little son than about herself, she grabs the child and runs out of the house without stopping for a moment, dressing only a shirt."

Original: e giù dal collo de la ripa dura supin si diede a la pendente roccia, che l’un de’ lati a l’altra bolgia tura
Translate: He jumped back from the top of the embankment along the rocky slope that divided a part of the Bolgia.

Original: Non corse mai sì tosto acqua per doccia a volger ruota di molin terragno, quand’ella più verso le pale approccia,
Translate: Never has water rushed so fast down a conduit to move an earthen mill wheel, when it is closest to the blades

Original: come ’l maestro mio per quel vivagno, portandosene me sovra ’l suo petto, come suo figlio, non come compagno
Translate: "to play while my teacher went down that bank, holding me to his chest as if I were a son, not just a friend of the game."

Original: A pena fuoro i piè suoi giunti al letto del fondo giù, ch’e’ furon in sul colle sovresso noi

Original: ma non lì era sospetto:
Translate: "At that point, there was no need to worry anymore."

Original: ché l’alta provedenza che lor volle porre ministri de la fossa quinta, poder di partirs’indi a tutti tolle
Translate: "High providence, by assigning them as guardians of the fifth Bolgia, prevented them from abandoning it."

Original: Là giù trovammo una gente dipinta che giva intorno assai con lenti passi, piangendo e nel sembiante stanca e vinta

Original: Elli avean cappe con cappucci bassi dinanzi a li occhi, fatte de la taglia che in Clugnì per li monaci fassi

Original: Di fuor dorate son, sì ch’elli abbaglia

Original: Oh in etterno faticoso manto
Translate: An Eternal Weight to Carry

Translate: "We changed direction to the left with them, listening to their weeping lamentation."

Original: ma per lo peso quella gente stanca venìa sì pian, che noi eravam nuovi di compagnia ad ogne mover d’anca
Translate: "Those people, because of their plentiful weight, proceeded so slowly that each step brought in the company of new people."

Original: E un che ’ntese la parola tosca, di retro a noi gridò:

Translate: "Stop, you who are running in the dark air!"

Original: Forse ch’avrai da me quel che tu chiedi"
Translate: You could have what you asked for from me.

Translate: "The teacher then turned to them and prayed to wait, adding that they should adjust their step to theirs."

Original: Ristetti, e vidi due mostrar gran fretta de l’animo, col viso, d’esser meco

Original: ma tardavali ’l carco e la via stretta
Translate: the mass of the hoods and the narrow road limited them

Translate: "When they came to us, they searched me for a long time with a suspicious expression, without saying a word."

Translate: "They looked at each other, then they said, "This person seems to be alive as the neck is waving."

Translate: "Write among these hypocrites sad, O Tuscan, reveal us who you are"

Original: E io a loro: "I’ fui nato e cresciuto sovra ’l bel fiume d’Arno a la gran villa, e son col corpo ch’i’ ho sempre avuto
Translate: "I was born and raised in the great city on the Arno, and still now I keep my fragile mortal body."

Translate: The crucifix watched by the Pharisees suggested that it would be better to sacrifice one person for the good of the people.

Translate: "The ancient priests of the Sanhedrin, including the father-in-law of the speaker, are paid with the same measure of their wrongdoing against the Jewish people, a sentence that has brought heavy consequences."

Translate: "and then from a door in the middle of the wall"So he stated that there was a pier, starting from the outer perimeter and crossing all the trenches in the darkness, which led to an entrance in the center of the wall."

Translate: "On this Bolgia is no longer present any overhanging, having collapsed."

Translate: You can climb the rock cliff that is on the wall and piled up on the bottom.

Translate: "With the arrival of the season and the constellation of Aquarius, the sun gets warmer and the days are getting longer than nights."

Translate: "When the image of a white frost remembers that of her sister, but they lack her ink pen to write with."

Translate: "While the farmer stands up in the hope that something has taken away his concern about the forage, looking out sees a snowy countryside."

Original: ond’ei si batte l’anca,  ritorna in casa, e qua e là si lagna, come ’l tapin che non sa che si faccia
Translate: "then you hit the palm of your hand, go back to the house, complaining here and there, like the poor man who is in the dark about what to do."

Translate: "When I saw the master with such a troubled expression, he made me whiten on my face, but fortunately the solution to the problem presented itself just as quickly."

Translate: Coveting fame is not obtained simply by settling on the pillows or by stretching the blankets.

Translate: "Whoever spends his life without leaving a sign of himself, like smoke in the air or foam on the water, leaves no indelible trace on Earth."

Translate: "Win fatigue with the courage that overcomes all obstacles, even if the forces are lacking."

Translate: We must face a more challenging challenge.

Original: non basta da costoro esser partito
Translate: we no longer have any connection or affiliation with these unhappy

Original: Se tu mi ’ntendi, or fa sì che ti vaglia"

Translate: "We headed on the rocky bridge, which was impervious and narrow, making the road rather difficult; moreover it had a much greater inclination than the previous one."

Original: Parlando andava per non parer fievole
Translate: "SlowlyIn order not to look tired, I spoke quietly."

Original: onde una voce uscì de l’altro fosso, a parole formar disconvenevole

Original: Non so che disse, ancor che sovra ’l dosso fossi de l’arco già che varca quivi

Original: ma chi parlava ad ire parea mosso

Translate: "I was looking down, but my watchful eyes couldn't see the deep darkness underneath."

Translate: From this point I can't hear any sound and nothing I can see if I look down.

Original: ché la dimanda onesta si de’ seguir con l’opera tacendo"

Original: e vidivi entro terribile stipa di serpenti, e di sì diversa mena che la memoria il sangue ancor mi scipa
Translate: "I had a terrible memory of snakes intertwined, so different from each other that I shuddered."

Original: Più non si vanti Libia con sua rena

Original: ché se chelidri, iaculi e faree produce, e cencri con anfisibena,
Translate: "Since they were produced kerinthids, iaculi, fairy tales, cencri and anphysibenei."

Translate: He never showed such a number of weeds throughout Ethiopia in addition to the area around the Red Sea.

Original: con serpi le man dietro avean legate

Translate: "Never a ""o" or a ""i" were written faster than this one lit, burned and then became ash falling to the ground."

Translate: "After touching the ground in such a weakened form, the ash recomposes itself and the damned one immediately had the appearance he had before."

Translate: "It is said that the phoenix, close to the five hundred years of age, perishes and then succeeds in resurrecting."

Translate: "So he fell down as well, going down like a rock, without knowing the reason, as if they were devils to drag him down or something similar to hindering his vital energy; so also happened to the protagonist."

Original: tal era ’l peccator levato poscia

Original: Oh potenza di Dio, quant’è severa, che cotai colpi per vendetta croscia
Translate: "Oh, divine sovereign, how relentless you are in your punishment for your vengeance!"

Translate: "AnglingThe teacher, with tears in his eyes, asked the condemned to identify himself"

Translate: "He replied: "Since I arrived from Tuscany, I am in this heinous pit."

Translate: "I had a predilection for the existence of an animal rather than that of a human being, just like the illegitimate son I was."

Original: son Vanni Fucci bestia, e Pistoia mi fu degna tana"
Translate: "My name is Vanni Fucci, but I am known as the beast; Pistoia was the house where I spent my life."

Translate: Ask Virgil to make him understand that he does not run away and question him about what sin he has brought him to this place.

Original: ch’io ’l vidi omo di sangue e di crucci"

Translate: "It was with great regret that he admitted that he was torn from mortal life, rather than being seen in that sad situation."

Translate: "If you want to enjoy the vision that these dark places contain, you must listen to my prophecy before leaving them."

Original: Pistoia in pria d’i Neri si dimagra
Translate: Before the exile of the Black Guelphs in Pistoia

Original: poi Fiorenza rinova gente e modi

Translate: "As a flash, the fog will be lightened and every White Knight will have his wounds."

Translate: I said that with the intent of making you suffer.

Translate: "The snakes began to establish a bond with me from that moment, as if one wanted to let them know that she didn't want me to talk again by wrapping around my neck."

Translate: She tied another rope around his arms and held it so tight that he couldn't move a single muscle.

Translate: "Alas, Pistoia, why do you not decide to destroy yourself so as to cease to exist, since you have overcome the filthiness committed by your ancestors?"

Translate: "I never saw, even among the deepest circles of hell, such an overwhelming spirit in opposition to God as that which escaped from the walls of Thebes."

Original: El si fuggì che non parlò più verbo

Translate: "and I saw a centaur full of irritation, who was calling him."

Translate: I do not think that the Maremma counts a number of bisces comparable to those that were agitating on the back to the point where it meets the human aspect.

Translate: A dragon with spread wings lay on his shoulders and behind the back of the head.

Original: e quello affuoca qualunque s’intoppa
Translate: and that arouses enthusiasm in everyone you meet

Translate: "My instructor said, "That's Caco, who repeated under the Aventine was filling a basin with blood."

Original: Non va co’ suoi fratei per un cammino, per lo furto che frodolente fece del grande armento ch’elli ebbe a vicino
Translate: It is not with his centaur brothers for the scam he committed against the vast herd of animals in his vicinity.

Original: onde cessar le sue opere biece sotto la mazza d’Ercule, che forse gliene diè cento, e non sentì le diece"
Translate: "Under the strength of the club of Hercules, the evil deeds of him came to cease; it is said that Hercules struck him a hundred strokes before he fell dead after the ninth."

Original: Mentre che sì parlava, ed el trascorse, e tre spiriti venner sotto noi, de’ quai né io né ’l duca mio s’accorse,
Translate: "While Virgil was speaking and Caco had gone away, three spirits appeared under us but neither of them realized it."

Original: se non quando gridar: "Chi siete voi?"
Translate: When they heard shouting, "Who are you?"

Original: per che nostra novella si ristette, e intendemmo pur ad essi poi
Translate: We stopped talking, and we must listen to them.

Original: Io non li conoscea
Translate: I didn't recognize them.

Original: ma ei seguette, come suol seguitar per alcun caso, che l’un nomar un altro convenette,  dicendo: "Cianfa dove fia rimaso?"
Translate: "and suddenly, as often happens by chance, someone asked: "Where did Cianfa end up?"

Original: per ch’io, acciò che ’l duca stesse attento, mi puosi ’l dito su dal mento al naso
Translate: I raised my index finger from my chin to my nose to capture his attention and silence him.

Original: Se tu se’ or, lettore, a creder lento ciò ch’io dirò, non sarà maraviglia, ché io che ’l vidi, a pena il mi consento
Translate: "If you, reader, are skeptical of what I'm about to tell you, you shouldn't be too surprised because I too had trouble believing the scene that was generated in front of me."

Original: Com’io tenea levate in lor le ciglia, e un serpente con sei piè si lancia dinanzi a l’uno, e tutto a lui s’appiglia
Translate: "As I watched them carefully, a six-legged snake violently struck one of them, clinging to hell."

Original: Co’ piè di mezzo li avvinse la pancia e con li anterïor le braccia prese
Translate: "He clinged to his belly with his legs, while his forelegs held his arms firmly."

Original: poi li addentò e l’una e l’altra guancia
Translate: then gave him two kisses on both cheeks

Original: li diretani a le cosce distese, e miseli la coda tra ’mbedue e dietro per le ren sù la ritese
Translate: "He spread his back feet on his thighs and arched his tail until he put it in the middle of his back, with his end pointing upwards."

Original: Ellera abbarbicata mai non fue ad alber sì, come l’orribil fiera per l’altrui membra avviticchiò le sue
Translate: .The ivy never clings to a tree as the repellent serpent had enveloped the members of the condemned.

Original: Poi s’appiccar, come di calda cera fossero stati, e mischiar lor colore, né l’un né l’altro già parea quel ch’era:
Translate: "They clinged to each other, as if they had been merged together, and their differences mixed in a single indistinct dye; neither was recognizable as before."

Original: come procede innanzi da l’ardore, per lo papiro suso, un color bruno che non è nero ancora e ’l bianco more
Translate: "When a white paper is burned, the flame rises creating shades of color ranging from white to black."

Original: Li altri due ’l riguardavano, e ciascuno gridava: "Omè, Agnel, come ti muti
Translate: "!"The other two stared at the scene, while they exclaimed simultaneously: "Oh no! Lamb, how you changed your appearance!"

Original: Vedi che già non se’ né due né uno"
Translate: "You're not alone anymore, but you're not two yet."

Original: Già eran li due capi un divenuti, quando n’apparver due figure miste in una faccia, ov’eran due perduti
Translate: "The two figures that appeared to us were one, with the face in half divided: the features and the aspects of the two heads had blended together."

Original: Fersi le braccia due di quattro liste
Translate: The four members joined together to form only two arms.

Original: le cosce con le gambe e ’l ventre e ’l casso divenner membra che non fuor mai viste
Translate: "Body parts like thighs, legs, belly and chest became elements that had never been noticed before."

Original: Ogne primaio aspetto ivi era casso: due e nessun l’imagine perversa parea
Translate: Every original track had been erased; the horrible glimpse seemed that there was no one.

Original: e tal sen gio con lento passo
Translate: that being strayed at a slow pace

Original: Come 'l ramarro sotto la gran fersa dei dì canicular, cangiando sepe, folgore par se la via attraversa,
Translate: "Like lightning under the hot summer sun, the frog splashes from one hedge to another, as quick as a flash."

Original: sì pareva, venendo verso l’epe de li altri due, un serpentello acceso, livido e nero come gran di pepe
Translate: "It was like a furious snake crawling rapidly toward the belly of the other two, pale and dark as a grain of pepper."

Original: e quella parte onde prima è preso nostro alimento, a l’un di lor trafisse
Translate: The animal sank its teeth in the part from which we take the initial nourishment of one of the two.

Original: poi cadde giuso innanzi lui disteso
Translate: Then the reptile fell to the ground before his eyes.

Original: Lo trafitto ’l mirò, ma nulla disse
Translate: "He looked at the damned, bitten, without uttering a word."

Original: anzi, co’ piè fermati, sbadigliava pur come sonno o febbre l’assalisse
Translate: "he was wandering like he was overwhelmed by fatigue, even standing perfectly still."

Original: Elli ’l serpente e quei lui riguardava
Translate: He and the snake looked at each other.

Original: l’un per la piaga e l’altro per la bocca fummavan forte, e ’l fummo si scontrava
Translate: "The two of them emitted smoke, a plague sent his to heaven, and the tongue of the serpent produced his, stirring in the air."

Original: Taccia Lucano omai là dov’e’ tocca del misero Sabello e di Nasidio, e attenda a udir quel ch’or si scocca
Translate: "Lucano should be careful to talk about the miseries of Sabello and Nasidio, and be vigilant about what is narrated here."

Original: Taccia di Cadmo e d’Aretusa Ovidio, ché se quello in serpente e quella in fonte converte poetando, io non lo ’nvidio
Translate: "Ovidio no longer speaks of Cadmos and Aretusa, for if he turned them into a serpent and a fountain, I would certainly not envy him."

Original: ché due nature mai a fronte a fronte non trasmutò sì ch’amendue le forme a cambiar lor matera fosser pronte
Translate: "He never created two figures that faced each other, so that each one of them could modify their own materials."

Original: Insieme si rispuosero a tai norme, che ’l serpente la coda in forca fesse, e ’l feruto ristrinse insieme l’orme
Translate: "At the same time, they transformed themselves in such a way that the serpent divided the tail in half and the man put his feet together."

Original: Le gambe con le cosce seco stesse s’appiccar sì, che ’n poco la giuntura non facea segno alcun che si paresse
Translate: PartsThe legs and thighs merged so tightly that soon there was no division between the two elements.

Original: Togliea la coda fessa la figura che si perdeva là, e la sua pelle si facea molle, e quella di là dura
Translate: "The tail forked in two, taking the shape that the man was losing, and his coat of fur began to become soft while that of the man became harder."

Original: Io vidi intrar le braccia per l’ascelle, e i due piè de la fiera, ch’eran corti, tanto allungar quanto accorciavan quelle
Translate: "I watched the man holding his arms to his chest, while the short legs of the animal seemed to stretch as his arms shortened."

Original: Poscia li piè di rietro, insieme attorti, diventaron lo membro che l’uom cela, e ’l misero del suo n’avea due porti
Translate: "The hind legs of the serpent interwoven together to form the organ that man tries to hide, unlike the unfortunate demon who had its part divided in two."

Original: Mentre che ’l fummo l’uno e l’altro vela di color novo, e genera ’l pel suso per l’una parte e da l’altra il dipela,
Translate: "While the smoke wrapped both with a new nuance, it gave one of them the hair while the other was removing it."

Original: l’un si levò e l’altro cadde giuso, non torcendo però le lucerne empie, sotto le quai ciascun cambiava muso
Translate: "One of the two stood while the other collapsed on the ground, and despite all the two continued to cross with evil looks, each masking his own expression."

Original: Quel ch’era dritto, il trasse ver’ le tempie, e di troppa matera ch’in là venne uscir li orecchi de le gote scempie
Translate: "Being standing raised the chin toward the temples, and two ears appeared on the cheeks as if they had never been absent."

Original: ciò che non corse in dietro e si ritenne di quel soverchio, fé naso a la faccia e le labbra ingrossò quanto convenne
Translate: "Of that excess matter, a face was molded with nose and lips that grew until they got to the right size."

Original: Quel che giacëa, il muso innanzi caccia, e li orecchi ritira per la testa come face le corna la lumaccia
Translate: The creature on the ground thrust its muzzle forward and withdrew its ears into its head, like a snail withdrew its horns

Original: e la lingua, ch’avëa unita e presta prima a parlar, si fende, e la forcuta ne l’altro si richiude
Translate: "While the other kept his forked tongue closed, the one he had once joined and was ready to be used divided into two."

Original: e ’l fummo resta
Translate: The smoke vanished.

Original: L’anima ch’era fiera divenuta, suffolando si fugge per la valle, e l’altro dietro a lui parlando sputa
Translate: "The soul turned into a serpent drove away along the Bolgia, wheezing; the other followed him with words and spits."

Original: Poscia li volse le novelle spalle, e disse a l’altro: "I’ vo’ che Buoso corra, com’ ho fatt’io, carpon per questo calle"
Translate: "With rigid shoulders, Buoso was addressed by the other with these words: "Please take the same test as I did, running all the way to this area."

Original: Così vid’io la settima zavorra mutare e trasmutare
Translate: I saw how the evildoers of the Seventh Bolgia changed and converted.

Original: e qui mi scusi la novità se fior la penna abborra
Translate: I apologize if my handwriting is grammatical because of the absolute inexperience.

Original: E avvegna che li occhi miei confusi fossero alquanto e l’animo smagato, non poter quei fuggirsi tanto chiusi,  ch’i’ non scorgessi ben Puccio Sciancato
Translate: "Even though I was confused and lost, I couldn't help but recognize Puccio Sciancato when he tried to escape in secret."

Original: ed era quel che sol, di tre compagni che venner prima, non era mutato
Translate: "of the three friends who had initially arrived there, he was the only one who didn't change shape."

Original: l’altr’era quel che tu, Gaville, piagni
Translate: "You, Gaville, were complaining about that other guy."

Original: Godi, Fiorenza, poi che se' sì grande che per mare e per terra batti l'ali, e per lo 'nferno tuo nome si spande
Translate: "Drink, Florence, for your fame reaches all where, from the sea to the earth to the kingdom below; and your name is in the mouth of Hell."

Original: Tra li ladron trovai cinque cotali tuoi cittadini onde mi ven vergogna, e tu in grande orranza non ne sali
Translate: "I met five of your fellow citizens among thieves, this circumstance embarrasses me and certainly brings you no honor."

Original: Ma se presso al mattin del ver si sogna, tu sentirai, di qua da picciol tempo, di quel che Prato, non ch’altri, t’agogna
Translate: "If dreams made at dawn are true, not long afterward you will face the sanctions that even Prato and other smaller cities have in store for you."

Original: E se già fosse, non saria per tempo
Translate: "Even if it had already happened, it would still be too late."

Original: Così foss’ei, da che pur esser dee
Translate: "If it were inevitable, it would have happened already."

Original: ché più mi graverà, com’ più m’attempo
Translate: "As I grow old, this punishment will become increasingly intolerable."

Original: Noi ci partimmo, e su per le scalee che n’avea fatto iborni a scender pria, rimontò ’l duca mio e trasse mee
Translate: "We walked away, and the master made a bold ascent on those rocks that had been so impressive that we were only shaking at the thought of having to go down. He took me with him."

Original: e proseguendo la solinga via, tra le schegge e tra ’ rocchi de lo scoglio lo piè sanza la man non si spedia
Translate: "While he continued along the desolate way, his path was hindered by the edges and shards of rock that could not be overcome without the help of the hands."

Original: Allor mi dolsi, e ora mi ridoglio quando drizzo la mente a ciò ch’io vidi, e più lo ’ngegno affreno ch’i’ non soglio,  perché non corra che virtù nol guidi
Translate: "Afterwards I suffered, and I continue to do so by reminding myself of what I saw; I strive to refrain from acting without being guided by virtuosity."

Original: sì che, se stella bona o miglior cosa m’ ha dato ’l ben, ch’io stessi nol m’invidi
Translate: "If I have had, through a beneficial heavenly passage or even something even more significant, the blessing of joy toward me, I will not try to keep myself from myself."

Original: Quante ’l villan ch’al poggio si riposa, nel tempo che colui che ’l mondo schiara la faccia sua a noi tien meno ascosa,
Translate: "The farmer, while resting on the hill in the darkest season of the year, can admire a large number of fireflies shine in the night sky."

Original: come la mosca cede a la zanzara, vede lucciole giù per la vallea, forse colà dov’e’ vendemmia e ara:
Translate: "While the fly was leaving its place to the mosquito, he could see in the valley, where it was harvesting and plowing."

Original: di tante fiamme tutta risplendea l’ottava bolgia, sì com’io m’accorsi tosto che fui là ’ve ’l fondo parea
Translate: "I immediately saw that as many flames shone in the eighth Bolgia, once arrived at that point where it was possible to see the bottom."

Original: E qual colui che si vengiò con li orsi vide ’l carro d’Elia al dipartire, quando i cavalli al cielo erti levorsi,
Translate: "When Elijah decided to leave in a horse-drawn chariot, who had risen in flight very high in the sky, as if he had been the avenger of bears to watch,"

Original: che nol potea sì con li occhi seguire, ch’el vedesse altro che la fiamma sola, sì come nuvoletta, in sù salire:
Translate: "and couldn't follow him with his gaze without seeing only the flame, rising as fast as a small cloud."

Original: tal si move ciascuna per la gola del fosso, ché nessuna mostra ’l furto, e ogne fiamma un peccatore invola
Translate: "so in the bottom of the Bolgia every flame was seen, without being able to see what was hidden within it, and these flames contained sinners."

Original: Io stava sovra ’l ponte a veder surto, sì che s’io non avessi un ronchion preso, caduto sarei giù sanz’esser urto
Translate: "While I was leaning from the bridge to look down, I was forced to hold the grip on a rocky grip or else I would fall down without touching anything."

Original: E ’l duca, che mi vide tanto atteso, disse: "Dentro dai fuochi son li spirti
Translate: "There, among those flames, live souls," said the master, observing me carefully."

Original: catun si fascia di quel ch’elli è inceso"
Translate: each is surrounded by the fire that envelops it

Original: "Maestro mio", rispuos’io, "per udirti son io più certo
Translate: "After listening to my teacher's words, I became even more convinced."

Original: ma già m’era avviso che così fosse, e già voleva dirti:
Translate: I had already predicted that it would be like this and I was wondering:

Original: chi è ’n quel foco che vien sì diviso di sopra, che par surger de la pira dov’Eteòcle col fratel fu miso?"
Translate: "Who is in the flames, from the top divided into two points, who seem to rise from a funeral pyre where Etheocles and his brother were placed?"

Original: Rispuose a me: "Là dentro si martira Ulisse e Dïomede, e così insieme a la vendetta vanno come a l’ira
Translate: "Ulysses and Diomedes are punished in that place, both being condemned to bear the consequences of their crimes. I was answered."

Original: e dentro da la lor fiamma si geme l’agguato del caval che fé la porta onde uscì de’ Romani il gentil seme
Translate: "In their flame, they expose the betrayal of the famous Trojan horse that gave rise to the descendants of the Roman nobles."

Original: Piangevisi entro l’arte per che, morta, Deïdamìa ancor si duol d’Achille, e del Palladio pena vi si porta"
Translate: "Although Deidamia is dead, she is forced to regret Achilles as a result of the punishment inflicted on her scam and the theft of Palladio."

Original: "S’ei posson dentro da quelle faville parlar", diss’io, "maestro, assai ten priego e ripriego, che ’l priego vaglia mille,
Translate: "I implored my teacher, repeatedly begging him fervently for my prayer to have a value of a thousand if it had been possible for them to speak out of those flames."

Original: che non mi facci de l’attender niego fin che la fiamma cornuta qua vegna
Translate: May I hope that that two-burning ardor will come down here.

Original: vedi che del disio ver’ lei mi piego"
Translate: I incline my body towards her by desire.

Original: Ed elli a me: "La tua preghiera è degna di molta loda, e io però l’accetto
Translate: "He approved of my prayer with great admiration, and decided to accept it."

Original: ma fa che la tua lingua si sostegna
Translate: You have to refrain from saying something inappropriate.

Original: Lascia parlare a me, ch’i’ ho concetto ciò che tu vuoi
Translate: "Let me explain, for I know exactly what you mean."

Original: ch’ei sarebbero schivi, perch’e’ fuor greci, forse del tuo detto"
Translate: "Being Greek states, they may be reluctant to open up to you."

Original: Poi che la fiamma fu venuta quivi dove parve al mio duca tempo e loco, in questa forma lui parlare audivi:
Translate: "When the flame reached the point where my teacher had decided as a suitable time and place, I heard him utter the following words."

Original: "O voi che siete due dentro ad un foco, s’io meritai di voi mentre ch’io vissi, s’io meritai di voi assai o poco  quando nel mondo li alti versi scrissi, non vi movete
Translate: O you who are two in a single flame, if I have acquired merits towards you when I was alive, if I have acquired great or small merits with you when, on Earth, I wrote the high verses, do not go away

Original: ma l’un di voi dica dove, per lui, perduto a morir gissi"
Translate: Can any of you tell us where your journey without return has ended?

Original: Lo maggior corno de la fiamma antica cominciò a crollarsi mormorando, pur come quella cui vento affatica
Translate: "The ancient top of that flame was upset by murmuring, as if it had been hit by a flow of air."

Original: indi la cima qua e là menando, come fosse la lingua che parlasse, gittò voce di fuori e disse:
Translate: "So when he moved his head from one side to the other, as if he were speaking, he put out his voice and said: "

Original: "Quando  mi diparti’ da Circe, che sottrasse me più d’un anno là presso a Gaeta, prima che sì Enëa la nomasse,
Translate: When I left Circe, who kept me more than a year there near Gaeta, before Aeneas gave this name to the promontory,

Original: né dolcezza di figlio, né la pieta del vecchio padre, né ’l debito amore lo qual dovea Penelopè far lieta,
Translate: "Neither affection for my son, nor deep respect for my old father, nor the legitimate devotion that should have made Penelope happy."

Original: vincer potero dentro a me l’ardore ch’i’ ebbi a divenir del mondo esperto e de li vizi umani e del valore
Translate: "I have cultivated the desire to gain knowledge of the reality of the world, its weaknesses and moral qualities."

Original: ma misi me per l’alto mare aperto sol con un legno e con quella compagna picciola da la qual non fui diserto
Translate: I boarded a ship with a few loyal companions who never left me.

Original: L’un lito e l’altro vidi infin la Spagna, fin nel Morrocco, e l’isola d’i Sardi, e l’altre che quel mare intorno bagna
Translate: "I had the opportunity to admire, from Spain to Morocco through Sardinia and the other islands of the Mediterranean, both the shores of that sea."

Original: Io e’ compagni eravam vecchi e tardi quando venimmo a quella foce stretta dov’Ercule segnò li suoi riguardi  acciò che l’uom più oltre non si metta
Translate: "We, old and weak as we were, came to the point where Hercules had placed the columns of Hercules - the last limit to the known world of man."

Original: da la man destra mi lasciai Sibilia, da l’altra già m’avea lasciata Setta
Translate: "To the east, we had Seville; to the west, Ceuta."

Original: "O frati," dissi, "che per cento milia perigli siete giunti a l’occidente,
Translate: "I exclaimed: "Brothers, you have faced a hundred thousand perils to reach the extreme west!"

Original: a questa tanto picciola vigilia  d’i nostri sensi ch’è del rimanente non vogliate negar l’esperïenza, di retro al sol, del mondo sanza gente
Translate: "Do not deny the vigil, which is still in your senses, the possibility of experiencing the desolate world by taking the western direction."

Original: Considerate la vostra semenza: fatti non foste a viver come bruti, ma per seguir virtute e canoscenza"
Translate: "Remember your origin: you were not created to lead a beastly life, but rather to walk on the way of virtue and knowledge."

Original: Li miei compagni fec’io sì aguti, con questa orazion picciola, al cammino, che a pena poscia li avrei ritenuti
Translate: With my little words it took me to ensure that the desire of my companions to leave became untenable: later I would have struggled to hold them.

Original: e volta nostra poppa nel mattino, de’ remi facemmo ali al folle volo, sempre acquistando dal lato mancino
Translate: "Wiring the stern eastward, we used the oars as wings for our crazy flight southwest."

Original: Tutte le stelle già de l’altro polo vedea la notte, e ’l nostro tanto basso, che non surgëa fuor del marin suolo
Translate: "In the starry sky it was possible to admire the constellations of the southern pole, while those of the northern hemisphere were so low on the horizon that they were not visible."

Original: Cinque volte racceso e tante casso lo lume era di sotto da la luna, poi che 'ntrati eravam ne l'alto passo,
Translate: "Since we started our journey, the moonlight visible to us had been turned off and rekindled five times."

Original: quando n’apparve una montagna, bruna per la distanza, e parvemi alta tanto quanto veduta non avëa alcuna
Translate: "Away, an imposing dark mountain stood on the horizon, higher than any other we had ever observed."

Original: Noi ci allegrammo, e tosto tornò in pianto
Translate: The initial joy quickly turned into tears.

Original: ché de la nova terra un turbo nacque e percosse del legno il primo canto
Translate: "The ship suffered a little in front of that land, with the storm coming."

Original: Tre volte il fé girar con tutte l’acque
Translate: "She turned on herself three times, in a whirlwind."

Original: a la quarta levar la poppa in suso e la prora ire in giù, com’altrui piacque,  infin che ’l mar fu sovra noi richiuso"
Translate: "The fourth time, he lifted up his stern and took the bow, to the pleasure of others, until the sea had overlaid itself upon us."

Original: Già era dritta in sù la fiamma e queta per non dir più, e già da noi sen gia con la licenza del dolce poeta,
Translate: "The flame, now still, did not sound; the sweet poet had allowed her to depart from us."

Original: quand’un’altra, che dietro a lei venìa, ne fece volger li occhi a la sua cima per un confuso suon che fuor n’uscia
Translate: "When, from its most advanced point, a second ship forced us to take a look at it as a result of the noise that came."

Original: Come ’l bue cicilian che mugghiò prima col pianto di colui, e ciò fu dritto, che l’avea temperato con sua lima,  mugghiava con la voce de l’afflitto,
Translate: "As a scream of anguish, the Sicilian ox mugged for the first time with the voice of his creator, the one who had shaped him with fatigue and suffering."

Original: sì che, con tutto che fosse di rame, pur el pareva dal dolor trafitto
Translate: He seemed to be suffering even though he was made of copper.

Original: così, per non aver via né forame dal principio nel foco, in suo linguaggio si convertïan le parole grame
Translate: "Uncertain words have been transformed into a tongue of flames, for they did not know how to get out of their initial state."

Original: Ma poscia ch’ebber colto lor vïaggio su per la punta, dandole quel guizzo che dato avea la lingua in lor passaggio,  udimmo dire:
Translate: "Once they had found a way to pass through the tip, moving it like a tongue at their passage, we heard:"

Original: "O tu a cu’ io drizzo la voce e che parlavi mo lombardo, dicendo "Istra ten va, più non t’adizzo",
Translate: "To the one to whom I addressed the word, who only a few minutes ago uttered words in Italian Now go', I don't provoke you anymore, since then"

Original: perch’io sia giunto forse alquanto tardo, non t’incresca restare a parlar meco
Translate: Don't worry about talking to me any longer just because I got a little late.

Original: vedi che non incresce a me, e ardo
Translate: "despite I don't mind, I'm burning in flames"

Original: Se tu pur mo in questo mondo cieco caduto se’ di quella dolce terra latina ond’io mia colpa tutta reco,  dimmi se Romagnuoli han pace o guerra
Translate: "If you have arrived in this dark world from that sweet Italian land, for which I am responsible, tell me whether the Romagnoli are well or need peace."

Original: ch’io fui d’i monti là intra Orbino e ’l giogo di che Tever si diserra"
Translate: I was once between the hills of Urbino and the highest point from which the Tiber flows.

Original: Io era in giuso ancora attento e chino, quando il mio duca mi tentò di costa, dicendo:
Translate: "While I was leaning on the bridge, my guide touched my side and exclaimed:"

Original: "Parla tu questi è latino"
Translate: "You do the word, this is in Italian."

Original: E io, ch’avea già pronta la risposta, sanza indugio a parlare incominciai:
Translate: "I, prepared to answer, started my conversation without delay."

Original: "O anima che se’ là giù nascosta,  Romagna tua non è, e non fu mai, sanza guerra ne’ cuor de’ suoi tiranni
Translate: "Oh, soul buried in fire over there, is Romagna always subject to wars in the hearts of his oppressors?"

Original: ma ’n palese nessuna or vi lasciai
Translate: I didn't involve her in any explicit war.

Original: Ravenna sta come stata è molt’anni: l’aguglia da Polenta la si cova, sì che Cervia ricuopre co’ suoi vanni
Translate: "For many years, the Da Polenta Eagle has dominated Ravenna and its wings have spread over Cervia."

Original: La terra che fé già la lunga prova e di Franceschi sanguinoso mucchio, sotto le branche verdi si ritrova
Translate: "Under the banner of the green rampant lion, the city resisted the prolonged siege and fled the French army."

Original: E ’l mastin vecchio e ’l nuovo da Verrucchio, che fecer di Montagna il mal governo, là dove soglion fan d’i denti succhio
Translate: "The old and the new Verrucchio hound, which devastated the Parcited Mountain, used their teeth as suckers in the same way they usually did."

Original: Le città di Lamone e di Santerno conduce il lïoncel dal nido bianco, che muta parte da la state al verno
Translate: The white lion that is found on the river fields of the Lamone and Santerno rivers constantly changes the pacts with the various cities throughout the year.

Original: E quella cu' il Savio bagna il fianco, così com'ella sie' tra 'l piano e 'l monte, tra tirannia si vive e stato franco
Translate: "The city, located between the plain and the mountain and embraced by the waters of the river Savio, is a place where tyranny and civic freedom coexist together."

Original: Ora chi se’, ti priego che ne conte
Translate: Please tell us who you are

Original: non esser duro più ch’altri sia stato, se ’l nome tuo nel mondo tegna fronte"
Translate: "Do not allow your name to be diminished compared to those of others, if your reputation is of great value."

Original: Poscia che ’l foco alquanto ebbe rugghiato al modo suo, l’aguta punta mosse di qua, di là, e poi diè cotal fiato:
Translate: "After the terrible muttering of flames, the flexible tongue waved from all sides and issued these words:"

Original: "S’i’ credesse che mia risposta fosse a persona che mai tornasse al mondo, questa fiamma staria sanza più scosse
Translate: "If I had the hope to speak to someone who would return to Earth, this flame would remain still."

Original: ma però che già mai di questo fondo non tornò vivo alcun, s’i’ odo il vero, sanza tema d’infamia ti rispondo
Translate: "Since no one has ever come from the living Hades, I can safely tell you the truth without fear of being dishonored."

Original: Io fui uom d'arme, e poi fui cordigliero, credendomi, sì cinto, fare ammenda
Translate: "As a soldier to a friar, I induced myself to embrace a totally different lifestyle to try to compensate for my sinful past by tightening the cord."

Original: e certo il creder mio venìa intero,  se non fosse il gran prete, a cui mal prenda,
Translate: "I had the certainty that what I believed would come true, had it not been for the pope: may God curse him."

Original: mi rimise ne le prime colpe
Translate: It spurred me to commit sin again.

Original: e come e quare, voglio che m’intenda
Translate: I want you to understand why this happened.

Original: Mentre ch’io forma fui d’ossa e di polpe che la madre mi diè, l’opere mie non furon leonine, ma di volpe
Translate: "So long as I was alive, with the body given to me by my mother, my actions were not based on violence but on intelligence."

Original: Li accorgimenti e le coperte vie io seppi tutte, e sì menai lor arte, ch’al fine de la terra il suono uscie
Translate: "I became an expert in the art of tricks and hidden streets, with which I built a fame that spread internationally."

Original: Quando mi vidi giunto in quella parte di mia etade ove ciascun dovrebbe calar le vele e raccoglier le sarte,
Translate: "When I realized that I had come to that point in my life where everyone should be ready for the retreat of the sail and the care of the tailors,"

Original: ciò che pria mi piacëa, allor m’increbbe, e pentuto e confesso mi rendei
Translate: "After regretting what I once liked, I regretted my sins and decided to take religious vows."

Original: ahi miser lasso
Translate: "Ah, that's bad luck!"

Original: e giovato sarebbe
Translate: No doubt I would have benefited from this.

Original: Lo principe d’i novi Farisei, avendo guerra presso a Laterano, e non con Saracin né con Giudei,  ché ciascun suo nimico era cristiano,
Translate: "The prince of the new Pharisees was taking part in a conflict near the Lateran, in which his adversaries were neither Saracens nor Jews but other Christians."

Original: e nessun era stato a vincer Acri né mercatante in terra di Soldano,
Translate: None of these had laid siege to Acre or sought business in the Sultan's kingdom.

Original: né sommo officio né ordini sacri guardò in sé, né in me quel capestro che solea fare i suoi cinti più macri
Translate: "He took no account of his highest rank, nor of the sacred precepts, nor of that Franciscan belt that tended to make the wearer lose weight."

Original: Ma come Costantin chiese Silvestro d’entro Siratti a guerir de la lebbre, così mi chiese questi per maestro  a guerir de la sua superba febbre
Translate: "In a similar way that Constantine summoned Pope Silvestro from his refuge on Mount Soratte to heal from leprosy, so he called me to cure his terrible fever."

Original: domandommi consiglio, e io tacetti perché le sue parole parver ebbre
Translate: I didn't give him any advice because his words seemed like crazy to me.

Original: E’ poi ridisse: "Tuo cuor non sospetti
Translate: "Don't be afraid, he urged me, "Your heart be without fear"."

Original: finor t’assolvo, e tu m’insegna fare sì come Penestrino in terra getti
Translate: "I accept to absolve you from the beginning, as long as you teach me how to break down the Palestrina fortress"

Original: Lo ciel poss’io serrare e diserrare, come tu sai
Translate: "As is known, I have the power to open the gates of heaven."

Original: però son due le chiavi che ’l mio antecessor non ebbe care"
Translate: My predecessor didn't keep the two keys in mind.

Original: Allor mi pinser li argomenti gravi là ’ve ’l tacer mi fu avviso ’l peggio, e dissi:
Translate: "As I agreed that silence would cost me dear, persuaded by the arguments put forward, I pronounced:"

Original: "Padre, da che tu mi lavi  di quel peccato ov’io mo cader deggio, lunga promessa con l’attender corto ti farà trïunfar ne l’alto seggio"
Translate: Promise little and maintain much will ensure your success in your tasks as a father and with His grace you will be freed from the sin in which you incur.

Original: Francesco venne poi, com’io fu’ morto, per me
Translate: "Soon after my last breath had left my body, St. Francis appeared to welcome my soul."

Original: ma un d’i neri cherubini li disse: "Non portar non mi far torto
Translate: "So great!" "But a devil cried to him, "Don't take it with you! Don't offend me!""

Original: Venir se ne dee giù tra ’ miei meschini perché diede ’l consiglio frodolente, dal quale in qua stato li sono a’ crini
Translate: "He must come down under my sentence, for he has given a dishonest counsel, from which I have stood after him ever since."

Original: ch'assolver non si può chi non si pente, né pentere e volere insieme puossi per la contradizion che nol consente"
Translate: "Without repentance there can be no absolution, and intentionally sinning after repenting would be an insane contradiction."

Original: Oh me dolente
Translate: "Oh, how unhappy I am!"

Original: come mi riscossi quando mi prese dicendomi: "Forse tu non pensavi ch’io löico fossi"
Translate: "When he grabbed me and uttered those words, "I wondered if I had considered the idea that I was a philosopher," I was shocked."

Original: A Minòs mi portò
Translate: I was led into the presence of Minos

Original: e quelli attorse otto volte la coda al dosso duro
Translate: And he rolled his tail eight times around his hard back

Original: e poi che per gran rabbia la si morse,  disse: "Questi è d’i rei del foco furo"
Translate: "Rage, he bit his lips and said, "This must go among the sinners who are to be burned in the fire in order to take them away from sight"."

Original: per ch’io là dove vedi son perduto, e sì vestito, andando, mi rancuro"
Translate: "I feel lost here where I am, surrounded by the flames burning as I wander into a sad melancholy."

Original: Quand’elli ebbe ’l suo dir così compiuto, la fiamma dolorando si partio, torcendo e dibattendo ’l corno aguto
Translate: "of wingsWhen the cursed one had finished speaking, the flame went away sore, waving and wiggling the pointed tips of his wings."

Original: Noi passamm’oltre, e io e ’l duca mio, su per lo scoglio infino in su l’altr’arco che cuopre ’l fosso in che si paga il fio  a quei che scommettendo acquistan carco
Translate: "We went further, crossing the bridge over the Bolgia where individuals guilty of sowing dissidis and accumulating sin are relegated."

Original: Chi poria mai pur con parole sciolte dicer del sangue e de le piaghe a pieno ch’i’ ora vidi, per narrar più volte?
Translate: "Who could, even with simple words but repeating the same story, fully understand the blood and wounds that I have observed?"

Original: Ogne lingua per certo verria meno per lo nostro sermone e per la mente c’ hanno a tanto comprender poco seno
Translate: "If there weren't our language and our mind, which both have limited ability to grasp everything that is said, each language would undoubtedly be much more insightful."

Original: S’el s’aunasse ancor tutta la gente che già, in su la fortunata terra di Puglia, fu del suo sangue dolente  per li Troiani e per la lunga guerra che de l’anella fé sì alte spoglie,
Translate: "Although all those who in southern Italy endured the consequences of a lasting war, sacrificing their blood at the service of the Romans, were gathered together to receive the reward of the great quantity of rings taken away as spoil."

Original: come Livïo scrive, che non erra,  con quella che sentio di colpi doglie per contastare a Ruberto Guiscardo
Translate: "According to Livio, those people who were severely punished in their resistance against Robert the Guiscard did not miss."

Original: e l’altra il cui ossame ancor s’accoglie  a Ceperan, là dove fu bugiardo ciascun Pugliese, e là da Tagliacozzo, dove sanz’arme vinse il vecchio Alardo
Translate: "The ashes of our ancestors still lie in the land of Ceprano, where the Apulian barons once stained with betrayal. Tagliacozzo then recalls the heroic victory of old Alardo with his wisdom."

Original: e qual forato suo membro e qual mozzo mostrasse, d’aequar sarebbe nulla il modo de la nona bolgia sozzo
Translate: "If each of them showed the parts of his body wounded or mutilated, it would still not be enough to emulate the terrible aspect of Ninth Bolgia."

Original: Già veggia, per mezzul perdere o lulla, com’io vidi un, così non si pertugia, rotto dal mento infin dove si trulla
Translate: A private barrel of its lower slats is not pierced as I saw an imprecise cut from the chin as far as the anus is located.

Original: Tra le gambe pendevan le minugia
Translate: His bowels hung between his legs.

Original: la corata pareva e ’l tristo sacco che merda fa di quel che si trangugia
Translate: You could observe the internal organs and the disgusting sack that turns food into excrement.

Original: Mentre che tutto in lui veder m'attacco, guardommi e con le man s'aperse il petto, dicendo: "Or vedi com'io mi dilacco
Translate: "?While I lingered on him with my eyes, he returned my gaze and opened his shirt by showing his chest, saying, "See how deep my pain is?"

Original: vedi come storpiato è Mäometto
Translate: Muhammad was mistreated in an extreme way

Original: Dinanzi a me sen va piangendo Alì, fesso nel volto dal mento al ciuffetto
Translate: "Alì disappeared in tears in front of me, with a deep wound running from the chin to the forehead."

Original: E tutti li altri che tu vedi qui, seminator di scandalo e di scisma fuor vivi, e però son fessi così
Translate: "All those who are here have been deprived of their powers as a result of the spread of scandal and division, caused by themselves."

Original: Un diavolo è qua dietro che n’accisma sì crudelmente, al taglio de la spada rimettendo ciascun di questa risma,
Translate: "A hellish demon torments us with great ferocity, forcing every damned one of this group to submit to the blade of the sword once again."

Original: quand’avem volta la dolente strada
Translate: We've finished our desperate journey through Bolgia.

Original: però che le ferite son richiuse prima ch’altri dinanzi li rivada
Translate: "before everyone returns to him, the wounds are healed."

Original: Ma tu chi se’ che ’n su lo scoglio muse, forse per indugiar d’ire a la pena ch’è giudicata in su le tue accuse?"
Translate: "What motivation is behind your continuing on the bridge, even though I know that punishment will result for all your sins?"

Original: "Né morte ’l giunse ancor, né colpa ’l mena", rispuose ’l mio maestro, "a tormentarlo
Translate: "My teacher replied, "The time has not yet come for him to leave, there is no reason to deceive him with suffering."

Original: ma per dar lui esperïenza piena,  a me, che morto son, convien menarlo per lo ’nferno qua giù di giro in giro
Translate: "I must lead him, who is alive, through the circles of Hell to give him a complete vision of this place."

Original: e quest’è ver così com’io ti parlo"
Translate: It's a fact I'm talking to you.

Original: Più fuor di cento che, quando l’udiro, s’arrestaron nel fosso a riguardarmi per maraviglia, oblïando il martiro
Translate: "There were more than one hundred unfortunates who, when they learned of the fact, stopped in the moat with an astonishing expression, forgetting their unhappiness."

Original: "Or dì a fra Dolcin dunque che s’armi, tu che forse vedra’ il sole in breve, s’ello non vuol qui tosto seguitarmi, sì di vivanda,
Translate: Ask AROUND TO BUY ABBUNDANT LIVE IF YOU DON'T WANT TO FIND ME.

Original: che stretta di neve non rechi la vittoria al Noarese, ch’altrimenti acquistar non saria leve"
Translate: So that a harsh winter does not hinder the Novaras in obtaining a victory that would otherwise be difficult to conquer.

Original: Poi che l’un piè per girsene sospese, Mäometto mi disse esta parola
Translate: "After raising a foot to say goodbye, Muhammad told me these words before leaving."

Original: indi a partirsi in terra lo distese
Translate: "Finally, he laid it on the ground and started to leave."

Original: Un altro, che forata avea la gola e tronco ’l naso infin sotto le ciglia, e non avea mai ch’una orecchia sola,
Translate: "Another victim had his throat ripped open, his nose crushed under his eyelashes and lacked an ear."

Original: ristato a riguardar per maraviglia con li altri, innanzi a li altri aprì la canna, ch’era di fuor d’ogne parte vermiglia,  e disse:
Translate: "Stop looking at me, with more astonishment than the others, opened the reed of the throat torn with blood and said:"

Original: "O tu cui colpa non condanna e cu’ io vidi in su terra latina, se troppa simiglianza non m’inganna,
Translate: "Tell me. "If my purity is the guarantor of yours, and if my recognition is not wrong, let us speak to you who you have known in Italy without any fault."

Original: rimembriti di Pier da Medicina, se mai torni a veder lo dolce piano che da Vercelli a Marcabò dichina
Translate: "Remember Pier da Medicina, if you ever want to review the sweet conformation of the territory that descends from the hills around Vercelli to Marcabò"

Original: E fa sapere a’ due miglior da Fano, a messer Guido e anco ad Angiolello, che, se l’antiveder qui non è vano,
Translate: "Inform the two excellent men of Fano, Messer Guido del Cassero and Angiolello da Carignano, that if our forecasts are not unfounded."

Original: gittati saran fuor di lor vasello e mazzerati presso a la Cattolica per tradimento d’un tiranno fello
Translate: "They will be condemned to death, throwing into them a sack tied to a boulder, near Catholic, following the betrayal of the cruel despot."

Original: Tra l’isola di Cipri e di Maiolica non vide mai sì gran fallo Nettuno, non da pirate, non da gente argolica
Translate: "Neptune, the god of the Mediterranean, had never observed such a serious crime committed neither by pirates nor by Argo raiders."

Original: Quel traditor che vede pur con l’uno, e tien la terra che tale qui meco vorrebbe di vedere esser digiuno,  farà venirli a parlamento seco
Translate: "That traitor, whose gaze is limited to the left eye and who has a dominion over the earth, will force them to come forward to talk to him - something a damned man here would wish he had never known."

Original: poi farà sì, ch’al vento di Focara non sarà lor mestier voto né preco"
Translate: ensure that prayers and vows against Focara's winds are not necessary for them.

Original: E io a lui: "Dimostrami e dichiara, se vuo’ ch’i’ porti sù di te novella, chi è colui da la veduta amara"
Translate: "I said to him, "Let me know, if you want me to talk about it on Earth, who suffered consequences because of their journey to Rimini?"."

Original: Allor puose la mano a la mascella d’un suo compagno e la bocca li aperse, gridando: "Questi è desso, e non favella
Translate: "While he grabbed his partner's jaw and opened his mouth, he exclaimed: "Here he is, and he is dumb!"

Original: Questi, scacciato, il dubitar sommerse in Cesare, affermando che ’l fornito sempre con danno l’attender sofferse"
Translate: Caesar no longer had any doubt when the one who had been banished from Rome told him that those who are ready to do something have always earned compared to one who is waiting.

Original: Oh quanto mi pareva sbigottito con la lingua tagliata ne la strozza Curïo, ch’a dir fu così ardito
Translate: "Curion was shocked, his language now deprived of the possibility of speaking, considering that he had always been very talkative."

Original: E un ch’avea l’una e l’altra man mozza, levando i moncherin per l’aura fosca, sì che ’l sangue facea la faccia sozza,  gridò:
Translate: "He, with both his hands amputated and the blood dripping down from the stumps in the air, shouted:"

Original: "Ricordera’ ti anche del Mosca, che disse, lasso,
Translate: " - that the dead no longer have suffering"Moscow of the Lamberti said, in a melancholy tone, that the dead no longer have to suffer."

Original: ’Capo ha cosa fatta’, che fu mal seme per la gente tosca"
Translate: "The boss, responsible for so much damage to the Tuscans."

Original: E io li aggiunsi: "E morte di tua schiatta"
Translate: I added: "And it also led to the dissolution of your family."

Original: per ch’elli, accumulando duol con duolo, sen gio come persona trista e matta
Translate: "With an uncomfortable sadness and unhappiness, he left with heavy lacerations in his heart."

Original: Ma io rimasi a riguardar lo stuolo, e vidi cosa ch’io avrei paura, sanza più prova, di contarla solo
Translate: "I watched that murmuring of souls, and I came across such a shocking revelation that I would hardly be able to give it without proving its accuracy."

Original: se non che coscïenza m'assicura, la buona compagnia che l'uom francheggia sotto l'asbergo del sentirsi pura
Translate: "Together with my good faith, which encourages man and gives him courage thanks to the sense of having maintained a clean conscience, I am comforted."

Original: Io vidi certo, e ancor par ch’io ’l veggia, un busto sanza capo andar sì come andavan li altri de la trista greggia
Translate: "I have undoubtedly observed, and I think I see it again, an unfortunate body that went along with others of the sad host."

Original: e ’l capo tronco tenea per le chiome, pesol con mano a guisa di lanterna: e quel mirava noi e dicea: "Oh me"
Translate: "Keeping her head cut off by the hair, which were pounding like a lantern, and bouncing at every single movement, she stared at us with sad looks almost as if she were saying "Alas!"

Original: Di sé facea a sé stesso lucerna, ed eran due in uno e uno in due
Translate: "He was able to illuminate both himself and another part of himself at the same time, as two individuals and one entity."

Original: com’esser può, quei sa che sì governa
Translate: He who is able to make this possible knows how to do it.

Original: Quando diritto al piè del ponte fue, levò ’l braccio alto con tutta la testa per appressarne le parole sue,  che fuoro:
Translate: "When he reached the bridge, he lifted his arm over his head inviting us to hear his words: """

Original: "Or vedi la pena molesta, tu che, spirando, vai veggendo i morti: vedi s’alcuna è grande come questa
Translate: "See, you who visit the dead alive, if there is another pain as great as my painful."

Original: E perché tu di me novella porti, sappi ch’i’ son Bertram dal Bornio, quelli che diedi al re giovane i ma’ conforti
Translate: "For you to report on me, know that I am Bertran de Born, the one who gave the young sovereign questionable counsel."

Original: Io feci il padre e ’l figlio in sé ribelli
Translate: I had his son crossed paths with his father.

Original: Achitofèl non fé più d’Absalone e di Davìd coi malvagi punzelli
Translate: Achitophel supported both Absalom and David with evil incitements without distinction.

Original: Perch’io parti’ così giunte persone, partito porto il mio cerebro, lasso, dal suo principio ch’è in questo troncone
Translate: "Being responsible for separating what was once united, I carry with me my thought cut off from the spinal cord within this fracture."

Original: Così s’osserva in me lo contrapasso"
Translate: It is clear that I am in contradiction.

Original: La molta gente e le diverse piaghe avean le luci mie sì inebrïate, che de lo stare a piangere eran vaghe
Translate: "The vision of the many damned and their terrible plagues had filled my eyes with tears, to the point where I felt the need to burst into tears."

Original: Ma Virgilio mi disse: "Che pur guate? perché la vista tua pur si soffolge là giù tra l’ombre triste smozzicate?
Translate: "Virgilio asked me ""Why do you keep your eyes fixed there on those mutilated spirits?""

Original: Tu non hai fatto sì a l’altre bolge
Translate: You've never reached this point before.
