Original: pensa, se tu annoverar le credi, che miglia ventidue la valle volge
Translate: "If I wanted to count its perimeter, think that the circumference of this chasm is twenty-two miles."

Original: E già la luna è sotto i nostri piedi
Translate: Under our feet the moon is now hiding.

Original: lo tempo è poco omai che n’è concesso, e altro è da veder che tu non vedi"
Translate: We have very little time available and there is still so much to see.

Original: "Se tu avessi", rispuos’io appresso, "atteso a la cagion per ch’io guardava, forse m’avresti ancor lo star dimesso"
Translate: "I answered immediately after: "If you had known the reason why I needed to observe, perhaps you would have allowed me to continue."

Original: Parte sen giva, e io retro li andava, lo duca, già faccendo la risposta, e soggiugnendo:
Translate: "I was behind my guide, who was walking away. I answered every statement and added details:"

Original: "Dentro a quella cava  dov’io tenea or li occhi sì a posta, credo ch’un spirto del mio sangue pianga la colpa che là giù cotanto costa"
Translate: ""While I still held my gaze in the pit, I am convinced that a relative of mine is expiating the error for which he is so severely punished in that place"."

Original: Allor disse ’l maestro: "Non si franga lo tuo pensier da qui innanzi sovr’ello
Translate: "Don't give treatment" The teacher recommended: "Don't get anxious, give him less attention from now on"."

Original: Attendi ad altro, ed ei là si rimanga
Translate: "Don't pay attention to that, and let it stay in its place."

Original: ch’io vidi lui a piè del ponticello mostrarti e minacciar forte col dito, e udi’ ’l nominar Geri del Bello
Translate: "I took note of him at a short distance from the bridge, with a mustolaccio while he was pointing his finger at you and shouted ""Geri del Bello!"."

Original: Tu eri allor sì del tutto impedito sovra colui che già tenne Altaforte, che non guardasti in là, sì fu partito"
Translate: "You were so busy listening to Bertran de Born, the man who owned the castle of Hautefort, that you didn't take his eyes off until he left."

Original: "O duca mio, la vïolenta morte che non li è vendicata ancor", diss’io, "per alcun che de l’onta sia consorte,  fece lui disdegnoso
Translate: I said: "O my master, his violent death which has not yet been avenged by any who, as a member of his coterie, shares his shame, made him disdainful

Original: ond’el sen gio sanza parlarmi, sì com’ïo estimo: e in ciò m’ ha el fatto a sé più pio"
Translate: "Despite the fact that he left without saying a word, as I thought, this made me more compassionate for him."

Original: Così parlammo infino al loco primo che de lo scoglio l’altra valle mostra, se più lume vi fosse, tutto ad imo
Translate: "We discussed up to the first point of the bridge, from which we could see all the second Bolgia if only there had been more light."

Original: Quando noi fummo sor l’ultima chiostra di Malebolge, sì che i suoi conversi potean parere a la veduta nostra,
Translate: "Arriving at the edge of the last abyss of the Malebolge, we could see his condemned."

Original: lamenti saettaron me diversi, che di pietà ferrati avean li strali
Translate: I heard various groanings so pitiful that I was moved by compassion.

Original: ond’io li orecchi con le man copersi
Translate: They forced me to put my hands on my ears

Original: Qual dolor fora, se de li spedali di Valdichiana tra ’l luglio e ’l settembre e di Maremma e di Sardigna i mali  fossero in una fossa tutti ’nsembre,
Translate: "If you take all the patients of the hospitals of Valdichiana, Maremma and Sardinia between July and September and meet them in one place, you will get a scene similar to that of a Bolgia."

Original: tal era quivi, e tal puzzo n’usciva qual suol venir de le marcite membre
Translate: the smell that spread was comparable to that of the rotting meats

Original: Noi discendemmo in su l’ultima riva del lungo scoglio, pur da man sinistra
Translate: "To the left, we headed towards the last section of the great bridge."

Original: e allor fu la mia vista più viva  giù ver’ lo fondo, là ’ve la ministra de l’alto Sire infallibil giustizia punisce i falsador che qui registra
Translate: "Then I could direct my gaze down, where divine justice, infallible servant of God, punishes wrongdoers who commit sins on Earth."

Original: Non credo ch’a veder maggior tristizia fosse in Egina il popol tutto infermo, quando fu l’aere sì pien di malizia,  che li animali, infino al picciol vermo, cascaron tutti,
Translate: "When the plague was so widespread in the region of Aegina that it spared none of the animals, from the largest to the smallest worm."

Original: e poi le genti antiche, secondo che i poeti hanno per fermo,  si ristorar di seme di formiche
Translate: "According to the narration of the poets, the ancient peoples redone their numbers with ants."

Original: ch’era a veder per quella oscura valle languir li spirti per diverse biche
Translate: "I don't think the scene of many suffering sick people was more distressing than the darkness in which the spirits were curled up, left aside."

Original: Qual sovra ’l ventre e qual sovra le spalle l’un de l’altro giacea, e qual carpone si trasmutava per lo tristo calle
Translate: "The bodies lay one over the other, lying on the back and on the belly, while some dragged forward crawling along that desolate place."

Original: Passo passo andavam sanza sermone, guardando e ascoltando li ammalati, che non potean levar le lor persone
Translate: "We proceeded slowly without saying a word, observing and listening to the sick who were unable to get up."

Original: Io vidi due sedere a sé poggiati, com’a scaldar si poggia tegghia a tegghia, dal capo al piè di schianze macolati
Translate: "I saw two sitting against each other, as if they were in the right place to be put on the fire, both covered in crusts from head to toe."

Original: e non vidi già mai menare stregghia a ragazzo aspettato dal segnorso, né a colui che mal volontier vegghia,
Translate: "I've never seen a solicitous servant, or a reluctant boy with the idea of watching, using stripes."

Original: come ciascun menava spesso il morso de l’unghie sopra sé per la gran rabbia del pizzicor, che non ha più soccorso
Translate: "As each of them scratched his own skin in the frenzy of bites, which had no other pleasant feeling"

Original: e sì traevan giù l’unghie la scabbia, come coltel di scardova le scaglie o d’altro pesce che più larghe l’abbia
Translate: They scratched the scab with their nails as if using a knife to remove the scales of a scorpion or another fish with larger scales.

Original: "O tu che con le dita ti dismaglie", cominciò ’l duca mio a l’un di loro, "e che fai d’esse talvolta tanaglie,
Translate: "You don't have to do this!My teacher turned to someone, saying: "Stop scratching your nails with your fingers and stop using them as claws! It's not allowed."

Original: dinne s’alcun Latino è tra costoro che son quinc’entro, se l’unghia ti basti etternalmente a cotesto lavoro"
Translate: "Ask us if there are Italians among these people, and may the punishment for this effort last forever."

Original: "Latin siam noi, che tu vedi sì guasti qui ambedue", rispuose l’un piangendo
Translate: "One of the two reacted sobbing: "We are both Italians, but as you can see our conditions are truly atrocite."

Original: "ma tu chi se’ che di noi dimandasti?"
Translate: "Who are you, from whom comes this question?"

Original: E ’l duca disse: "I’ son un che discendo con questo vivo giù di balzo in balzo, e di mostrar lo ’nferno a lui intendo"
Translate: "The master said, "I go down in spiral with this soul to show Hell."

Original: Allor si ruppe lo comun rincalzo
Translate: The two ceased to support each other.

Original: e tremando ciascuno a me si volse con altri che l’udiron di rimbalzo
Translate: "Threefold, many of those present had turned to me after learning the news."

Original: Lo buon maestro a me tutto s’accolse, dicendo: "Dì a lor ciò che tu vuoli"
Translate: The kind teacher approached me and urged me to tell them what I wanted.

Original: e io incominciai, poscia ch’ei volse:
Translate: "I began to speak, as had been requested."

Original: "Se la vostra memoria non s’imboli nel primo mondo da l’umane menti, ma s’ella viva sotto molti soli,
Translate: "to come" "that your memory endures in the minds of human beings on this planet, and relives through countless years to follow."

Original: ditemi chi voi siete e di che genti
Translate: "Please tell me where you come from and who you are."

Original: la vostra sconcia e fastidiosa pena di palesarvi a me non vi spaventi"
Translate: "Do not be afraid to present yourselves to me, despite your terrible and unpleasant punishment."

Original: "Io fui d'Arezzo, e Albero da Siena", rispuose l'un, "mi fé mettere al foco
Translate: One said, "I was from Arezzo and Tree from Siena condemned me to the stake!"

Original: ma quel per ch'io mori' qui non mi mena
Translate: "I died for something that wasn't my fault, but it brought me here."

Original: Vero è ch’i’ dissi lui, parlando a gioco: "I’ mi saprei levar per l’aere a volo"
Translate: I joked that I could fly in the air.

Original: e quei, ch’avea vaghezza e senno poco,  volle ch’i’ li mostrassi l’arte
Translate: "And that, which was capricious and devoid of common sense, desired that I teach him that trick."

Original: e solo perch’io nol feci Dedalo, mi fece ardere a tal che l’avea per figliuolo
Translate: "Since I didn't become Daedalus, a person made me burn because he regarded him as his son."

Original: Ma ne l’ultima bolgia de le diece me per l’alchìmia che nel mondo usai dannò Minòs, a cui fallar non lece"
Translate: "Minos, to whom not being allowed to make mistakes was implicit, decreed my condemnation to the deepest underworld of Tartarus for the alchemy I practiced during my life."

Original: E io dissi al poeta: "Or fu già mai gente sì vana come la sanese? Certo non la francesca sì d'assai"
Translate: I questioned Virgil: "A more foolish and wandering people of the Sienese exists? Frankly it is absolutely not overtaken by the French."

Original: Onde l’altro lebbroso, che m’intese, rispuose al detto mio:
Translate: "When the leper, who had heard what I had said, replied back to my statement."

Original: "Tra’ mene Stricca che seppe far le temperate spese,  e Niccolò che la costuma ricca del garofano prima discoverse ne l’orto dove tal seme s’appicca
Translate: "Better" Stricca, who proved to be parsimonious in spending, and Niccolò, the first to discover the expensive use of cloves in the garden where this plant has the greatest possibility to take root, should be excluded."

Original: e tra’ ne la brigata in che disperse Caccia d’Ascian la vigna e la gran fonda, e l’Abbagliato suo senno proferse
Translate: "Hunting of Asciano destroyed the vineyard and the great farms of the brigade, but the Abbagliato showed all its capacity outside of it."

Original: Ma perché sappi chi sì ti seconda contra i Sanesi, aguzza ver’ me l’occhio, sì che la faccia mia ben ti risponda:
Translate: "Be careful, so that you can recognize me among those who support you on the Sienese; look me in the face."

Original: sì vedrai ch’io son l’ombra di Capocchio, che falsai li metalli con l’alchìmia
Translate: "You will see that I am the soul of Capocchio, the one who modified metals through the alchemical arts."

Original: e te dee ricordar, se ben t’adocchio,  com’io fui di natura buona scimia"
Translate: "You must remember, if you remember correctly, how I was a valid interpreter of nature."

Original: Nel tempo che Iunone era crucciata per Semelè contra ’l sangue tebano, come mostrò una e altra fïata, Atamante divenne tanto insano,
Translate: "When Juno showed his anger toward the Theban seed because of Shemele in two episodes, Atamante was so troubled that he became insane."

Original: che veggendo la moglie con due figli andar carcata da ciascuna mano,  gridò:
Translate: "When he saw his wife hugging their two children, one by one, he cried out to her:"

Original: "Tendiam le reti, sì ch’io pigli la leonessa e ’ leoncini al varco"
Translate: "Let's pull the nets so I can take the lioness and her puppies."

Original: e poi distese i dispietati artigli,  prendendo l’un ch’avea nome Learco, e rotollo e percosselo ad un sasso
Translate: "and then stretched out his deadly claws, grasping one of the two named Learcus, flying him in the air and hurling him against a rock."

Original: e quella s’annegò con l’altro carco
Translate: "Keeping the other child, the woman drowned."

Original: E quando la fortuna volse in basso l’altezza de’ Troian che tutto ardiva, sì che ’nsieme col regno il re fu casso,
Translate: "When destiny lowered the Trojans who aspired for everything, their kingdom was shattered and the king assassinated."

Original: Ecuba trista, misera e cattiva, poscia che vide Polissena morta, e del suo Polidoro in su la riva  del mar si fu la dolorosa accorta, forsennata latrò sì come cane
Translate: "from the pain.Ecuba, witness of the tragedy that had struck Polissena and deeply distressed for the loss of Polidoro, gave himself to a devastating vent manifesting it with desperate cries similar to the latrate of a dog."

Original: tanto il dolor le fé la mente torta
Translate: the pain struck her so much that it upset her mind

Original: Ma né di Tebe furie né troiane si vider mäi in alcun tanto crude, non punger bestie, nonché membra umane,
Translate: "There was never the fury of the Thebans, nor that of the Trojans so terrible against anyone, nor soliciting animals or people."

Original: quant’io vidi in due ombre smorte e nude, che mordendo correvan di quel modo che ’l porco quando del porcil si schiude
Translate: "I saw two souls, pale and naked, running with the same voracity as a pig that came out hungry from the pigsty."

Original: L’una giunse a Capocchio, e in sul nodo del collo l’assannò, sì che, tirando, grattar li fece il ventre al fondo sodo
Translate: "One of them jumped on Capocchio and sank his teeth in the back of his neck, dragging him away so quickly that he had to crawl with his belly on the rocky soil of the Bolgia."

Original: E l’Aretin che rimase, tremando mi disse: "Quel folletto è Gianni Schicchi, e va rabbioso altrui così conciando"
Translate: "Griffolino d'Arezzo was there trembling, when he told me: "That ghost is Gianni Schicchi and is showing an uncontrollable anger against the other condemned."

Original: "Oh", diss’io lui, "se l’altro non ti ficchi li denti a dosso, non ti sia fatica a dir chi è, pria che di qui si spicchi"
Translate: "Oh, I replied to him, "I hope he doesn't fall into another person's clutches: please let me know who he is before he runs away from here."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Quell’è l’anima antica di Mirra scellerata, che divenne al padre, fuor del dritto amore, amica
Translate: "And he said to me, "The story is that of the wicked Myrrh, who betrayed the morals and fell in love with his father."

Original: Questa a peccar con esso così venne, falsificando sé in altrui forma,
Translate: "She managed to commit treason with him, disguised herself as someone else."

Original: come l’altro che là sen va, sostenne,  per guadagnar la donna de la torma, falsificare in sé Buoso Donati, testando e dando al testamento norma"
Translate: "As he went away, the other managed to impersonate Buoso Donati in order to obtain the queen of the armament and alter the will in order to make it pass as valid."

Original: E poi che i due rabbiosi fuor passati sovra cu’ io avea l’occhio tenuto, rivolsilo a guardar li altri mal nati
Translate: "When the two quarrellings had departed, I turned my gaze on the other sinners."

Original: Io vidi un, fatto a guisa di lëuto, pur ch’elli avesse avuta l’anguinaia tronca da l’altro che l’uomo ha forcuto
Translate: "I saw a person who, if she had been divided into two parts at the groin level, would look like a lute."

Original: La grave idropesì, che sì dispaia le membra con l’omor che mal converte, che ’l viso non risponde a la ventraia,
Translate: "The badly disposed lymph can cause severe idiopathy, which deforms the limbs so much that the face is considerably thinner than the belly."

Original: faceva lui tener le labbra aperte come l’etico fa, che per la sete l’un verso ’l mento e l’altro in sù rinverte
Translate: "They pushed him to pull up his lips like a water-hungry person, carrying the upper lip up and the lower lip up to the corner of the chin."

Original: "O voi che sanz’alcuna pena siete, e non so io perché, nel mondo gramo", diss’elli a noi, "guardate e attendete  a la miseria del maestro Adamo
Translate: "We were told to look carefully at the sad condition of Master Adam, we who are without punishment in Hell and do not know why."

Original: io ebbi, vivo, assai di quel ch’i’ volli, e ora, lasso,
Translate: "Dead, I don't want anything alive I got everything I wanted, and now when I'm dead I don't want anything anymore."

Original: un gocciol d’acqua bramo
Translate: I'd love some water.

Original: Li ruscelletti che d’i verdi colli del Casentin discendon giuso in Arno, faccendo i lor canali freddi e molli, sempre mi stanno innanzi,
Translate: "The streams of crystal clear water that descend from the green heights of Casentino, creating a wet and regenerating path to the river Arno, always remain in my memory."

Original: e non indarno, ché l’imagine lor vie più m’asciuga  che ’l male ond’io nel volto mi discarno
Translate: "and not without reason, since their presence soothes me much more than the disturbance that provokes me my afflicted face."

Original: La rigida giustizia che mi fruga tragge cagion del loco ov’io peccai a metter più li miei sospiri in fuga
Translate: The relentless divine sentence that causes me so much pain exploits the place where I committed a sin to torment me further.

Original: Ivi è Romena, là dov’io falsai la lega suggellata del Batista
Translate: "The castle of Romena stood under there, and it was in that place that I forgave the blossom."

Original: per ch’io il corpo sù arso lasciai
Translate: "For this reason, I was burned."

Original: Ma s’io vedessi qui l’anima trista di Guido o d’Alessandro o di lor frate, per Fonte Branda non darei la vista
Translate: "If I had before me the evil incarnation of the trio Guido, Alexander and their brother, I would gladly give up the cup of the Branda Fountain."

Original: Dentro c’è l’una già, se l’arrabbiate ombre che vanno intorno dicon vero
Translate: "One of them should be present already now, if what the enraging souls support is truthful."

Original: ma che mi val, c’ ho le membra legate?
Translate: What is the point of all this if I cannot move?

Original: S’io fossi pur di tanto ancor leggero ch’i’ potessi in cent’anni andare un’oncia, io sarei messo già per lo sentiero,
Translate: "If I could do one ounce every hundred years, I'd have left by now."

Original: cercando lui tra questa gente sconcia, con tutto ch’ella volge undici miglia, e men d’un mezzo di traverso non ci ha
Translate: "Surrounded by these disease-deformed creatures, even though the circle of Bolgia has a diameter of eleven miles and its width is at least half a mile."

Original: Io son per lor tra sì fatta famiglia
Translate: I came here because of them.

Original: e’ m’indussero a batter li fiorini ch’avevan tre carati di mondiglia"
Translate: They encouraged me to create guilders with three little metal carats.

Original: E io a lui: "Chi son li due tapini che fumman come man bagnate ’l verno,  giacendo stretti a’ tuoi destri confini?"
Translate: "I asked him, "Who are the two poor devils who are there, on your right hand, smoking as if their hands were intimidated by frost?"

Original: "Qui li trovai - e poi volta non dierno -", rispuose, "quando piovvi in questo greppo,  e non credo che dieno in sempiterno
Translate: "I said, "I saw them falling into this crack, and they have not been removed from their place ever since, and I doubt they will do it again."

Original: L’una è la falsa ch’accusò Gioseppo
Translate: Joseph was unjustly accused by a liar.

Original: l’altr’è ’l falso Sinon greco di Troia:  per febbre aguta gittan tanto leppo"
Translate: "The other, False Greek Trojan Synon, is plagued by an acute fever and smells sour of burnt fat."

Original: E l’un di lor, che si recò a noia forse d’esser nomato sì oscuro,  col pugno li percosse l’epa croia
Translate: "He punched the taut belly of one of them, perhaps annoyed by being so insultingly appointed."

Original: Quella sonò come fosse un tamburo
Translate: That sounded like a beating drum.

Original: e mastro Adamo li percosse il volto  col braccio suo, che non parve men duro, dicendo a lui:
Translate: "Master Adam threw himself at him with a violent blow to his face, and cried out to him: "

Original: "Ancor che mi sia tolto lo muover per le membra che son gravi,  ho io il braccio a tal mestiere sciolto"
Translate: "Even with my heavy legs, immobilized, I still have the strength in my arms to strike."

Original: Ond’ei rispuose: "Quando tu andavi al fuoco, non l’avei tu così presto
Translate: "Then the other replied, "When you were going to the gallows, you weren't exactly fast."

Original: ma sì e più l’avei quando coniavi"
Translate: Move your arms nicely while you were counterfeiting coins.

Original: E l’idropico: "Tu di’ ver di questo: ma tu non fosti sì ver testimonio  là ’ve del ver fosti a Troia richesto"
Translate: "The hydropic exclaimed: "You are right, but you were certainly not a reliable witness when the Truth was required in Troy."

Original: "S’io dissi falso, e tu falsasti il conio", disse Sinon
Translate: "Sinone declared, "If I have given a lie, you have counterfeited the coin."

Original: "e son qui per un fallo,  e tu per più ch’alcun altro demonio"
Translate: "I am here for a single guilt, while you have been condemned to more than any other."

Original: "Ricorditi, spergiuro, del cavallo", rispuose quel ch’avëa infiata l’epa
Translate: "He with his prominent belly replied, "I swear, I remember the horse."

Original: "e sieti reo che tutto il mondo sallo"
Translate: That everyone knows this will be a great inconvenience to you.

Original: "E te sia rea la sete onde ti crepa", disse ’l Greco, "la lingua, e l’acqua marcia  che ’l ventre innanzi a li occhi sì t’assiepa"
Translate: "The Greek exclaimed: "What an unbearable craving that of the thirst that makes your tongue crumble, the poverty of drinking water inflates your belly in front of your eyes!."

Original: Allora il monetier: "Così si squarcia la bocca tua per tuo mal come suole
Translate: "Then the monetier: "Exactly as your tongue suffers because of the disease, as it always happens."

Original: ché, s’i’ ho sete e omor mi rinfarcia, tu hai l’arsura e ’l capo che ti duole, e per leccar lo specchio di Narcisso, non vorresti a ’nvitar molte parole"
Translate: "I was thirsty and the water filled me, while you were suffering from acute thirst and severe headaches. It doesn't take much encouragement to let you drink a few drops of water."

Original: Ad ascoltarli er’io del tutto fisso, quando ’l maestro mi disse: "Or pur mira, che per poco che teco non mi risso"
Translate: Virgil warned me that I was close to being involved in his discussion because I was listening carefully.

Original: Quand’io ’l senti’ a me parlar con ira, volsimi verso lui con tal vergogna, ch’ancor per la memoria mi si gira
Translate: "When he was turning his anger to me, I turned to him with such an intense sense of embarrassment that he is still present in my memory today."

Original: Qual è colui che suo dannaggio sogna, che sognando desidera sognare, sì che quel ch’è, come non fosse, agogna,
Translate: "As a dreamer who fears his own desires, and would like to continue to dream rather than face reality, so he ardently desires unrealizable things."

Original: tal mi fec’io, non possendo parlare, che disïava scusarmi, e scusava me tuttavia, e nol mi credea fare
Translate: "Don't you dare talk, I was still trying to apologize even though I wasn't aware of it."

Original: "Maggior difetto men vergogna lava", disse ’l maestro, "che ’l tuo non è stato
Translate: "The teacher declared: "What you have done is less serious than a remorse of conscience cannot repair"

Original: però d’ogne trestizia ti disgrava
Translate: Let go of all sadness.

Original: E fa ragion ch’io ti sia sempre allato, se più avvien che fortuna t’accoglia  dove sien genti in simigliante piato:
Translate: Rest assured that I will always be at your side if one day fate takes you to places where discord reigns among people.

Original: ché voler ciò udire è bassa voglia"
Translate: The will to witness certain quarrels is thorny.

Original: Una medesma lingua pria mi morse, sì che mi tinse l’una e l’altra guancia, e poi la medicina mi riporse
Translate: "The same voice began with a rebuke that made me all red on both cheeks, but then offered me medicine."

Original: così od’io che solea far la lancia d’Achille e del suo padre esser cagione prima di trista e poi di buona mancia
Translate: "Achille and her father Peleo used the spear in turn, starting first the sad fates and then rejoicing."

Original: Noi demmo il dosso al misero vallone su per la ripa che ’l cinge dintorno, attraversando sanza alcun sermone
Translate: "We moved away from the melancholy pit of Malebolge, following the steep wall surrounding it, silently."

Original: Quiv’era men che notte e men che giorno, sì che ’l viso m’andava innanzi poco
Translate: .In this twilight I was able to just see what was just ahead.

Original: ma io senti’ sonare un alto corno,  tanto ch’avrebbe ogne tuon fatto fioco,
Translate: "A note of horn sounded so powerful that it overwhelmed any thunder, immediately capturing my attention."

Original: che, contra sé la sua via seguitando, dirizzò li occhi miei tutti ad un loco
Translate: "he was going in the opposite direction to that of sound, towards an unknown place."

Original: Dopo la dolorosa rotta, quando Carlo Magno perdé la santa gesta, non sonò sì terribilmente Orlando
Translate: " as RolandoWhen Charlemagne lost his paladins in the Camp of Roncesvalle, Orlando did not make his trumpet sound with the same intensity as Rolando."

Original: Poco portäi in là volta la testa, che me parve veder molte alte torri
Translate: "I turned my head forward, spotting a large number of tall towers."

Original: ond’io: "Maestro, dì, che terra è questa?"
Translate: Then I asked the Master, "Which land is this?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Però che tu trascorri per le tenebre troppo da la lungi, avvien che poi nel maginare abborri
Translate: "When you look at the darkness from too far away, your thoughts become confused; so he said to me."

Original: Tu vedrai ben, se tu là ti congiungi, quanto ’l senso s’inganna di lontano
Translate: "Once you get there, you'll be surprised how far away you deceive your senses."

Original: però alquanto più te stesso pungi"
Translate: Move fast to get there.

Original: Poi caramente mi prese per mano e disse:
Translate: "Then he took my hand gently, as he said,

Original: "Pria che noi siam più avanti, acciò che ’l fatto men ti paia strano,
Translate: "Your knowledge of the situation should be refreshed" Before you move on, so that it may seem less strange, you should update your knowledge of the situation."

Original: sappi che non son torri, ma giganti, e son nel pozzo intorno da la ripa da l’umbilico in giuso tutti quanti"
Translate: "There are no towers to see here, only giants set in the rock around the well. They extend from the navel down."

Original: Come quando la nebbia si dissipa, lo sguardo a poco a poco raffigura ciò che cela ’l vapor che l’aere stipa,
Translate: "When the fog dissipates and the panorama slowly emerges from the steamy mist, you can finally clearly distinguish the things stored in the air."

Original: così forando l’aura grossa e scura, più e più appressando ver’ la sponda, fuggiemi errore e cresciemi paura
Translate: "With the gaze that crossed the dense darkness, as we progressed towards the edge of the well, I felt my error dissolve and fear grow stronger."

Original: però che, come su la cerchia tonda Montereggion di torri si corona,
Translate: Monteriggioni is surrounded by a ring of walls on which stand majestic towers.

Original: così la proda che ’l pozzo circonda  torreggiavan di mezza la persona li orribili giganti, cui minaccia Giove del cielo ancora quando tuona
Translate: "The frightening giants, to whom Jupiter in the thunders reiterates his threat from the sky, emerged as imposing towers overlooking the embankment surrounding the well, starting from life up."

Original: E io scorgeva già d’alcun la faccia, le spalle e ’l petto e del ventre gran parte, e per le coste giù ambo le braccia
Translate: "I already saw the head, shoulders, chest and much of the abdomen of one of them with both arms lying along the sides."

Original: Natura certo, quando lasciò l’arte di sì fatti animali, assai fé bene per tòrre tali essecutori a Marte
Translate: "Of course nature has done a great favor, when it has ceased to generate creatures like these, so as to take away from Mars similar ministers."

Original: E s’ella d’elefanti e di balene non si pente, chi guarda sottilmente, più giusta e più discreta la ne tene
Translate: Even a person who knows how to discern wisely can only admire his decision to deny himself involvement in matters relating to whales and elephants.

Original: ché dove l'argomento de la mente s'aggiugne al mal volere e a la possa, nessun riparo vi può far la gente
Translate: "Where the intellect attaches itself to evil desire and brute force, individuals are powerless in defense."

Original: La faccia sua mi parea lunga e grossa
Translate: His face seemed big and elongated.

Original: come la pina di San Pietro a Roma, e a sua proporzione eran l’altre ossa
Translate: "Like the bronze cone in St. Peter's, in Rome, so the other members were in proportion."

Original: sì che la ripa, ch’era perizoma dal mezzo in giù, ne mostrava ben tanto di sovra, che di giugnere a la chioma  tre Frison s’averien dato mal vanto
Translate: "The rock, which had on it like a thong from the waist down, let us see so much of his body that three Frisons put on top of each other would struggle to reach his hair."

Original: però ch’i’ ne vedea trenta gran palmi dal loco in giù dov’omo affibbia ’l manto
Translate: "From where I was, I counted at least thirty palm trees to the area where man had hung his cloak."

Original: "Raphèl maì amècche zabì almi", cominciò a gridar la fiera bocca, cui non si convenia più dolci salmi
Translate: "His fierce mouth exclaimed ""Raphél maì amache zabì almi"" which was not suited to a sweeter tongue."

Original: E ’l duca mio ver’ lui: "Anima sciocca, tienti col corno, e con quel ti disfoga quand’ira o altra passïon ti tocca
Translate: ""And this is my advice for you: while fury and other feelings kindle your senses, be reasonable and indulge with a little self-irony"."

Original: Cércati al collo, e troverai la soga che ’l tien legato, o anima confusa, e vedi lui che ’l gran petto ti doga"
Translate: "Touch your neck and you will discover the harness that holds it, or confused soul, and examine the bagpipe that snakes through the big chest."

Original: Poi disse a me: "Elli stessi s’accusa
Translate: He himself accuses himself.

Original: questi è Nembrotto per lo cui mal coto pur un linguaggio nel mondo non s’usa
Translate: Nembrod is the cause of linguistic diversity in the world because of his evil thinking.

Original: Lasciànlo stare e non parliamo a vòto
Translate: We're not gonna say anything anymore, and we're gonna leave him alone.

Original: ché così è a lui ciascun linguaggio come ’l suo ad altrui, ch’a nullo è noto"
Translate: "He does not understand any language, whether it be spoken by the people around him or by himself, for it makes sense only for him."

Original: Facemmo adunque più lungo vïaggio, vòlti a sinistra
Translate: "We then went on a longer path, heading to the left."

Original: e al trar d’un balestro trovammo l’altro assai più fero e maggio
Translate: "After a short distance, we came across an even more fearsome and enormous giant."

Original: A cigner lui qual che fosse ’l maestro, non so io dir, ma el tenea soccinto dinanzi l’altro
Translate: "I don't know who the author is, but someone had held his left arm in front."

Original: e dietro il braccio destro  d’una catena che ’l tenea avvinto dal collo in giù, sì che ’n su lo scoperto si ravvolgëa infino al giro quinto
Translate: "He was wrapped around his neck by a chain, so that the visible part would wrap in five laps around his right arm."

Original: "Questo superbo volle esser esperto di sua potenza contra ’l sommo Giove", disse ’l mio duca, "ond’elli ha cotal merto
Translate: "Who rightly called his mother his fortune"My master claimed that this connoisseur of idealism voluntarily provoked himself against the sovereign Jupiter, by whom he was rewarded with such a fortune as to define it as part of his kinship."

Original: Fïalte ha nome, e fece le gran prove quando i giganti fer paura a’ dèi
Translate: Fialte is the name of the figure who joined the battle when the giants threatened the gods.

Original: le braccia ch’el menò, già mai non move"
Translate: He couldn't use the arms he had moved in that circumstance.

Original: E io a lui: "S’esser puote, io vorrei che de lo smisurato Brïareo esperïenza avesser li occhi mei"
Translate: "I would express to him the desire to see with my own eyes the boundless Briareus, if possible."

Original: Ond’ei rispuose: "Tu vedrai Anteo presso di qui che parla ed è disciolto, che ne porrà nel fondo d’ogne reo
Translate: "He replied: "You will see here near Anteo, who is speaking and has been liberated, so that you can reach the bottom of Hell."

Original: Quel che tu vuo’ veder, più là è molto ed è legato e fatto come questo, salvo che più feroce par nel volto"
Translate: "What you want to see is far away and looks the same as what you see, except for a trace of ferocity in its expression."

Original: Non fu tremoto già tanto rubesto, che scotesse una torre così forte, come Fïalte a scuotersi fu presto
Translate: There had never been an earthquake so violent as to shake a tower with such force as Fialte did.

Original: Allor temett’io più che mai la morte, e non v’era mestier più che la dotta, s’io non avessi viste le ritorte
Translate: "I felt a deadly fear of dying and that would have been enough to convince me if I hadn't noticed the chains."

Original: Noi procedemmo più avante allotta, e venimmo ad Anteo, che ben cinque alle, sanza la testa, uscia fuor de la grotta
Translate: "Continuing, we arrived at Anteo popping out of the stone five hours apart without the head."

Original: "O tu che ne la fortunata valle che fece Scipïon di gloria reda, quand’Anibàl co’ suoi diede le spalle,  recasti già mille leon per preda,
Translate: "Hybrids?"When Hannibal was in the throes, did you set up your wealth in the historic valley of Zama, whose glory was inherited by Scipione, arresting a thousand lion hybrids?

Original: e che, se fossi stato a l’alta guerra de’ tuoi fratelli, ancor par che si creda  ch’avrebber vinto i figli de la terra:
Translate: "If I had fought in the great war of my brothers, it is believed that the Earth's children would have been victorious."

Original: mettine giù, e non ten vegna schifo, dove Cocito la freddura serra
Translate: We do not refuse to lower ourselves where Cocito Lake becomes ice because of the cold

Original: Non ci fare ire a Tizio né a Tifo: questi può dar di quel che qui si brama
Translate: Avoid having to resort to Guy or Typheus: Dante can provide what you need.

Original: però ti china e non torcer lo grifo
Translate: squat and don't turn your head

Original: Ancor ti può nel mondo render fama, ch’el vive, e lunga vita ancor aspetta se ’nnanzi tempo grazia a sé nol chiama"
Translate: "He can still offer fame in the world, remains alive and could live for a long time, provided that he is given a further blessing from God."

Original: Così disse ’l maestro
Translate: That's what the teacher said.

Original: e quelli in fretta le man distese, e prese ’l duca mio, ond’Ercule sentì già grande stretta
Translate: "And Anteo immediately stretched out his arms, grasping Virgil with his formidable hands, which Hercules immediately perceived as a tremendous grip."

Original: Virgilio, quando prender si sentio, disse a me: "Fatti qua, sì ch’io ti prenda"
Translate: "Virgilio, when he heard me next to him, exclaimed: "Come closer so that I can grasp you."

Original: poi fece sì ch’un fascio era elli e io
Translate: "He held me firmly in his arms, so as to unite our hearts as if they were one."

Original: Qual pare a riguardar la Carisenda sotto 'l chinato, quando un nuvol vada sovr'essa sì, ched ella incontro penda:
Translate: "The appearance of the tower of the Garisenda changes when a cloud overlooks it, making it appear as if it was going to fall forward to those who watch it from below."

Original: tal parve Antëo a me che stava a bada di vederlo chinare, e fu tal ora ch’i’ avrei voluto ir per altra strada
Translate: "While I watched Antheus carefully, his figure was so terrifying that I was willing to take another way to avoid him."

Original: Ma lievemente al fondo che divora Lucifero con Giuda, ci sposò
Translate: He placed us tenderly at the bottom of Hell where Lucifer and Judas are destined to be consumed.

Original: né, sì chinato, lì fece dimora,  e come albero in nave si levò
Translate: He climbed again like a sail in the master tree of a ship.

Original: S’ïo avessi le rime aspre e chiocce, come si converrebbe al tristo buco sovra ’l qual pontan tutte l’altre rocce,
Translate: "If I had a poetic style capable of doing justice to the depths of the center of the Earth, which houses the most solid and massive rocks, it would be hard and harsh."

Original: io premerei di mio concetto il suco più pienamente
Translate: I would more appropriately expose the meaning of my poetic words.

Original: ma perch’io non l’abbo, non sanza tema a dicer mi conduco
Translate: "Because I have no resources at my disposal, I write with some apprehension."

Original: ché non è impresa da pigliare a gabbo discriver fondo a tutto l’universo, né da lingua che chiami mamma o babbo
Translate: "Representing the essence of the entire universe is absolutely not to be overlooked, nor is it suitable for children's words."

Original: Ma quelle donne aiutino il mio verso ch’aiutaro Anfïone a chiuder Tebe, sì che dal fatto il dir non sia diverso
Translate: "The prayers that I address to the goddesses who helped Amphion to surround Thebes with the walls, so that what I say may conform to reality."

Original: Oh sovra tutte mal creata plebe che stai nel loco onde parlare è duro, mei foste state qui pecore o zebe
Translate: "The sinners, the most wicked of all creatures, who are found in a little upbuilding place, would have been better if you had lived like sheep or goats."

Original: Come noi fummo giù nel pozzo scuro sotto i piè del gigante assai più bassi, e io mirava ancora a l’alto muro,  dicere udi’ mi:
Translate: "When we had descended into the dark pit, at a depth lower than that of the feet of the giant Antaeus, and I was still looking at the high rocky surface, I heard someone saying to me: "

Original: "Guarda come passi: va sì, che tu non calchi con le piante le teste de’ fratei miseri lassi"
Translate: Be careful where you put your feet: try not to crush the remains of your brothers.

Original: Per ch’io mi volsi, e vidimi davante e sotto i piedi un lago che per gelo avea di vetro e non d’acqua sembiante
Translate: "I turn around and in front of me, under my feet, I see an ice lake that seems to be made of crystal rather than water."

Original: Non fece al corso suo sì grosso velo di verno la Danoia in Osterlicchi, né Tanaï là sotto ’l freddo cielo,  com’era quivi
Translate: "There had never been such a winter situation on the Danube and Don, under the freezing sky: the surface did not freeze as solidly as the lake of Hell."

Original: che se Tambernicchi vi fosse sù caduto, o Pietrapana, non avria pur da l’orlo fatto cricchi
Translate: "If Mount Tambura or Pania had fallen upon them, not even a slight squeegee would have been heard on their surface."

Original: E come a gracidar si sta la rana col muso fuor de l’acqua, quando sogna di spigolar sovente la villana,
Translate: "Like a dim frog swimming just on the surface of the summer water, the peasant often dreams of picking the grass of the field."

Original: livide, insin là dove appar vergogna eran l’ombre dolenti ne la ghiaccia, mettendo i denti in nota di cicogna
Translate: "Sorrowful and lively souls, shivering cold with their teeth beating like storks, were wrapped in ice until a reddish nuance was glimpsed."

Original: Ognuna in giù tenea volta la faccia
Translate: Everyone looked down.

Original: da bocca il freddo, e da li occhi il cor tristo tra lor testimonianza si procaccia
Translate: "Among them, the lips reveal the coldness as their eyes convey an inner anguish."

Original: Quand’io m’ebbi dintorno alquanto visto, volsimi a’ piedi, e vidi due sì stretti, che ’l pel del capo avieno insieme misto
Translate: "When I looked around for a while, I noticed two wretches, so close to each other that they had their hair intertwined with each other."

Original: "Ditemi, voi che sì strignete i petti", diss’io, "chi siete?"
Translate: I asked, "Would you kindly tell me who you are who hold your breasts so tight?"

Original: E quei piegaro i colli
Translate: Their hills bowed down.

Original: e poi ch’ebber li visi a me eretti,  li occhi lor, ch’eran pria pur dentro molli, gocciar su per le labbra, e ’l gelo strinse le lagrime tra essi e riserrolli
Translate: "After raising their eyes to me, tears poured on their lips as the cold closed them in a bite. Their eyes before overflowing with weeping were now a torrent of emotion."

Original: Con legno legno spranga mai non cinse forte così
Translate: Never was an iron bar so tightly tightened on two axes

Original: ond’ei come due becchi cozzaro insieme, tanta ira li vinse
Translate: "The two clashed furiously, so angry that they went mad at each other."

Original: E un ch’avea perduti ambo li orecchi per la freddura, pur col viso in giùe, disse:
Translate: "Another person, frozen to such an extent that he had lost his two ears and his face bowed to the ground, addressed the word to me, saying to me:"

Original: "Perché cotanto in noi ti specchi?  Se vuoi saper chi son cotesti due, la valle onde Bisenzo si dichina del padre loro Alberto e di lor fue
Translate: "Why do you look at us with so much emphasis?If you want to understand who these people are, know that they come from the valley where the Bisenzio river is born, like their father Alberto."

Original: D’un corpo usciro
Translate: They came to light from the same mother.

Original: e tutta la Caina potrai cercare, e non troverai ombra degna più d’esser fitta in gelatina:
Translate: "you can search all over Caina for a long time, without finding the most worthy of them to be preserved in this jelly."

Original: non quelli a cui fu rotto il petto e l’ombra con esso un colpo per la man d’Artù
Translate: King Arthur pierced his breast with a spear, and the shadow of him.

Original: non Focaccia
Translate: Instead of Focaccia

Original: non questi che m’ingombra  col capo sì, ch’i’ non veggio oltre più, e fu nomato Sassol Mascheroni
Translate: "What gives me the shadow with the head, to the point of not being able to see beyond and called Sassolo Mascheroni."

Original: se tosco se’, ben sai omai chi fu
Translate: "if you're from Tuscany, you know who's at the center of the conversation"

Original: E perché non mi metti in più sermoni, sappi ch’i’ fu’ il Camiscion de’ Pazzi
Translate: "Because you haven't opened your mouth yet, remember that I was Crazy Shirt."

Original: e aspetto Carlin che mi scagioni"
Translate: I wait here for Carlino to help make my guilt less serious

Original: Poscia vid’io mille visi cagnazzi fatti per freddo
Translate: I saw a thousand faces reddened because of the cold.

Original: onde mi vien riprezzo, e verrà sempre, de’ gelati guazzi
Translate: Even today I feel a thrill of disgust when I see frozen waters.

Original: E mentre ch’andavamo inver’ lo mezzo al quale ogne gravezza si rauna, e io tremava ne l’etterno rezzo
Translate: "While we were walking the path that leads to the heart of the Earth attracted by all the weights, the cold cold flooded me with tremors."

Original: se voler fu o destino o fortuna, non so
Translate: "I don't know if my future was predestined, or if this was determined by my own will or destiny."

Original: ma, passeggiando tra le teste, forte percossi ’l piè nel viso ad una
Translate: "while I was walking among people, I accidentally struck someone's face violently"

Original: Piangendo mi sgridò: "Perché mi peste? se tu non vieni a crescer la vendetta di Montaperti, perché mi moleste?"
Translate: "Tears to the eyes, he asked me: "Why this treatment? If you didn't come to increase the suffering for Montaperti, then what brought you here to torment me?"

Original: E io: "Maestro mio, or qui m’aspetta, sì ch’io esca d’un dubbio per costui
Translate: "I said to the Master: "Stop here waiting for me to solve my uncertainty about this person"."

Original: poi mi farai, quantunque vorrai, fretta"
Translate: You'll never know when or how I'll put pressure on you

Original: Lo duca stette, e io dissi a colui che bestemmiava duramente ancora: "Qual se’ tu che così rampogni altrui?"
Translate: "My guide stood still, and I said to the damned one, who was still speaking improbably, "What is your right to blame others so?"

Original: "Or tu chi se’ che vai per l’Antenora, percotendo", rispuose, "altrui le gote, sì che, se fossi vivo, troppo fora?"
Translate: "He asked, "Who are you who, by going down for the Ancestor, strike at others, a violation of my dignity if I were still alive?"

Original: "Vivo son io, e caro esser ti puote", fu mia risposta, "se dimandi fama, ch’io metta il nome tuo tra l’altre note"
Translate: "My answer was: "I'm still alive, and this could help if you're looking for notoriety; I'll include your name in my poem."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Del contrario ho io brama
Translate: I'd like it to be different.

Original: Lèvati quinci e non mi dar più lagna, ché mal sai lusingar per questa lama"
Translate: "Get out of here and don't bother me anymore, since your flattery is worth little in this desolate Tana."

Original: Allor lo presi per la cuticagna e dissi: "El converrà che tu ti nomi, o che capel qui sù non ti rimagna"
Translate: "I grabbed him by the collar and said, "You should tell me who you are immediately, otherwise you will no longer have a single hair."

Original: Ond’elli a me: "Perché tu mi dischiomi, né ti dirò ch’io sia, né mosterrolti se mille fiate in sul capo mi tomi"
Translate: "He told me that, despite what I could do to him, he would stand firm in his decision and never allow anyone to understand who he was or what information he possessed."

Original: Io avea già i capelli in mano avvolti, e tratti glien’avea più d’una ciocca, latrando lui con li occhi in giù raccolti,  quando un altro gridò:
Translate: "Holding his hair twisted in my hand, I had already ripped away several strands while he latrified with his gaze to the ground, when someone else shouted:"

Original: "Che hai tu, Bocca? non ti basta sonar con le mascelle, se tu non latri? qual diavol ti tocca?"
Translate: "What's the matter, Bocca? Why don't you make your voice sound barking instead of just banging your jaws together? What's going on, boy?"

Original: "Omai", diss’io, "non vo’ che più favelle, malvagio traditor
Translate: I cried out, "Don't listen to one word of this treacherous traitor!"

Original: ch’a la tua onta io porterò di te vere novelle"
Translate: Instead, I will spread false news about you on Earth that will slander you.

Original: "Va via", rispuose, "e ciò che tu vuoi conta
Translate: He replied: "Go away and share whatever you want."

Original: ma non tacer, se tu di qua entro eschi, di quel ch’ebbe or così la lingua pronta
Translate: "If you ever leave here, don't stop spreading the name of those who have expressed their opinions so casually."

Original: El piange qui l’argento de’ Franceschi: "Io vidi", potrai dir, "quel da Duera là dove i peccatori stanno freschi"
Translate: "I saw Buoso da Duera, a place that recalls the lack of the silver of the French; where the wicked cannot hope to go unharmed."

Original: Se fossi domandato "Altri chi v’era?", tu hai dallato quel di Beccheria di cui segò Fiorenza la gorgiera
Translate: "If anyone finds out who else was here, you remember that Tesauro dei Beccheria was killed by the Florentines by a beheading."

Original: Gianni de’ Soldanier credo che sia più là con Ganellone e Tebaldello, ch’aprì Faenza quando si dormia"
Translate: "I believe that Gianni dei Soldanieri, Gano di Maganza and Tebaldello de' Zambrasi opened the doors of Faenza in the night."

Original: Noi eravam partiti già da ello, ch’io vidi due ghiacciati in una buca, sì che l’un capo a l’altro era cappello
Translate: "We had already moved away from that disturbing situation, when I noticed two other frozen in a pit, placed in such a way that the head of one was a hat for the other."

Original: e come ’l pan per fame si manduca, così ’l sovran li denti a l’altro pose là ’ve ’l cervel s’aggiugne con la nuca:
Translate: "as a devouring hunger feeds on bread, so the one above sank his teeth into the other where the brain meets the spinal cord."

Original: non altrimenti Tidëo si rose le tempie a Menalippo per disdegno, che quei faceva il teschio e l’altre cose
Translate: of the bodyTideo did not bite the temples of Menalippo with the same livor that put in the bite to the jaw and to other parts of the carcass of the ill-headed.

Original: "O tu che mostri per sì bestial segno odio sovra colui che tu ti mangi, dimmi ’l perché", diss’io, "per tal convegno,
Translate: "You speak and I listen."I asked: "Why do you show so violent hatred for who you are devouring? If you explain it to me, I will listen to you."

Original: che se tu a ragion di lui ti piangi, sappiendo chi voi siete e la sua pecca, nel mondo suso ancora io te ne cangi,
Translate: "If you feel that you are right to complain about him, since you know both yourself and his sins, I will try to repay you when I return to Earth."

Original: se quella con ch’io parlo non si secca"
Translate: as long as my speech doesn't run out

Original: La bocca sollevò dal fiero pasto quel peccator, forbendola a' capelli del capo ch'elli avea di retro guasto
Translate: "The sinner finished eating the fierce meal, cleaning his mouth with the hair of his head that he bite from behind."

Original: Poi cominciò: "Tu vuo’ ch’io rinovelli disperato dolor che ’l cor mi preme già pur pensando, pria ch’io ne favelli
Translate: "Before I recalled a painful memory that already hurts my mind, I began to ask you if I wanted to talk about it."

Original: Ma se le mie parole esser dien seme che frutti infamia al traditor ch’i’ rodo, parlare e lagrimar vedrai insieme
Translate: "If my words are to be a seed that brings infamy to the one whom I betrayed, then I will pronounce them weeping."

Original: Io non so chi tu se’ né per che modo venuto se’ qua giù
Translate: I have no idea where you came from or who you are.

Original: ma fiorentino mi sembri veramente quand’io t’odo
Translate: You look like a Florentine native when you talk.

Original: Tu dei saper ch’i’ fui conte Ugolino, e questi è l’arcivescovo Ruggieri: or ti dirò perché i son tal vicino
Translate: "I, Count Ugolino, must let you know that Archbishop Ruggieri is my neighbor; now I will reveal why I am so hostile to him."

Original: Che per l’effetto de’ suo’ mai pensieri, fidandomi di lui, io fossi preso e poscia morto, dir non è mestieri
Translate: "Because I had faith in him, I was unfortunately captured and subsequently murdered as a result of his perverse plans."

Original: però quel che non puoi avere inteso, cioè come la morte mia fu cruda, udirai, e saprai s’e’ m’ ha offeso
Translate: "You will feel what a horrible situation I have been a victim of, and then you will understand if he has failed me."

Original: Breve pertugio dentro da la Muda, la qual per me ha ’l titol de la fame, e che conviene ancor ch’altrui si chiuda,
Translate: "A small wound in the Tower of the Muda, now known to me as the Tower of Fame, which is about to welcome many other prisoners."

Original: m’avea mostrato per lo suo forame più lune già, quand’io feci ’l mal sonno che del futuro mi squarciò ’l velame
Translate: "He had already shown me many moons through his opening, when I had the bad dream that revealed the future to me."

Original: Questi pareva a me maestro e donno, cacciando il lupo e ’ lupicini al monte per che i Pisan veder Lucca non ponno
Translate: "This seemed to me to be the leader and expert conductor of a wolf hunt between the valleys of the mountain, visible only by the Pisans but not by Lucca."

Original: Con cagne magre, studïose e conte Gualandi con Sismondi e con Lanfranchi s’avea messi dinanzi da la fronte
Translate: "On the first line he had deployed the Gualandi, the Sismondi and the Lanfranchi with their slender and hungry dogs trained in the clash."

Original: In picciol corso mi parieno stanchi lo padre e ’ figli, e con l’agute scane mi parea lor veder fender li fianchi
Translate: "After a quick run, family members seemed to be exhausted, with dogs sinking their sharp tusks into each other's hips."

Original: Quando fui desto innanzi la dimane, pianger senti’ fra ’l sonno i miei figliuoli ch’eran con meco, e dimandar del pane
Translate: "When I woke up before dawn, I heard my children crying in their sleep and asking for bread."

Original: Ben se’ crudel, se tu già non ti duoli pensando ciò che ’l mio cor s’annunziava
Translate: "You are very insensitive, not feeling sorry for the premonition I kept in my heart."

Original: e se non piangi, di che pianger suoli?  Già eran desti, e l’ora s’appressava che ’l cibo ne solëa essere addotto, e per suo sogno ciascun dubitava
Translate: "Once we woke up, the hour of the meal was approaching but this was not received by general enthusiasm because of the unbelief aroused by each one's dream. What was the thing that usually made them cry?"

Original: e io senti’ chiavar l’uscio di sotto a l’orribile torre
Translate: "underneath the left and frightening tower, the door was fixed to the hinges."

Original: ond’io guardai nel viso a’ mie’ figliuoi sanza far motto
Translate: Silently I looked at the faces of my children.

Original: Io non piangëa, sì dentro impetrai: piangevan elli
Translate: "I was too upset to shed tears while they were crying desperately."

Original: e Anselmuccio mio disse: "Tu guardi sì, padre
Translate: ""My brother Anselmuccio exclaimed, "You have such a beautiful expression, Father!""

Original: che hai?"
Translate: What's wrong with you?

Original: Perciò non lagrimai né rispuos’io tutto quel giorno né la notte appresso, infin che l’altro sol nel mondo uscìo
Translate: "I did not shed a tear nor answered during that endless day and night, until the sun rose the next morning."

Original: Come un poco di raggio si fu messo nel doloroso carcere, e io scorsi per quattro visi il mio aspetto stesso,  ambo le man per lo dolor mi morsi
Translate: "As soon as a faint ray of light penetrated into the sad prison, I had four faces that looked very, very curved and hungry. Desperation made me hold my fists for pain."

Original: ed ei, pensando ch’io ’l fessi per voglia di manicar, di sùbito levorsi  e disser:
Translate: "They quickly got up assuming that I was starving, exclaiming:"

Original: "Padre, assai ci fia men doglia se tu mangi di noi: tu ne vestisti queste misere carni, e tu le spoglia"
Translate: ""Father, it would be much less painful if you consumed our flesh: they were given by you to us, and delivered us by their use"."

Original: Queta’ mi allor per non farli più tristi
Translate: I tried to keep calm so as not to add more sadness.

Original: lo dì e l’altro stemmo tutti muti
Translate: For two consecutive days no sound was heard.

Original: ahi dura terra, perché non t’apristi?
Translate: "Why haven't you absorbed us, O relentless earth?"

Original: Poscia che fummo al quarto dì venuti, Gaddo mi si gittò disteso a’ piedi, dicendo: "Padre mio, ché non m’aiuti?"
Translate: "Gaddo bowed to my feet when we arrived on the fourth day, begging: "My Father, why do you not want to help me?""

Original: Quivi morì
Translate: A person lay on this place.

Original: e come tu mi vedi, vid’io cascar li tre ad uno ad uno tra ’l quinto dì e ’l sesto
Translate: "As I saw, so you saw the other three fall one after the other between the fifth and the sixth day."

Original: ond’io mi diedi,  già cieco, a brancolar sovra ciascuno, e due dì li chiamai, poi che fur morti
Translate: "I went in stride among their salettes as I announced the names of the dead for two days after their departure. Already blind and dying, I did my sad duty."

Original: Poscia, più che 'l dolor, poté 'l digiuno"
Translate: "The hunger, rather than the pain, eventually killed me."

Original: Quand’ebbe detto ciò, con li occhi torti riprese ’l teschio misero co’ denti, che furo a l’osso, come d’un can, forti
Translate: "After speaking his statement, with his eyes slid, he continued to bite the miserable skull with a force equal to that of a dog to the bone."

Original: Ahi Pisa, vituperio de le genti del bel paese là dove 'l sì suona,
Translate: "Unfortunately, Pisa, who plays the so famous ""yes"," is the shame of the people of the beautiful country."

Original: poi che i vicini a te punir son lenti,  muovasi la Capraia e la Gorgona, e faccian siepe ad Arno in su la foce, sì ch’elli annieghi in te ogne persona
Translate: "For the neighbors are slow to punish you, forcing them to withdraw from the islands of Capraia and Gorgona to interrupt the mouth of the Arno, so that the waters of the river submerge each of your inhabitants."

Original: Che se ’l conte Ugolino aveva voce d’aver tradita te de le castella, non dovei tu i figliuoi porre a tal croce
Translate: "If Count Ugolino was suspected of betraying you by surrendering the castles, you would not have had to inflict such torture on his children."

Original: Innocenti facea l’età novella, novella Tebe, Uguiccione e ’l Brigata e li altri due che ’l canto suso appella
Translate: "The freshness of the young age, or novel Thebes, had made Uguccione and the Brigade, as well as the other two mentioned in the previous song, innocent."

Original: Noi passammo oltre, là ’ve la gelata ruvidamente un’altra gente fascia, non volta in giù, ma tutta riversata
Translate: "We moved further, where the ice was a terrible condemnation for other unfortunates, not looking down but toward the sky."

Original: Lo pianto stesso lì pianger non lascia, e ’l duol che truova in su li occhi rintoppo, si volge in entro a far crescer l’ambascia
Translate: "They cannot weep, for their weeping is held back; the suffering that sees a barrier in their eyes remains and contributes to increasing the penalty."

Original: ché le lagrime prime fanno groppo, e sì come visiere di cristallo, rïempion sotto ’l ciglio tutto il coppo
Translate: "The first tears freeze and form like ice windows, flooding the orbital case of the eye under the corner."

Original: E avvegna che, sì come d’un callo, per la freddura ciascun sentimento cessato avesse del mio viso stallo,
Translate: "Despite the cold that had numbed all my feelings, the skin of my face was like a callus."

Original: già mi parea sentire alquanto vento
Translate: I felt like I felt a breeze.

Original: per ch’io: "Maestro mio, questo chi move? non è qua giù ogne vapore spento?"
Translate: "Then I asked: "Master, what causes the action of the wind? Is there no atmospheric phenomenon here?"

Original: Ond’elli a me: "Avaccio sarai dove di ciò ti farà l’occhio la risposta, veggendo la cagion che ’l fiato piove"
Translate: "And he said to me, "Soon you'll get to the point where visual understanding will give you the answer, when you can find out the reason for this phenomenology."

Original: E un de’ tristi de la fredda crosta gridò a noi: "O anime crudeli tanto che data v’è l’ultima posta,
Translate: "One of the unhappy trapped in the ice shouted to us, insensitive souls: "You have reached the last stage of your punishment.""

Original: levatemi dal viso i duri veli, sì ch’ïo sfoghi ’l duol che ’l cor m’impregna, un poco, pria che ’l pianto si raggeli"
Translate: "Take off the layer of ice that hides my face so that I can free some of the suffering that has accumulated in my heart before the tears are frozen again."

Original: Per ch’io a lui: "Se vuo’ ch’i’ ti sovvegna, dimmi chi se’, e s’io non ti disbrigo, al fondo de la ghiaccia ir mi convegna"
Translate: "I said to him, "If you need my help, you must first reveal to me who you are. If I cannot free your eyes, may my actions take me to the deepest point of the freezing exterminated."

Original: Rispuose adunque: "I’ son frate Alberigo
Translate: ==References====External links==

Original: i’ son quel da le frutta del mal orto, che qui riprendo dattero per figo"
Translate: I am the one offering figs in exchange for dates from the wicked orchard.

Original: "Oh", diss’io lui, "or se’ tu ancor morto?"
Translate: I asked him: "Have you already exhaled your last breath?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Come ’l mio corpo stea nel mondo sù, nulla scïenza porto
Translate: He told me: "I don't understand how my body can sustain itself on the earth's surface."

Original: Cotal vantaggio ha questa Tolomea, che spesse volte l’anima ci cade innanzi ch’Atropòs mossa le dea
Translate: What Toloma offers as a privilege is often the extinction of the soul before Anthropus puts an end to life.

Original: E perché tu più volontier mi rade le ’nvetrïate lagrime dal volto, sappie che, tosto che l’anima trade  come fec’ïo,
Translate: "In order to avoid the pain of a disappointment similar to what I felt, know that as soon as the soul breaks fidelity as happened in my case, you will have to remove more easily the cold tears from your cheek."

Original: il corpo suo l’è tolto da un demonio, che poscia il governa mentre che ’l tempo suo tutto sia vòlto
Translate: A demonic force controls his body until the moment of his death.

Original: Ella ruina in sì fatta cisterna
Translate: She falls into the dark pit of darkness.

Original: e forse pare ancor lo corpo suso de l’ombra che di qua dietro mi verna
Translate: "maybe the soul, still today, rests in this distant world behind my back"

Original: Tu ’l dei saper, se tu vien pur mo giuso: elli è ser Branca Doria, e son più anni poscia passati ch’el fu sì racchiuso"
Translate: "If you have arrived now, you must know that Ser Branca Doria has been here for many years."

Original: "Io credo", diss’io lui, "che tu m’inganni
Translate: I gave him an accusation: "I think you're lying to me!"

Original: ché Branca Doria non morì unquanche, e mangia e bee e dorme e veste panni"
Translate: "Branca Doria is still alive and carries out normal daily activities such as eating, drinking, sleeping and wearing clothes."

Original: "Nel fosso sù", diss’el, "de’ Malebranche, là dove bolle la tenace pece, non era ancora giunto Michel Zanche,  che questi lasciò il diavolo in sua vece nel corpo suo,
Translate: "After Michele Zanche had not yet reached the Bolgia dei Malebranche, in which he muttered mischievous pitch, they abandoned the devil in his place."

Original: ed un suo prossimano che ’l tradimento insieme con lui fece
Translate: "an ally of his, who betrayed with him"

Original: Ma distendi oggimai in qua la mano
Translate: Stretch your hand here.

Original: aprimi li occhi"
Translate: Open my eyes

Original: E io non gliel’apersi
Translate: I didn't give them access.

Original: e cortesia fu lui esser villano
Translate: A courtesy was given to him by offering him hospitality as if he were a gentleman.

Original: Ahi Genovesi, uomini diversi d'ogne costume e pien d'ogne magagna, perché non siete voi del mondo spersi?
Translate: "Alas, what has caused the attraction of these Genoese to bad habits and defects, so that they are not scattered around the world?"

Original: Ché col peggiore spirto di Romagna trovai di voi un tal, che per sua opra in anima in Cocito già si bagna,
Translate: "You can rewrite the sentence in this way: In the worst of Romagna, I came across a fellow countryman whose exploits had already drowned his soul in the hell of Cocito."

Original: e in corpo par vivo ancor di sopra
Translate: Looks like his body's still breathing the Earth.

Original: "Vexilla regis prodeunt inferni verso di noi
Translate: The pillars of the Sovereign of Hell are approaching us.

Original: però dinanzi mira", disse ’l maestro mio, "se tu ’l discerni"
Translate: "My teacher suggested that I look forward, to see if I could see what I was looking for."

Original: Come quando una grossa nebbia spira, o quando l’emisperio nostro annotta, par di lungi un molin che ’l vento gira,  veder mi parve un tal dificio allotta
Translate: "in motionAs the wind carried the thick fog, and the darkness of the night made itself felt in our hemisphere, so then I felt the movement of a mill that appeared from afar as brought by the same ethereal breath."

Original: poi per lo vento mi ristrinsi retro al duca mio, ché non lì era altra grotta
Translate: "I sheltered from the wind by leaning on my guide, in the absence of other shelters."

Original: Già era, e con paura il metto in metro, là dove l’ombre tutte eran coperte, e trasparien come festuca in vetro
Translate: "I found myself, with terror in my verses, in a place where souls were wrapped in the icy depths of winter and shone like small pieces of glass."

Original: Altre sono a giacere
Translate: Some lie down.

Original: altre stanno erte, quella col capo e quella con le piante
Translate: "Nailed to the groundSome people go straight ahead, while others stick to the ground with their heads pointing upwards."

Original: altra, com’arco, il volto a’ piè rinverte
Translate: "some people bend forward, bend like an arch, and have their faces positioned at their feet."

Original: Quando noi fummo fatti tanto avante, ch’al mio maestro piacque di mostrarmi la creatura ch’ebbe il bel sembiante,
Translate: We reached a point where my teacher thought it appropriate to show me the wonderful creature.

Original: d’innanzi mi si tolse e fé restarmi, "Ecco Dite", dicendo, "ed ecco il loco ove convien che di fortezza t’armi"
Translate: "He pushed me on one side and made me stop, saying: "Here we are at Dite, this is where you have to prepare to face with courage."

Original: Com’io divenni allor gelato e fioco, nol dimandar, lettor, ch’i’ non lo scrivo, però ch’ogne parlar sarebbe poco
Translate: "As I was moved by a deep emotion at that time, I cannot describe with words: I was breathless and unable to speak."

Original: Io non mori’ e non rimasi vivo
Translate: "I survived, I avoided death."

Original: pensa oggimai per te, s’ hai fior d’ingegno, qual io divenni, d’uno e d’altro privo
Translate: "think, with a little creativity, how I had found myself in that situation between life and the afterlife"

Original: Lo ’mperador del doloroso regno da mezzo ’l petto uscia fuor de la ghiaccia
Translate: The emperor of the kingdom of pain emerged from the frozen depths to the belt.

Original: e più con un gigante io mi convegno,  che i giganti non fan con le sue braccia:
Translate: There's a bigger difference between me and a giant than the one between the giants and their arms.

Original: vedi oggimai quant’esser dee quel tutto ch’a così fatta parte si confaccia
Translate: "in relation to that body sector, what are the total measures of that individual"

Original: S’el fu sì bel com’elli è ora brutto, e contra ’l suo fattore alzò le ciglia, ben dee da lui procedere ogne lutto
Translate: "If he had been as attractive as he is now repulsive, and despite this he had resisted his Creator, then it is justified that from him comes all misfortune."

Original: Oh quanto parve a me gran maraviglia quand’io vidi tre facce a la sua testa
Translate: I was amazed to see that his head had three faces.

Original: L’una dinanzi, e quella era vermiglia
Translate: One had been placed in the center and was red.

Original: l’altr’eran due, che s’aggiugnieno a questa sovresso ’l mezzo di ciascuna spalla, e sé giugnieno al loco de la cresta:
Translate: "The other two shoulders joined at the first half of their ends, and finally met behind their heads."

Original: e la destra parea tra bianca e gialla
Translate: It seemed to me that the right was a mixture of white and yellow.

Original: la sinistra a vedere era tal, quali vegnon di là onde ’l Nilo s’avvalla
Translate: the left was of the shade of those who come from the earth where the Nile throws itself into a basin.

Original: Sotto ciascuna uscivan due grand’ali, quanto si convenia a tanto uccello: vele di mar non vid’io mai cotali
Translate: "From under each side two huge wings were sprouting, perfect for such a large creature: I had never seen sails so wide on any ship."

Original: Non avean penne, ma di vispistrello era lor modo
Translate: "He didn't have any pens, but they looked like a bat."

Original: e quelle svolazzava, sì che tre venti si movean da ello:  quindi Cocito tutto s’aggelava
Translate: Lucifer created distinct winds that caused the complete freezing of the lake basin of Cocytus.

Original: Con sei occhi piangëa, e per tre menti gocciava ’l pianto e sanguinosa bava
Translate: "Sobbing, sadness flies out of her six-ray eyes and her pain condensed on the three heads in a reddish slime."

Original: Da ogne bocca dirompea co’ denti un peccatore, a guisa di maciulla, sì che tre ne facea così dolenti
Translate: "He used his teeth as a weave to tear three sinners apart at the same time in each of the three mouths."

Original: A quel dinanzi il mordere era nulla verso ’l graffiar, che talvolta la schiena rimanea de la pelle tutta brulla
Translate: "At the center of the sinner, being scratched was much more painful than being bitten, so much so as to leave the skin of the back torn."

Original: "Quell’anima là sù c’ ha maggior pena", disse ’l maestro, "è Giuda Scarïotto, che ’l capo ha dentro e fuor le gambe mena
Translate: "The master announced: "The ill-capitulated one up there, who suffers the most severe punishment, is Judas Iscariot with his head between Lucifer's jaws and his legs with dangling feet."

Original: De li altri due c’ hanno il capo di sotto, quel che pende dal nero ceffo è Bruto:
Translate: "The other two with their heads turned down, one with a black face is Brutus."

Original: vedi come si storce, e non fa motto
Translate: Look how it wobbles without saying a word

Original: e l’altro è Cassio, che par sì membruto
Translate: Cassius appears so vigorous.

Original: Ma la notte risurge, e oramai è da partir, ché tutto avem veduto"
Translate: "It's almost time to go, since we've examined everything."

Original: Com’a lui piacque, il collo li avvinghiai
Translate: "According to Virgil, I embraced his neck."

Original: ed el prese di tempo e loco poste, e quando l’ali fuoro aperte assai,  appigliò sé a le vellute coste
Translate: "He waited for the right moment and place, and when the monster's wings dilated enough, he grabbed his hips covered in fur."

Original: di vello in vello giù discese poscia tra ’l folto pelo e le gelate croste
Translate: " holding tight a tuft of hair, he went down between his thick hair and the chilly crust of Cocytus"

Original: Quando noi fummo là dove la coscia si volge, a punto in sul grosso de l’anche, lo duca, con fatica e con angoscia,
Translate: "Following the conjunction point of the thigh and pelvis, located at the height of the femur, Virgilio worked hard to progress."

Original: volse la testa ov’elli avea le zanche, e aggrappossi al pel com’om che sale, sì che ’n inferno i’ credea tornar anche
Translate: "He turned his head where Lucifer had his legs, and grabbed his mane like a knight climbing, so I believed that we were returning to Hell."

Original: "Attienti ben, ché per cotali scale", disse ’l maestro, ansando com’uom lasso, "conviensi dipartir da tanto male"
Translate: "The master, with the drowning breathing of a exhausted man, said, "Take strength, for it is our intention to escape this evil by climbing this ladder."

Original: Poi uscì fuor per lo fóro d’un sasso e puose me in su l’orlo a sedere
Translate: "He came out of the crack in the rock and led me to the end of the opening, and then sat me down."

Original: appresso porse a me l’accorto passo
Translate: Moving with caution, he approached me.

Original: Io levai li occhi e credetti vedere Lucifero com’io l’avea lasciato, e vidili le gambe in sù tenere
Translate: "I looked up and, contrary to how I had left it, I saw Lucifer with his legs raised."

Original: e s’io divenni allora travagliato, la gente grossa il pensi, che non vede qual è quel punto ch’io avea passato
Translate: "If then I was perplexed, those who did not grasp the meaning of my action are considered ignorant."

Original: "Lèvati sù", disse ’l maestro, "in piede: la via è lunga e ’l cammino è malvagio, e già il sole a mezza terza riede"
Translate: "The teacher declared that it was necessary to stand up, for there was an exhausting journey to be undertaken and the sun was already halfway through the third hour."

Original: Non era camminata di palagio là ’v’eravam, ma natural burella ch’avea mal suolo e di lume disagio
Translate: "We were in an underground hole, with a uneven and poorly lit floor, very different from what we could have met in a building."

Original: "Prima ch’io de l’abisso mi divella, maestro mio", diss’io quando fui dritto, "a trarmi d’erro un poco mi favella:
Translate: "Once I got up, I turned to my teacher and asked him to enlighten me to solve a matter that I had before leaving the infernal abyss."

Original: ov’è la ghiaccia? e questi com’è fitto sì sottosopra? e come, in sì poc’ora, da sera a mane ha fatto il sol tragitto?"
Translate: "Where is the ice, how can Lucifer be so upside down and how did the sun move so quickly from the evening to the morning?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Tu imagini ancora d’esser di là dal centro, ov’io mi presi al pel del vermo reo che ’l mondo fóra
Translate: "He told me: "You still think you are beyond the center of the Earth, while I am clinging to the mane of the horrible animal that devastates the world."

Original: Di là fosti cotanto quant’io scesi
Translate: You stayed there until I got here.

Original: quand’io mi volsi, tu passasti ’l punto al qual si traggon d’ogne parte i pesi
Translate: "When I turned around, you passed the fulcrum to which all the efforts of the world converge."

Original: E se’ or sotto l’emisperio giunto ch’è contraposto a quel che la gran secca coverchia,
Translate: Now you are under the hemisphere opposite that which faces the earth furrowed by man.

Original: e sotto ’l cui colmo consunto  fu l’uom che nacque e visse sanza pecca
Translate: At the highest height of the heavenly hemisphere was where the life of the one who had never committed a sin ended tragically.

Original: tu haï i piedi in su picciola spera che l’altra faccia fa de la Giudecca
Translate: You stand in balance on a small sphere that has the opposite face in Judecca.

Original: Qui è da man, quando di là è sera
Translate: "In this hemisphere it is morning, while in the other evening it is evening."

Original: e questi, che ne fé scala col pelo, fitto è ancora sì come prim’era
Translate: "Lucifer, who helped us with his hair to climb, is in the same situation as before."

Original: Da questa parte cadde giù dal cielo
Translate: Falls from the sky from this direction

Original: e la terra, che pria di qua si sporse, per paura di lui fé del mar velo,  e venne a l’emisperio nostro
Translate: "The land, previously emerged in the southern hemisphere, was moved by fear of him to take refuge under the waters and to land in our hemisphere."

Original: e forse per fuggir lui lasciò qui loco vòto quella ch’appar di qua, e sù ricorse"
Translate: "And it may be that in order to escape him, that being emerged on this side has left a vacant place and reappeared in the southern hemisphere."

Original: Luogo è là giù da Belzebù remoto tanto quanto la tomba si distende, che non per vista, ma per suono è noto  d’un ruscelletto
Translate: "It is located in a place so far away that it appears in the eyes of Belzebu, as if it were digging into the depths of the earth. However, it is possible to hear the murmur of the river flowing within."

Original: che quivi discende per la buca d’un sasso, ch’elli ha roso, col corso ch’elli avvolge, e poco pende
Translate: "through a canal of rock dug by it in its own path with low inclination, flowing down here"

Original: Lo duca e io per quel cammino ascoso intrammo a ritornar nel chiaro mondo
Translate: The master and I undertook that secret way to reach the light of the sun.

Original: e sanza cura aver d’alcun riposo,  salimmo sù, el primo e io secondo,
Translate: "He set out on his head and I followed him, without even stopping to rest, climbing up to the highest point."

Original: tanto ch’i’ vidi de le cose belle che porta ’l ciel, per un pertugio tondo
Translate: as I watched through a circular opening the stars of the sky

Original: E quindi uscimmo a riveder le stelle
Translate: We went out to contemplate the beauty of the starry sky.
